PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Senators in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth that the proposed Australia Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians, and your petitioners therefore request a national referendum on the Australia Card Bill before the proposal is resubmitted to Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Archer (from two citizens), Michael Baume (from 153 citizens), MacGibbon (from 1,022 citizens), Puplick (from 39 citizens), Stone (from 14 citizens) and Watson (from 5,702 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-1986 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Card and Taxation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
that we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Government's Identity Card;

that this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security;
that we call upon the Government to improve management systems within the Australian Tax Office and other Departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Hamer (from 14 citizens) and MacGibbon (from 11 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Adult Migrant Education Service
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Honourable members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:
We the undersigned strongly protest 1987 cuts to ESL programs for adults, conducted by the Adult Migrant Education Service (AMES) in New South Wales.
Evening ESL classes have been cut by 25%.
The ESL Correspondence course is to be abolished in a few months time.
The English-in-the-Workplace Program has been reduced.
Full-time on-arrival courses have been abolished.
AMES day centres have had their teaching hours reduced.
Community programs have lost teaching hours.
We call for:
(i) the full and immediate restoration of AMES teaching programs in New South Wales to at least 1986 levels and
(ii) a substantial increase in funding to AMES programs in the 1987 budget in view of the recently announced increases in the immigration intake.

PETITION.TITLE: X-Rated Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
1. There is no legal barrier to the importation of X-rated videos into the A.C.T. or to their sale in the A.C.T.
2. The Government has ignored the repeated protests of the Senate and the people of Canberra on this situation.
3. As a result X-rated videos are being sold from Canberra to other States, although they are banned in all States.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate to put pressure on the Government to ban the importation and sale of X-rated video material.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoke Free Air Travel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned,
(i) are greatly disturbed by the dangers to health posed by passive smoking, and evidence of which is being documented daily by medical authorities around the world;

(ii) note that environmental tobacco smoke has been identified as the major pollutant in aeroplane cabins, and that its direct threat to health is recognised in the special leave provisions for flight attendants specifically on grounds of upper respiratory infections;

(iii) appreciate the government's undertaking to legislate for smoke-free travel on aeroplanes, but are dismayed at the apparent reluctance to follow up the Minister for Aviation's December announcement with action; and

(iv) call upon the government to make smoke-free aeroplane travel a reality without further delay, and to ensure that smoke-free areas which cannot be contaminated by recycled pollutants, are available to all aerodromes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Hamer (from nine citizens), Harradine (from 304 citizens), Reid (from 500 citizens) and Zakharov (from 33 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we consider the 2% discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 October 1986 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government. The Commonwealth has reneged on an established commitment as incorporated in Commonwealth legislation and benefit promise pensions are not being paid in full. In particular we resent the long-term effect of the discounting. The pension loss is compounded throughout the life of a pensioner and surviving dependants-into the 21st century for many. We consider this Government-induced penalty to be out of all proportion to the short-term ``extraordinary circumstances of the economy'' given as the reason for the discounting.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should urge the Government to:

1. limit the pension discounting effect of the Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Act 1986 to the period 10 October 1986 to 1 July 1987 so that pensions are restored to the 9 October 1986 level as a base for the 1987 pension adjustment; and
2. consult with organisations representing pensioners before changing the terms and conditions of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Schemes.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bjelke-Petersen (from 97 citizens), Reid (from four citizens) and Zakharov (from 18 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Imperial System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth objection to the metric system and request the Government to restore the imperial system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Armidale: ABC-FM service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of certain citizens of the city of Armidale, New South Wales, respectfully showeth:
(a) that there is a very limited range of radio services in rural areas;
(b) that the introduction of ABC-FM significantly broadens the radio options of rural listeners;

(c) that Armidale as a major centre is more isolated from capital cities than most other rural cities and would support and benefit from ABC-FM more than most because of the nature of the town and its population, and most keenly feels its absence;
(d) that, as Armidale is classed as an infill area, it will, on current Department of Communications plans, be one of the last areas in Australia to be connected to ABC-FM;
(e) that there are no technical barriers to the immediate connection of Armidale to ABC-FM as such connection is not dependent on Band II clearance;
(f) that the cost of such connection would form a minute proportion of the moneys being assigned to developing rural radio and television services;

(g) that, therefore, early connection of Armidale ABC-FM would involve minimum disruption to overall plans for rural radio and television services while benefiting greatly a significant area of Northern New South Wales;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Department of Communications be asked to arrange for the early connection of Armidale to the ABC-FM service.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully requests that the Australia Card Legislation be rejected because the proposed system:
(1) has been demonstrated to have no capacity to stop tax evasion, Social Security fraud, illegal immigration or to recoup the revenue lost through abuse of these systems as was claimed.
(2) will impose a large financial impact on Australian citizens, and has been demonstrated by the Parliament's own Joint Committee to be not cost effective.
(3) has been shown to have the capacity to actually aid and abet both illegal immigration and organised crime.
(4) is designed to cause a great intrusion and disruption to the normal day to day activities of all citizens.
(5) does not contain the very necessary barriers to invasion of privacy, and loss of personal liberties.
(6) will in both the words of the Government and the HIC be enlarged to encompass far greater uses, and the compilation of much more information on the data base.

And your petitioners humbly pray that in the light of the obvious and proven inability of the proposed Australia Card to achieve its stated objectives that the Government explain the reason why it is persisting in reintroducing this legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth opposition to the introduction of any form of national identification system especially a system known as Australia Card.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled should oppose any Legislation designed to impose such a system on the people of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled
The humble Petition of Citizens of Australia shows-

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the World in their efforts to achieve a Nuclear Free South Pacific, and such Decision being endorsed by the people at a General Election.

Your Petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled Stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the United States Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on Nuclear Vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of Zones of Peace and Nuclear Free Zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Otway Forests: Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the leader and members of the Senate of Australia:
the petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows that there has been clear demonstration of public dissatisfaction with the mismanagement of the Victorian Otway forests, and we pray that:
The Constitution of Australia be reformed to recognise significant expressions of public concern, e.g. petitions, by the formation of a committee to represent public requests.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Warships in Australian Ports
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled and to the Australian Government:
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:
foreign warships visiting Australian ports give acceptability to the increasing militarization of the Indian and Pacific Oceans;
W.A. endures a visit of a foreign warship on average every 1.5 weeks;
a situation of de facto ``home-porting'' facilities exists in W.A.;
there is increasing citizen concern that nuclear armed/nuclear powered warships put Australian ports and people at risk in many ways.

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap Defence Space Research Facility
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
The agreement between the United States of America and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap terminates on 19th October 1986.
In the event of war between the United States and the Soviet Union, access by the United States to Pine Gap's facilities makes it a probable nuclear target.
The people of Australia are entitled to be consulted through their representatives in Parliament, on any extension or modification of the agreement affecting their lives, security and welfare.
Access by all nations to Pine Gap's capacity to monitor and verify compliance with existing and future nuclear limitations treaties could contribute to world peace and security.
And your petitioners humbly pray that:
1. The agreement between the United States and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap not be extended beyond October 1986.

2. Public discussion and inquiry be instituted into the feasibility of negotiating a new agreement with the United Nations during the International Year of Peace offering the verifications facilities of the Pine Gap base to all nations.
3. Any agreement concerning the future use of Pine Gap be referred to Parliament for ratification.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoke Free Air Travel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

We the undersigned citizens call on the Commonwealth Government to introduce a ban on smoking on flights of 90 minutes or less. This ban should be introduced irrespective of the stand-off attitudes adopted by the airlines at present.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Uranium mining and processing is dangerous to the health and well-being and ecology of the Earth and its citizens,
By-products of uranium are toxics for periods of up to 500,000 years, and are an intrinsic part of the production of nuclear weapons,
Existing safeguards are inadequate, and are not properly monitored.
The policy of the Australian Government permits the entry into Australian territory of vessels and aircraft without the assurance that they are not nuclear powered or armed.
Such vessels pose a threat to both the security and well-being of Australia and its citizens.
The presence of foreign military and communication bases on Australian soil seriously endangers the health and well-being of Australia and its citizens.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable Senators will take cognisance of the above and take immediate action to remove the above dangers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes the presence in Fremantle last week of 17 United States warships with over 200 nuclear weapons between them, described as the biggest invasion of Western Australia since the Second World War;

(b) notes, too, the constant reference to ``Rest and Recreation'' for 14 000 sailors and marines which is a polite euphemism for the physical and sexual requirements of a large number of young men who have been at sea for 5 months;

(c) commends the Australian peace movement for non-violent opposition to the visits of these nuclear armed warships to our ports which represent Australia's support for nuclear war fighting strategies of the US Government;
(d) condemns the failure of the authorities to provide the citizens of Western Australia with an adequate Port Safety Plan that would give guidance in the event of a nuclear accident; and

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTERS OF STATE AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987ADMINISTRATIVE ARRANGEMENTS BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 September, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is agreeable to dealing cognately with the Ministers of State Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 and the Administrative Arrangements Bill 1987 and also to dealing with the statement which was put down yesterday by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, although there may well be further opportunities for debate of that statement in this place. The Bills relate to what Senator Button described yesterday as the most far-reaching reshaping of the Federal machinery of government and of public administration in our history. He went on to say that the number of departments has been reduced from 28 to 18, providing scope for savings through economies of scale and the removal of overlap and duplication across many areas of hitherto separate bureaucratic units. The legislation, therefore, which touches in only a small way upon this major reorganisation, is nonetheless important in that we have had a very substantial revision of the Public Service of this country and no doubt that will have a very great effect on the way Australia is governed.

SPEECH.PARA: Administrative Arrangements Legislation

The Ministers of State Amendment Bill (No.2) 1987 expands the number of Ministers which can be appointed by the Government from 27 to 30. The Opposition will oppose that Bill for reasons which I will explain during this speech. The other Bill, the Administrative Arrangements Bill 1987, makes machinery changes-changes which relate to the fact that the Government has appointed more than one Minister to a department. There are changes to the Acts Interpretation Act which to this point has been written on the basis of there being one Minister per department. In addition, the second Bill makes amendments to the Public Service Act. This is the first stage of amendments necessary to abolish the Public Service Board and replace it with a commissioner who will have independent statu- tory authority for the policy aspects of recruitment, promotion, mobility, discipline and retirement within the Public Service. We have these items of legislation with respect to the second Bill which makes a number of machinery changes which contribute to the major re-organisation that has been brought forward. We will move for there to be some committee exam- ination of this Bill. We will do that because we believe there exists in the Public Service at the moment considerable confusion about the effect of some of the Government's changes and a great deal of concern among the public servants who serve this country about the precise meaning of what has been achieved by the Government.

In addition, the Government has claimed that there will be savings and, indeed, it has predicted that there will be a reduction of some 3,000 in the Public Service as a result of these changes. Yet there has been no detail provided to the Parliament on how those savings will be achieved. There are doubts among the Opposition that the Government has, in fact, proceeded to deal with this matter in the best way possible. Indeed, we have some doubts about some of the functional groupings which have been made by the Government and we would like to see those examined by the Parliament. It is our hope that the Senate will agree to a committee examination of these changes on the basis that the changes are so major that something more than a mere announcement of the Parliament is warranted.

That should not cause any short term embarrassment to the Government because in the statement which was made yesterday by both the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Leader of the Government in this place they reported that the arrangements have been in place for seven weeks. They claim that the arrangements are working well. Since the arrangements have been in place and working for seven weeks without this legislation, there can be no suggestion that any delay in dealing with the legislation would in any way sabotage the current operation of government or put at risk the proper and orderly administration of this country. Of course, the Opposition would not wish to do that. But it is quite clear, as the arrangements are already in place, that there is no risk in there being some period of examination of this legislation by a Senate committee.

I have already indicated the reason that we want this committee examination. We think there is confusion, concern and doubts about the savings, and we have serious doubts about some of the groupings which the Government has proposed. Some look very odd indeed. We find that Local Government has gone to Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I think most Australians who are involved in local government would say there is no apparent natural grouping between the function of Local Government and Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Transport matters are complex and major and have been brought together with Communications. I think there are issues both as to the suitability of the fit and as to the volume of work which is imposed upon the Ministers, particularly the Minister who is principally responsible for that departmental grouping, Senator Gareth Evans. It is probably fair to say that there are no two areas more in need of reform and change in Australia if we are to develop a modern and productive economy than the fields of transport and communications. It would appear to the Opposition that there are very real risks of ministerial overload and resulting incapacity to effect some of the essential changes because of the grouping of those functions.

We find, under the tutelage of Mr John Brown, a ministry comprising the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. One would have to say that there are some oddities about that grouping. Some of the Territories' residents might say that they do not particularly lie naturally within that grouping of ministries. Other matters need examination, such as the precise legal status of Associate Secretaries and the ongoing arrangements with respect to the different positions which have been created and so on, but I do not wish to canvass those matters in this debate. Rather, there is ample need for a more careful consideration by this Parliament of what the Government is putting forward. For example, the Government has indicated that it will abolish the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. We are left almost completely in the dark as to how the Commonwealth's responsibilities in Aboriginal affairs will in fact be carried out under these new arrangements.

There are a host of reasons why the Opposition believes it is important that we should move the amendment which I think has been circulated in my name and which proposes that the second Bill, the Administrative Arrangements Bill 1987, should be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, which of course is not yet in place. The amendment requires that:

the Administrative Arrangements Bill 1987 be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations for inquiry and report, upon the establishment of that committee or, if a committee of that name is not established, to a committee specified in a subsequent resolution.

The main matters which I wish to raise in debating this legislation today are what I see as the most notable features of what the Government has done in this matter. The first is that it has substantially copied what the Opposition first proposed in 1984 with respect to the administrative reform. Secondly, I want to comment on the obvious duplicity shown by the Government in the debate on these issues over recent years, particularly before the last election. I remind the Senate of what the Opposition proposed in 1984 with respect to public administration. Under the heading `Functional Organisation of Ministry and Departments', we said that the key factors were:

the need to increase the capacity for Cabinet Ministers to concentrate on priorities and set the course of Government; they need to improve effective co-ordination of key policy areas and to change the present system of competing Departments working against each other; the need to improve the efficiency of the administrative functions of Departments, especially when this can lead to cost savings.
We went on, in a series of specific recommendations, to say:

Leaner, more efficient Government would result from a consolidation of existing Departments into twelve major Departments of State (including the Cabinet Office) led by 12 Cabinet Ministers; including the Prime Minister. Cabinet Ministers would be responsible for interrelated areas of policy. Most Cabinet Ministers would have one or more Junior Ministers reporting to them and each being responsible for a group of programs allocated to their departments. While under the Constitution, it is necessary for each Minister to be responsible for a specific area of policy, the Prime Minister's Administrative Orders can require a group of Ministers to work for a Member of the Cabinet.
We said:

The objectives of the organisational arrangement would be to relieve the Cabinet Ministers of major day-to-day administrative responsibilities for individual programs, and thus ensure there was time for their primarly role of shaping policy priorities, developing initiatives, identifying potential problems, evaluating policy implementation and participating in the full range of Cabinet work.
We said:

Groupings of existing Departments and functions within the new group Cabinet structure would be designed to minimise the current inter-Departmental conflicts caused by demarcation and accept the reality that many programs involve more than one Department.

I suppose that it ought to be a matter of satisfaction for the Opposition that, three years after the Opposition announced that approach to the organisation of government, we find the Prime Minister saying that he had decided to recommend to the Governor-General major changes to the structure of Commonwealth administration. He said:

The changes are aimed at achieving substantial enhancement of the decision-making process and at removing overlap and duplication of functions. In summary, the changes will substantially reduce the number of Commonwealth departments to achieve administrative efficiencies and savings, better policy co-ordination and improved budget processes; enhanced ministerial control of departments by moving to a 2-level ministerial structure, each Cabinet minister being responsible for one of 16 large portfolios supported in most cases by one or more non-Cabinet ministers responsible for specific parts of the Cabinet minister's portfolio, or assisting across the range of functions.

I do not have time in this debate to draw more fully on what we announced in 1984 and put out in more detail in 1987, and the close parallels which can be drawn with what the Prime Minister announced on 14 July 1987. It is a source of some satisfaction to see the outlines which were developed and promoted by the Opposition being adopted by the Government. But we find extraordinary duplicity and dishonesty on the part of the Government in discussion about these issues, particularly prior to the recent election. We find, for example, that Ministers such as the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, went into the Canberra-Queanbeyan area and threatened that the changes advocated by the Opposition:
. . . would cause a depression of 1930s magnitude, home values would collapse as thousands of people were forced to leave the region-
that is, the Canberra-Queanbeyan region-
in an attempt to find work elsewhere. As always, Queanbeyan would be hit first, hardest and longest.

We had a threat that people who owned homes in this area would see their homes losing 30 to 40 per cent of their value. That was a particularly good example of the level of debate which was encouraged by the Labor Party on these major administrative reforms which it trumpeted three days after the election. There was plenty of evidence of that sort of scare campaign in so many areas of the recent election campaign.

When one looks at the Prime Minister's contribution, one gets a quite horrifying picture of duplicity which is totally unworthy of somebody who holds the highest elected office in this country. In the week before the election was held the Prime Minister said that he was prepared to look at the sorts of changes which had been advocated by the Opposition. He said that no recommendations on this matter had been received from the Block inquiry. A matter of days before the election he said that no recommendations had been received.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you suggesting that that is untrue?

—No decisions had been taken. We then have a situation where an election is held on the basis that the Government is prepared to receive recommendations and prepared to look at these matters, but with no decisions taken and no recommendations received. I have been interrupted by Senator Button, who is at the table, asking me whether I am suggesting that this is untrue. I hope that Senator Button will tell us the truth of this matter because we had the Prime Minister on 5 July this year denying that the Government had a secret agenda involving plans to slash the number of departments. In other words there was no agenda in the Australian Labor Party for this reduction in the number of Government departments. Less than a week before the election there was no secret agenda. The attempts by Liberals, including Senator Reid and Mr David Connolly, to get the Labor Party to disclose its agenda for change were completely unsuccessful. The Government had no secret agenda involving plans to slash the number of departments. One can only look at the evidence that is available-that is, that there was a clear statement by the Prime Minister a matter of days before the election. Of course, the evidence is that three days after the election he announced major changes to the structure of the administration of the Commonwealth which have now been put in place.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply want to make the point that whilst the Opposition has, over the past three years, consistently supported streamlining of Commonwealth administration and the making of substantial changes to improve the government of this country, there has been a refusal by the Labor Party to enter into honest and open debate on this matter. Instead, a refuge in scare tactics and distortion has meant that there has been no sensible political debate on these issues at all prior to the election which is, of course, the important time.

I would like to express my personal contempt for that approach which will no doubt continue whilst it is blessed with political success and whilst the media of this country are prepared to accept a situation where politicians are positively admired for saying one thing and doing another. This is a blatant example of the corruption of political debate in this country. I would like to express my contempt and abhorrence of it. I think it is wrong and I think it is damaging us. In fact, we find an extraordinary similarity of pattern in so many of the major debates which are of significance to the future of this country.

I remind you, Mr Deputy President, of the debate on privatisation where statements were made by Ministers such as the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister. They were contemptuous of the proposals that the Opposition put forward in a most careful way on the need to look to privatisation, in particular as a means of encouraging a more efficient economy and competition in our economy. These were serious matters put forward in a considered way with detailed principles being laid out in our `Policies for Business' document published in July of last year. We had from the Labor Party a continued campaign of vilification and of trying to strike fear in the hearts of every employee of a statutory authority. Once again that has been a perversion of debate on an issue which is of major significance to this country. The success or failure of the ministerial arrangements to which I have referred, in particular in transport and communications which are of fundamental importance to the welfare of this country, will depend upon the Government being able to achieve greater efficiency in those areas. The reality is that if the Opposition were prepared to distort the debate in the way that the Labor Party has we could do much to frustrate and thwart reforms which are desperately needed in this country. As an Opposition we have chosen not to do that. I think it is a criminal shame that there has been so little acknowledgment in the Press of the distortion of debate which has occurred and the destruction which has been wrought.

I refer to privatisation. I will not repeat the many quotes which are available, particularly during the 1985 period. These quotes come not only from the Commonwealth but also from the South Australian Premier, Mr Bannon, and the Western Australian Premier, Mr Burke. I despise their dishonest approach which I believe is a very poor reflection on them.

TALK.START.PARA: —You ran away from the issue yourselves.

—The Leader of the Government says that we ran away from the issue. I invite him to look at what we published in our policies from July of last year which involved the principles that would apply to privatisation and our commitment to the privatisation of Trans Australia Airlines, of Qantas Airways Ltd, of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation, of the Australian Industry Development Corporation and a whole series of bodies which we indicated would add to the economic efficiency of this country. The whole process of political debate is important. If it is conducted on the basis that one can lie with impunity, democracy is corrupted in this country. It is all very well for members of the Australian Labor Party to smirk because they have had electoral success on the basis of lies, but I say to them that they are prepared to damage this country in a very political, totally cynical way.

SPEECH.PARA: We saw the same thing in the wages policy debate before the election. We have consistently said that real wage rises will depend upon there being real increases in productivity and wealth in this country. We saw both the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) offering-I have so often heard Labor's gibes about fistfuls of dollars-wage rises that would come under the Labor Party without regard to the question of productivity. The Prime Minister backed off in that debate some weeks before the election, but we saw again during the campaign a perversion of the debate on an issue which is of fundamental importance to this country. We saw exactly the same thing with respect to the lead-up to this Budget. We were told by the Treasurer that a balanced budget was not an appropriate thing for Australia. He claimed in the third or fourth line of his Budget Speech last night that that is what he has achieved. Whether he has achieved it we will debate elsewhere.

I raised those matters because I believe that, in terms of tackling the fundamental problems which this country faces and which cannot be masked under the recent benign response to the Budget-the reality of our external debt, the reality of our poor levels of investment and the reality of the stiff competition we face-there is a need for a greater degree of honesty in debate in this place, in this country, in the House of Representatives and in politics generally if we are to succeed in tackling those problems in an effective way.

I also want to raise in this debate in the same context the sort of smear campaign which is frequently indulged in by this Government against anybody who seeks to oppose it. We have seen this at both State and Federal levels. Over the last few days we have seen it with respect to the President of the Liberal Party of Australia in Western Australia, Mr Keith Simpson, where there was a leakage to the Government and a leakage by the Government of his personal financial affairs when there is no suggestion of any impropriety. An attempt has been made to smear him in a way which is disgraceful and typical of the attitude adopted by this Government; that is, that if one pokes one's head up against the parapet and opposes the Government one will be smeared and put upon. We saw a bit of this attitude yesterday with respect to Mr Des Moore. Mr Des Moore, who has written critically about this Government's economic policy, has had his affairs paraded before the Senate. Whether or not we have the full story we will never know. All we know is that someone who served the Commonwealth for 28 years, who has now resigned from the Commonwealth and is writing articles and papers which are critical of this Government's approach to economic policy, is smeared by the Minister for Finance over events of his departure from the Public Service. Again I regard with contempt that approach to politics by the Labor Party, and I believe that it should be thoroughly condemned by everybody in this chamber.

We oppose the legislation that will permit the appointment of extra Ministers because we do not believe it is necessary to have 30 Ministers. The expansion of the size of the Ministry is clearly and simply to accommodate the internal political difficulties of the Labor Party and its factional disputes. We saw the manner in which the Special Minister of State, Senator Ryan, was treated and the tokenism that she now represents in the odd selection of tasks that she has. We saw the factional leaders of the Labor Party, Senator Robert Ray and Senator Richardson, deliver the spoils of office to themselves to the exclusion of Senator Tate and to the concern of the Prime Minister, who saw that certain interests that he wanted represented in the Ministry would no longer be represented. All of that is a matter of public record. The subsequent rescue of Senator Tate-the Opposition expresses some approval about it--

TALK.START.PARA: —Assisted by Premier Gray.

—My colleague interjects that he was assisted by Premier Gray-so that Tasmania would be represented may well have been reasonable but it is not something that requires an addition to the size of the Ministry. The fact that there was the Bolkus-Reynolds sideways shuffle is again not a matter which requires the expenditure of additional taxpayers' funds to solve the Labor Party's problems. Thinking about Senator Bolkus and Senator Reynolds, I was reminded of Sammy Davis Jr who was asked before the days of affirmative action what his handicap on the golf course was. He said, `You are talking to a one-eyed Catholic Jew. You do not have to talk to me about handicaps'.

SPEECH.PARA: I wondered why the appointment to the Ministry of a woman from Queensland was superior to the appointment of an Australian of Greek origin from South Australia. It was that sort of nonsense which led to the Government decision to require a larger Ministry. We believe that that is a quite unnecessary burden on Australian taxpayers and we will oppose and vote against the Ministers of State Amendment Bill. We hope the Australian Democrats will join us. We do not believe that the public should pay for the ALP's games or that the expansion in the size of the Ministry has anything to do with the welfare of Australia. It has to do with the welfare of the Australian Labor Party. With respect to the Administrative Arrangements Bill 1987, I move:

Leave out all words after `That', insert: `the Administrative Arrangements Bill 1987 be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations for inquiry and report, upon the establishment of that committee or, if a committee of that name is not established, to a committee specified in a subsequent resolution'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats would like to address a few particular points to the Ministers of State Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 and the Administrative Arrangements Bill 1987. Perhaps the fundamental point is that although there may be arguments for and against the legislation, particularly the first Bill which relates to an increase in the size of the Ministry, the Australian Democrats believe that that increase is the prerogative of the executive arm of government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats in this chamber have, I think, a reputation for opposing Executive interference in the legitimate activities of the Parliament-the legislature. Certainly for a party such as ours to interfere in Executive changes of this type which, as I will demonstrate later, are on a relatively minor scale would, I think, place us in the position of being hard pressed to argue the consistency of principle. It is very important that we keep these responsibilities in mind. I am sure that very often in session, as in past sessions, it will be necessary for us to argue the responsibility of the Parliament as a whole in the face of the Executive wanting to override that in one way or another.

The Opposition's intention of opposing and voting against the Ministers of State Amendment Bill is not supported by the Australian Democrats for that reason in particular. That is not to say that we do not have concerns but I point out that this is not the first time that this Act has been amended. As honourable senators will know, it has been amended a great many times. This is the first time the Ministry has reached 30, although it is not the first time that ministerial duties have been undertaken by such a high number. In 1971, there were 27 Ministers plus six assistant Ministers which, of course, totals 33, and that was under a coalition government. That was in a total Parliament of 185 members, which means that the percentage of Ministers and assistant Ministers was 17.8 per cent. In 1982 there were 26 Ministers and three Parliamentary Secretaries, 29 in all, in a Parliament of 189 members, which constituted 15.3 per cent. In the present Parliament of 224 members the Ministry, upon the passage of this legislation, will total 30 but that will represent only 13.4 per cent of the size of the Parliament. So some of the arguments which the Opposition puts forward pale in the face of those figures.

Amongst those amendments to the Ministers of State Act to which I referred, the amendments which have taken place under coalition governments are interesting. In 1956 there were 22 Ministers. In 1964 the number was raised to 25, in 1967 to 26 and in 1971 to 27. So the Opposition has a record of increasing the size of the Ministry and on each occasion of having been able to argue its case. As I have demonstrated, there are arguments to the contrary. In relative terms the increase in the size of the Ministry to 30 in this instance is not able to be portrayed as extravagant.

We must consider the Ministers of State Amendment Bill and the increase in the size of the Ministry to 30 also in terms of the overall intention of the Government to reform and reconstruct the whole of the administrative structure. It is important that we do not look at this Bill in isolation. It seems a bit surprising that the Opposition is prepared to vote against this Bill and yet is taking a much softer stance on the second Bill, which is integral to the whole situation. It is interesting to speculate on whether the Opposition is prepared to back up its words with actions. I wonder whether the Opposition, to demonstrate the strength of feeling which is going to cause its members to vote against this Bill, will be taking three of its members off its front bench, either three of its rotating Ministers, who might by now be getting giddy, or perhaps some of those who are, or who hope they are, in a more stationary position. Or is the Opposition, as usual, going to take what it sees as the high moral ground, saying one thing and doing another?

Quite a feature of what Senator Chaney had to say to us this morning was that he is appalled by the way the Government has so often said one thing and then another. That is a case of people in glass houses throwing stones. Even in the last session of the Parliament we experienced so many instances of the Opposition saying one thing and then doing another. Some examples come to mind very quickly. We heard a great hue and cry from the Opposition benches about the implementation of tertiary fees. Yet the Opposition supported the Government in their introduction. We heard bleating from the Opposition, and we saw it in the Press, about the imposition of taxes on fruit juice and milk and the increase in the tax on wine. But there was nothing in the way of an Opposition vote, and no action to back up its words.

The National Party does not come out of this too well either, having in its own self-interest joined the Government to increase the size of the Parliament and having voted with the Government in its deal to turn over the ownership of Australia's media to a few very powerful and very friendly media bosses. There are other instances, such as the watering down of the access to freedom of information by members of the community. Although making noises about the legislation, the Opposition chose not to oppose it. So Senator Chaney is on pretty thin ice when he expresses moral outrage about politicians saying one thing and doing another. In this place one's vote counts much more than what one says.

Some petulance was displayed in the face of the move the Government is making to restructure the administration of government on the basis that this is something the Opposition wanted to do itself. The Opposition ought by now to be used to this Government taking initiatives which make it practically turn green with envy. One such initiative is the deregulation of the financial system. Who brought in the foreign banks? It was not a nice solid, conservative coalition government; it was a nice solid, conservative Labor Government. Who introduced the tertiary fees to which I have already referred? Who has been putting the squeeze on the welfare sector for all of these years? All of these initiatives have made the people on my right practically turn green with envy. Another initiative is the policy which is now in place to mine and sell uranium, even to France which chooses to conduct nuclear tests in our own backyard. We still have the issue of privatisation to come. Again, I am sure pea green will be the colour of the people on my right as the debate goes on and as this conservative Labor Government also moves in that area. The Opposition ought to be used to this by now. From time to time we are seeing a sop to the people in the community who have suggested to the Australian Labor Party that they are not prepared to get used to some of the initiatives it takes. Whilst we, the Australian Democrats, are still here we will oppose this kind of exercise both in what we say and how we vote. As I have said, the National Party does not come out too well in this kind of comparison either.

I refer to the restructuring of the Ministry. These two Bills need to be looked at together. We are not supporting the Opposition-as Senator Chaney had hoped-in its move against the Ministers of State Amendment Bill, nor are we supporting the reference of the Administrative Arrangements Bill to a committee. Of course, there are concerns about the Administrative Arrangements Bill which are wide ranging. Although we have been told by the Prime Minister's office that the cost of the increase in ministerial salaries will be about $98,000, most of us look upon that with a grain of salt. However, I think it is quite clear that the savings throughout the Public Service under the changed arrangements administered by the new ministerial system will be substantial. That is greatly desired although it will amount to some $8m, we are told, in this financial year and $16.5m in 1988-89. That is something which has yet to be shown. Nevertheless, the recommendations of the report by the Efficiency Scrutiny Unit of Proposed Successor Arrangements of the Public Service Board-the Block report-in substance give some hope that this will happen.

There is a strong argument for more direct ministerial responsibility. Anyone who has seen Yes, Minister will agree on the need to have a well-informed, strategically placed group of Ministers able-if they can-to guide and control their departments. However, there are some concerns. The statement made by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) yesterday provided details of the ministerial arrangements and responsibilities. Some of those concerns have been highlighted. One concern is that some confusion might arise from those responsibilities. I understand that concern to be one which has caused the Opposition to want to refer the legislation to a committee. In some specific instances this problem is clearly evident. For instance, the Special Minister of State, Senator Ryan, is designated as being the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women and for the Bicentenary. That is quite clear but it is followed by another designation which says, `and generally across the portfolio'. That is not a clear definition of the division of responsibility. That may become a problem. As I said in my opening remarks, this is a matter for the executive arm of Government to decide. If it comes unstuck it will be on the Government's head. It will be its problem and in due course it will go to the people to see whether they have a concern about it.

Another example of a fairly fuzzy definition in the arrangements of Ministers is seen in the arrangements under the Minister for Industry, Commerce and Technology, Senator Button, where we have the Assisting Minister for Science and Small Business, Mr Barry Jones. Beneath the designation of his responsibilities is the statement that two Ministers will work together in various areas which are listed. Again, it is a fairly fuzzy definition of the division of responsibility. The Minister for Trade Negotiations, Mr Duffy, has what appears to be a confusing range of responsibilities which go beyond the super ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade to which he is attached, to the Industry, Technology and Commerce ministry and the Primary Industries and Energy ministry. These concerns have been raised in the context that when it comes to the need for the definition of ministerial responsibility there may be problems.

Another issue which has been of concern to some people is the creation of super ministries. Whilst it might give Ministers a better strategic placing, it may also have the regrettable effect of perhaps submerging some areas of ministerial responsibility which are seen in the day to day context as being more important and more weighty. I have in mind here areas such as consumer affairs and the arts. For instance, one can see how issues in the areas covered by the super ministries might be seen to be less important perhaps because they are not handled by the senior Minister or because they are mixed up in a grab-bag of other portfolio responsibilities. In this time of economic stringency, in this time of gung-ho economic decision making, based very much on financial and economic benefits, the Australian Democrats would be very concerned if areas such as consumer affairs and the arts were given less significance in the minds of the Ministers involved.

I turn now to particular concerns the Australian Democrats have with the rearrangement. With the abolition of the Public Service Board-as the legislation is before us-goes the abolition of specific responsibility for equal employment opportunity within the Public Service as a whole. That responsibility under the Government's legislation is devolved to departmental heads who, unfortunately, have no track record to give any confidence in the area of equal employment opportunity. The Democrats believe that the Equal Employment Opportunity Unit must be kept intact within the new Public Service Commission. I propose to move an amendment at the committee stage of this legislation. An appropriate central unit within the Public Service Commission is necessary because it involves much more than the simple monitoring process which has been outlined, particularly in the Minister's statement yesterday. More than monitoring oversight is needed. To our credit, we have in recent times passed significant sex discrimination and equal opportunity legislation. Along with a number of groups in the community we think that to abolish or water down the equal employment opportunity provisions which come under the Public Service Board would be a retrograde step.

More than simple oversight is needed. A central agency is needed, not just to monitor and co-ordinate implementation, but also to undertake, for instance, specialised testing and recruitment of Aboriginals and people with disabilities, to undertake overall statistical analysis to develop a standard Service-wide policy on issues such as sexual harassment and to provide a central reference and resource for equal employment opportunity. It seems somewhat ironic that this move has been made. I hope that the Government will look seriously at the amendment which I will propose. The Government itself, as I have said, has been instrumental in recent times in the passage of far-reaching legislation, which has been strongly supported by the Australian Democrats, in the area of equal opportunity.

Mr Block seemed to see no need for a well co-ordinated and focused attack on discrimination, but I think all of us know that this is still necessary against discrimination in all of its forms. The measures in the legislation before us really leave the Government without an effective means of achieving these goals which it has worked on and stated so strongly in the past. In fact, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself sent a message via Public Service Board bulletin No. 76 in April this year from which I would like to quote. He said:
All Australians know of my Government's commitment to Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO)-a commitment based on the belief that Equal Employment Opportunity is a matter of justice.

Certainly, who could disagree with that? In his message via the Public Service Board bulletin the Prime Minister pointed to his Government's commitment to `equity in employment and the delivery of government services' which, he said, is guaranteed. He said too-and this was in only April of this year:

The aim of our Equal Employment Opportunity program is unchanged-that is to eliminate discrimination in the work place and create an environment in which all Australians have a fair chance to compete for jobs and careers in the public service, develop their full potential and contribute to a more effective and efficient management of government business.

As I said, I hope that the Government will look very seriously at the amendment which the Australian Democrats will move at the committee stage-an amendment which we have designed to ensure that the new Australian Public Service Management Advisory Board will have on it a member whose specific responsibility is equal employment opportunity. The Board will include a person specifically approved by the union movement and one who is specifically to have demonstrated expertise in the area of private industry. The Government's commitment to equal employment opportunity should not be downgraded or watered down at this time when, because we still have an unemployment level of around 8 per cent-and amongst young people of almost a quarter of their number-people are unemployed for longer periods and find it more difficult to get jobs. It is a time when it is very important that the Government in particular, through its Public Service, take a strong stand and set a very good and strong example in the area of equal employment opportunity.

It is a matter of great regret to the Australian Democrats that both the Labor Government and the Liberal-National Opposition appear to have accepted the plateau of 8 per cent unemployment. It is not a matter of public debate any more. It is not something that surfaced or was particularly addressed in the Budget yesterday. It is not something that the Australian Democrats are prepared to accept. We must remember that, amongst that 8 per cent unemployed, those who find it most difficult to find employment are those who for one reason or another suffer some disadvantage. It is only through strong continuing action in the area of equal employment opportunity that we can ensure that we do not add to the disadvantage of those people, not all of whom, of course, are in minority groups. Women, quite significantly, of course, are not a minority group; we are still in the majority, but this is still a group which suffers in the whole work market-place. Women are still not earning on average anything like the same figures as men. They are still not covered as well, for instance, by superannuation; they still do not have adequate access to child care arrangements. They still do not feature in the high levels of employment but are clustered in low status, low-paid employment. If only for women, I would argue very strongly for the amendment which the Australian Democrats will propose. It is not, of course, only for women; it is for a whole range of categories of people-from Aboriginal people through to the disabled of all kinds-who for one reason or another need this kind of backup and support and this kind of example from a government whose past record in this area is to be commended.

As I have said, this move-the increase in the Ministry and the changed arrangements in the Public Service-is not one which anyone can guarantee will work. Aspects of the recommendations of the Block report seem to us to meet the need for Ministers to have a very clear and direct oversight in their areas of responsibility, and we believe that it is the Government's prerogative to make these decisions. One point about the new changed ministerial arrangements that we believe could be borne in mind is that there is in fact an advantage of a political nature in having a super-Minister and assisting Minister situation in that it can actually be used as a useful training ground for Ministers. A couple of junior Ministers sitting in the chamber might resent the implication that they need some training.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not at all.

—It is very humble of Senator Ray to accede to that suggestion. This arrangement, of course, allows for greater flexibility and the ability to reshuffle Ministers and the responsibilities that they have, should that be necessary. I have cautioned that I believe some of the statement of ministerial responsibility is fuzzy around the edges and that this may leave the Government vulnerable, but, as I have said, that is the Government's responsibility. As I have also said, the Australian Democrats believe that the various arms of government have their particular responsibilities. We believe there are times when the Parliament has a role and must be listened to. We have demonstrated this belief, for instance, in our attempts to make the Parliament responsible when this nation decides to send its young men overseas to war. We believe that is something on which the Parliament as a whole should be able to make the decision and that it should not be in the hands of the Executive or the Prime Minister alone. There are areas where the Australian Democrats believe the whole Parliament, as the voice of the people, must act, but this is an area where we believe that the executive arm of government has the prerogative.

SPEECH.PARA: We therefore will not oppose the Ministers of State Amendment Bill, as the Opposition will, and we will not support the Opposition's moves to send the Administrative Arrangements Bill to a committee. We believe that the test of whether it will work is in the hands of the Government and of the Public Service. We will, however, be pressing very hard for our equal employment opportunity amendment and we commend that amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the Minister, Senator Tate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I am a Parliamentary Secretary. Did you call me by my correct title?
—I called you the Minister.

—That is very prophetic of you, sir, but I must indulge perhaps even more modestly than Senator Ray has by way of an interjection and note for the Hansard record that my title at the moment is Parliamentary Secretary for Justice. The attitude of the Opposition in relation to the debate that we are engaged in on the amendment to the Ministers of State Act and the Administrative Arrangements Bill 1987 is a very petulant one. Senator Chaney, unfortunately, sounded like a very poor loser. Had the Opposition parties succeeded in convincing the Australian electorate that a majority of their candidates for seats in the House of Representatives deserved their trust and confidence, I believe the Government which would have been led by Mr Howard would have been entitled to come to this Parliament and seek the passage of legislation putting into effect its own particular stamp and requirements and desires in relation to the administration of government on behalf of the people of Australia. I think the contribution made by the Opposition to this debate is marked by the fact that it has been rather unsettled and indeed very envious of the Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke, who has acted in a very decisive way in relation to the restructuring of the administration of government in this country, both at the ministerial and administrative level. We have a Prime Minister who has been willing to undertake, admittedly very rapidly but, as I say, decisively-and that is the mark of this Government--
—With no plans, no agenda. How amazing he is-in three days.

—We are told that there were no plans and no agenda. In fact the point is that, whereas the Opposition squandered its opportunity to reform and restructure the Public Service and the ministerial arrangements, we had the benefit not of relying, as the Opposition clearly had, merely on the advice of public servants so that one had a stagnation in the administrative arrangements, but on the advice of Mr David Block, for example-a consultant of the highest expertise and integrity who was brought in from the outside. These measures have been taken very largely on the basis of Mr Block's advice to the Prime Minister, which he was able to read at the tail end of the election campaign-and I believe that the press reports have it that the Prime Minister closeted himself in his room and read many of these reports on Sunday, 12 July. We had advice available to us from outside sources whereas the present Opposition year after year had allowed the Public Service to stagnate and the arrangements to just carry on with a little bit of tinkering here and there.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a Prime Minister who was prepared to take a decisive step, a step not dependent on advice from those within the bureaucracy. Furthermore, if I may say so, his timing was rather exquisite in that he made his announcement before Ministers were wedded to their bureaucrats in the new arrangements following upon our re-election. If I may say so, that was a very sensible move by the Prime Minister, which re-inforces my view that what is really being evidenced today is a rather envious streak in honourable senators on the other side of the chamber who see themselves confronted by a Prime Minister who is willing and able to take this sort of decisive action before, admittedly, Ministers got into a comfortable mode of operation with their expectations of continuing with the same bureaucratic arrangements as before. Both Ministers and the bureaucracy were confronted with a decisive Prime Minister. I believe that it was not a bad thing to undo the stagnation that has characterised these arrangements for so many years-indeed, so many decades. As I say, the fact that reports were available to the Prime Minister in a way that did not make him beholden to the bureaucracy is something which ought to be noted. I do not think Australians want to see the actual arrangement of the bureaucracy and, certainly, ministerial arrangements determined by advice from those sources alone.

I believe that a tribute is due to Mr David Block for the fact that we now have an opportunity, as has been said in the Governor- General's Speech and certainly in the Budget Papers last night, to carry out this massive restructuring of the administration of government at the Commonwealth level such that we will produce savings of $107m in a full year and cut staffing levels by 3,100 by 1988-89. That is an incredible change, and one which releases funds for us, as a Labor government, to devote expenditure to those areas which are thought to be important in the fulfilment of our election promises and manifesto. For example, in particular it enables us confidently to release funds which are now to be moved into the households of many hundreds of thousands of Australians by way of a fantastic, stupendous increase in the support available to families with two or three children, particularly those on or just below average weekly earnings. As was pointed out by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his statement on the Budget Papers last night, a family with two children under 13 years of age and another child, say, 14 years of age, with an income of some $340 a week and renting privately, will have an extra $69 a week in their pockets to spend on their children and their needs. How could a wage earner going out into the market-place, even with second tier negotiations, productivity agreements and all the rest of it, ever hope to bring back into his household to support his children an extra $69 a week after tax? He would have to go out and fight to get $100 a week before tax.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I know you think that I am slightly diverting and that I am not being entirely relevant, but I am trying to show that this Government, by making these decisive moves, has released money which would otherwise be going into the old, stagnated bureaucratic set up. It has enabled those moneys to be moved to help Australian families and households who are in the most need. I think that is really the overall picture that one ought to keep in mind in these debates. It enables us to carry through as a Labor government our highest priorities. As we all know, the first goal of this third Hawke Government is to help financially families and households in some distress so that no Australian child shall be in poverty. That is a very important motive in terms of what we have before us by way of ministerial and administrative rearrangements.

I am glad that nobody on the other side of the chamber was unkind enough or ungracious enough to suggest that I had a personal interest in joining in this debate. I have joined in the debate simply because my Leader, Senator Button, insisted that I should. But the fact is that the Ministers of State Act 1952 requires amendment to increase the size of the Ministry from 27 to 30. It is not entirely true, as Senator Powell said, that this is a matter entirely within the prerogative of government. The fact is that section 65 of the Constitution-and the Senate will recall that this was written and effective from 1901-says this:
Until the Parliament otherwise provides-
and that is what we are doing today-
the Ministers of State shall not exceed seven in number . . .

So there is clearly under the Constitution a parliamentary role in extending the size of the Ministry. We see that that section indicates that the Federal Government began its life in 1901-it had, of course, a much smaller range of responsibilities-with seven ministries. From time to time that number has been increased. Now we come before the Parliament, perhaps not with a prerogative but certainly with a very real primacy, with the claim that the Prime Minister, having submitted to the Governor-General certain proposals, be given the 30 Ministers which have been indicated as necessary if we are fully to realise the benefit of this new restructuring of government which has been undertaken.

The fact is that in moving from 27 to 30 there will be a two-tier system of senior portfolio Ministers and junior portfolio Ministers, and I will come to that in a moment. Senator Peter Durack possibly will want to comment on that matter in his contribution to the debate. May I say, by the way, that there is no retrospective clause in this Bill. Initially, I was a bit disappointed to see that in that I have not received any pay since 24 July in regard to the duties that I have discharged as a quasi-Minister. But rather than lose my seat in this chamber for taking an office of profit under the Crown in those interim weeks, I am quite happy that there is not. I just want to put on the record that I am doing this job at the moment out of patriotic fervour, as it were.

I think there is a very real and proper question to be asked about the two-tier system of Ministers that has been put in place. The chamber will be aware that the Government had the benefit of an opinion given by the Solicitor-General, Dr Gavan Griffith, and made available to the Governor-General before the Prime Minister approached the Governor-General for the swearing in of Ministers on 24 July. As I say, that opinion was made available to the Governor-General. In that opinion the Solicitor-General says that the association of junior Ministers with a senior portfolio Minister, so that several Ministers are involved in the one departmental supervision, is compatible with section 64 of the Constitution. This has not always been thought to be so. I believe that Sir Garfield Barwick thought it may not be the case. Nevertheless, that opinion is available from the Solicitor-General. He makes his opinion not only on the basis of a textual analysis of section 64, which reads:
The Governor-General may appoint officers to administer such departments of State of the Commonwealth as the Governor-General in Council may establish.

He builds somewhat on the text and looks at the plurality of expression in that section, which speaks of Ministers collectively. Not only does he build on that textual analysis to say that this arrangement is compatible with the Constitution, but he also looks at the experience of the Westminster Parliament in the United Kingdom. I think honourable senators would know that, whilst in some ways we have a parliamentary system modelled on the United States of America, with the House of Representatives and the Senate, we are a parliamentary system in that the Ministers of government are the elected representatives of the people and indeed are parliamentarians at the same time as they are Ministers of the Crown.

Looking to the experience in the United Kingdom, we find a common practice of senior and junior Ministers. Indeed, the Solicitor-General, Dr Gavan Griffith, in quoting from Parris's Constitutional Bureaucracy, published in 1969, comments that during the nineteenth century it was possible to make a satisfying career at the level of junior minister-I hope it proves to be so-`doing the work of a department presided over by a grandee'. `Grandee' is a word that perhaps some of the senior portfolio Ministers may adopt as a self-description, but I am merely quoting from a nineteenth century text.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some more than temporary portfolio Ministers might resent that.
—Yes. Parris notes that `each department normally needed a junior minister'. Dr Griffith continues:

SPEECH.PARA: It was regarded as the first rung of the ladder. As early as 1835, when he chose Gladstone to be his Under-Secretary, Lord Aberdeen wrote-
in words that might really have been prophetic of, for example, Senator Robert Ray, as commented on by Senator Powell in her remarks-
`it is a fine opening for a young man of talent and ambition and places him in the way to highest distinction'.

I think that experience of the United Kingdom and the Westminster parliamentary system gives us a fairly sure and sound basis for considering that these arrangements are constitutional. I am happy to make that opinion available to Senator Peter Durack, who approached me a little earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been asking you to make it available to the public for some time.
—The honourable senator asked me a moment ago whether--
—Will you table it?
—I am happy to table it and to make it available to the public. I table the opinion of Dr Gavan Griffith in the matter of appointment of Ministers and section 64 of the Constitution.
—Is he right?

—That raises the question of the justiciability of this whole matter, and whether in fact we are to be faced with a challenge to these arrangements in the High Court of Australia. We know that Mr David Connolly, the Opposition spokesman in this area, said that there would be such a challenge. I would be interested to hear from Senator Peter Durack, or perhaps Senator Austin Lewis, or even Senator Chaney, whether indeed it is the intention of the Opposition to mount a challenge in the High Court to these arrangements. As I say, I am not even sure of the justiciability of these matters. The opinion was made available, as I say, to the Governor-General. Nevertheless, I think some response from the Opposition on that point would be useful.

SPEECH.PARA: I move to the administrative arrangements themselves. I think this matter is really summed up in an editorial in the Australian of 25 July titled `Reforms must succeed' which in its leading paragraph says:

The reforms introduced by the Hawke Government to the administrative structure of federal government ministries hold out the prospect of achieving smaller government, greater administrative efficiency and significant economies.

I believe that is the motive, the hope and the expectation that we have, and we are entitled to put them into place and, as Senator Powell has quite rightly pointed out, to be judged by the electorate at the end of the three years as to whether those goals have indeed been achieved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Four years.
—Not four years, Senator, because I do not think we are going to the people with the idea of extending this term of the Parliament.
—That is a pity.

—I can only concur. Nevertheless, I think the point is that at the end of three years an assessment will be made by the electorate of these particular reforms which, as I say, are designed to produce savings of $107m and to cut 3,100 off staffing levels by 1988-89.

SPEECH.PARA: The question, therefore, is whether this chamber should send this whole package of administrative arrangements to a Senate committee for its consideration and deliberation. I think it is quite clear from my remarks that this really is a matter for Executive Government. It is peculiarly for the Prime Minister and for the Executive Government to arrange the departments of state in a way which most efficiently meets the end, the goals, for which the Government has been elected by the people of Australia. I do not believe that it is correct and proper for a Senate committee to be involved in the structuring of the departments of the Executive Government. I believe that there will be very adequate opportunity, as traditionally there is on the Estimates committees, whichever form they take in this session, for the sorts of questions that are normally asked under the salaries and administration vote in relation to the new structures. It is quite clear that that will go ahead. I think that is the adequate, traditional and proper opportunity for the Senate chamber to acquaint itself with these arrangements. But for a Senate committee to have the pretension of actually looking into these arrangements and suggesting that they might be restructured in this way or that way, or perhaps vetoing this or that reform or restructuring, I think goes far beyond the bounds of the realm of a parliamentary committee. This is something peculiarly within the task of the Executive, on which it will be judged.

I turn to the very important matter brought up by Senator Powell by way of an amendment to the structures that replace the Public Service Board and the new arrangements that are in place. The Australian Democrats have asked us to look at it very seriously. I am sure that Senator Button has taken on board the request of the Democrats that a commitment to equal employment opportunity be demonstrated to be at the very core and heart of the new arrangements and not dispersed amongst the departments as a responsibility of the departmental heads. As you know, Mr Acting Deputy President, much of this rearrangement is based on the idea of devolving as much responsibility, in particular managerial responsibility, to departmental heads away from a central bureaucratic concern such as the old Public Service Board. Insofar as there are nevertheless some structures which have a more central character, it may well be appropriate that within those structures the question of equal employment opportunity receive a definite place. I am sure that by the end of the committee stage debate Senator Powell's amendment will have received very due consideration by the Government and that a reply will then be available.

That is the case for the passage of this legislation through this chamber. I believe it does mark a decisive moment in the ministerial and administrative arrangements of government in this country. It is the mark of a Prime Minister who chose exquisite timing, I believe, to bring these matters in before the bureaucracy and the new Ministers were wedded to old and really quite stagnant arrangements that had been tinkered with but basically had been built merely on foundations laid many years before. With the aid of David Block, and with the advice of certain members of the bureaucracy, we have come up with what I believe is a quite striking rearrangement which, at the ministerial level and at the level of administration, will give this Government the opportunity to fulfil the mandate which was given to it by the Australian people in such decisive terms on 11 July.
