TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to follow Senator Tate in this debate because he has addressed himself primarily to the subject on which I also want to make my contribution, namely, the new structure of the Ministry and, of course, of the departments which the Ministers are sworn in to administer under the Constitution. Senator Tate in his contribution attempted to rewrite history to the greater glory of his leader, Prime Minister Hawke. I was rather distressed by the somewhat sycophantic nature of Senator Tate's contribution. I have always had some respect for his independent role, but I suppose he owes so much to Prime Minister Hawke in recent times for even his survival as a senator, much less the Gladstonian prospects of moving from the position of Parliamentary Secretary to Minister as a result of this legislation, and no doubt ultimately occupying the position of Senator Button, maybe sooner than Senator Button would wish.

SPEECH.PARA: Putting aside these personal explanations about Senator Tate's contribution, I want to return to the major issue. I support the Opposition's decision to oppose the increase in the Ministry from 27 to 30 proposed by the Ministers of State Amendment Bill (No. 2). I do not wish to add to what Senator Chaney said on that question, only to say that the new structure of government did not require the increase in the Ministry and that there are major political and economic reasons why that Ministry should have been reduced rather than increased; nor do I want to address myself particularly to the new departmental setup and that part of the Administrative Arrangements Bill which deals with the abolition of the Public Service Board and so on, all of which no doubt are interesting subjects, certainly to me and no doubt to many other senators.

I wish particularly to speak about the new Ministry, which was the major subject addressed by Senator Tate. Senator Tate has tabled the opinion of the Solicitor-General, Dr Griffith, which I am sure will be of interest to senators. I regret that as yet I have not had the opportunity of reading it, but extracts of it have been read to me and obviously it will repay study. I did not realise that the opinion had such interesting historical content as well about the nature of British Ministries and the early career of William Gladstone, but no doubt that makes it even more interesting.

This is an important starting point for what I want to say, because the question of having senior and junior Ministers attached to a particular department or ministry has a long history. I did not realise that it had such a long history, going back to 1835, but certainly it has a long history in the United Kingdom. The matter has been the subject of a great deal of discussion over many years in Australia. Senator Tate has been trying to rewrite history by saying that this was some great, new, brilliant idea that struck the Prime Minister on 12 July, the day after the election. It seems to be damning that the Prime Minister, after he had been in government for 4 1/2 years, should have suddenly focused on this issue when he was confronted with having to create a new government, having won the election on 11 July, and when he was also faced with the problem of a good deal of in-fighting among the factions, and several other problems such as saving Senator Tate's position on the front bench. It does not say very much for Prime Minister Hawke that he came to grips with this matter only a few days before he set it up. That does not seem to suggest that there was a very adequate study by the Prime Minister or those who were advising him.

No doubt Mr Block justifies the praise that has been heaped upon him by Senator Tate, but I do not think it could be suggested, and I do not think Mr Block would suggest, that this was any original idea of his. As we have already heard from Senator Tate, the idea goes back more than a century in the United Kingdom. It has certainly been the subject of a good deal of discussion in the upper echelons of the Federal bureaucracy for many years. I have had some experience in government in dealing with proposals which emanated from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet in relation to new structures of government. Things were done about it by coalition governments. In government we pioneered the idea of the office of Parliamentary Secretary held by Senator Tate at the moment. Indeed, constitutional questions were raised and I had my first contact with this subject as to what would be the status of Parliamentary Secretaries, whether they could be paid and so on. Coalition governments also attempted to use the idea of Assistant Ministers so that Ministers with fairly small junior portfolios could be allocated to assist senior Ministers. That was very much along the same lines as these proposals.

A great deal of nonsense has been talked since the Prime Minister had this sudden conversion to reform on 12 July. As Senator Chaney clearly pointed out, we not only made contributions in this respect when we were in government to improve the structure of government and to enhance ministerial control, but since we have been in opposition we have given a great deal of thought to perfecting these arrangements. In fact, we suggested in the 1984 and 1987 elections that there could be some major changes very much along the lines that the Government chose to adopt after the last election. At that election not only did the Opposition in its policy on public administration foreshadow that sort of thing at a departmental level, but the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, in his policy speech announced that the Opposition, if successful, would be abolishing a number of departments, including the department of which I was shadow Minister at the time, Resources and Energy. That was proposed by me. My experience in studying that Department was that there was no justification in having a separate Department of Resources and Energy and that it could be brought within a larger structure of administration.

It was interesting that the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), who was then the Minister for Resources and Energy, was deeply shocked by the Opposition's suggestion that his toffee apple might be taken away from him if those ideas ever appealed to his leader. I remember that when it was announced Senator Gareth Evans made a vigorous denunciation of the Opposition's proposal to abolish the Department of Resources and Energy. Although the Opposition supports the new structure in broad terms, we are by no means struck dumb by the wonder of the genius that Senator Tate would have us believe the Prime Minister has shown.

TALK.START.PARA: —We would not want you to be struck dumb, Senator.

—I do not think even Senator Button is very much struck with the wonder of it either, or at least I hope he is not. The question I find most interesting and important about the new arrangements relates to the impact they will have on ministerial responsibility and the accountability of Ministers to the Parliament. In his statement of 11 August the Prime Minister announced in detail the new structure and he said that the intention of appointing more than one Minister to administer a portfolio was to enhance ministerial control. In other words, there would be what the Prime Minister called `a portfolio Minister'-that is a senior Minister-who would be ultimately accountable for the portfolio. Other Ministers would have clear accountability for areas of responsibility allocated to them and would be required to answer questions in relation to those areas.

SPEECH.PARA: I was also rather surprised to find that in his speech the Parliamentary Secretary for Justice (Senator Tate) talked about senior and junior Ministers. As I understand it, the Government's decision means that Ministers are of equal status. There are not, in fact, senior and junior Ministers under this arrangement; it is a system described by the Prime Minister as `dual administration of portfolios'. This might sound like a debating point but it may be very important in relation to ministerial accountability to Parliament and to the electorate. I notice that the Prime Minister is always referring to the Cabinet Minister as `the portfolio Minister' and to the others as `the other Ministers'. The whole scheme is a dual administration concept-dual administration of departments with more than one Minister actually administering a department. I do not think by any means that this is just a particular choice of words. In my view this concept is dictated by the Constitution itself and, as I understand it, Dr Griffith has adopted this view. Section 64 of the Constitution is the foundation of executive power of Ministers. It says:
The Governor-General may appoint officers to administer such departments of State of the Commonwealth as the Governor-General in Council may establish.
That section goes on to enshrine in the Constitution our whole basis of responsible government and ministerial responsibility to Parliament. It says:
After the first general election no Minister of State shall hold office for a longer period than three months unless he is or becomes a senator or a member of the House of Representatives.

The whole concept is that one cannot have Ministers of state under section 64 of the Constitution unless they are given the administration of a department because only those people who are given the administration of a department can be classified as the Queen's Ministers of state in terms of section 64.

The great debate which has gone on-even though it may have gone on unknown to Senator Tate and apparently unknown to the Prime Minister until 12 July-is whether more than one Minister could administer a department under section 64 of the Constitution. I do not think that there has ever been any doubt in recent times that one cannot have a Minister unless he or she has a department to administer. The real question is whether more than one Minister can participate in the administration of a department. Obviously that question in itself has posed difficulties. Is one to have an old Roman concept of duumvirates? How will one assign responsibilities and so on if two Ministers are jostling with each other in administering a department? On the face of it there are very considerable difficulties. But of course these difficulties can be overcome at the political level; these matters are within the political control and power of a Prime Minister. As I understand it, that is what has been done by the Prime Minister by consultation within the Ministry. I presume that letters have been written about these matters and on such an interesting question it would be helpful if the Government were to table the letters that have passed so that we can see how the whole thing works.

TALK.START.PARA: —Helpful to whom?

—The Minister is making a big song and dance about the wonders of this new setup. It would be of great interest to students of government. The Minister has already indicated the allocation of responsibilities in the statement he put out yesterday, which presumably he has not read very carefully. The details are there. Political points can be made here and I think that Senator Harradine will probably make a few. If I have time I might do so also. But there are no politics in my comments; I am simply saying that it would be helpful to those who are interested in the whole structure of government to know exactly how these obvious administrative difficulties have been and will be overcome.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not agree with the legal opinions that have been advanced that the Constitution prevents more than one Minister being assigned to the administration of a department. I think that that is a very possible constitutional arrangement, although there is clearly doubt about it. Senator Tate asked whether the Opposition will challenge it. As far as I know the Opposition will not challenge it, but it is not for me to say so. It does seem to have constitutional foundations. It has the support and opinion of Dr Griffith, the Solicitor-General, and on the face of it it seems to me to be a reasonable legal proposal. Whether it will be challenged is another matter. Senator Tate referred to Mr Connolly, who was the then Opposition spokesman on these matters. Mr Connolly said that it would be challenged. Of course, it is likely to be challenged; it is a new concept. If a Minister signs a document which interferes with an individual's rights, that person may well challenge the legal validity of it. As I said, I do not believe that the Opposition intends to do so because the whole issue of this new structure of government is of great interest. It is an experiment. We will be watching it very closely simply because it is a useful and innovative contribution to the methods of administration of the Commonwealth Government. I cannot say whether it will stand up if in fact it is challenged in the High Court of Australia. That doubt-there is undoubtedly a doubt there-has been one of the reasons why the full system of dual administration was not implemented by coalition governments in the past, certainly those which I have had anything to do with, and other arrangements were made. As I have said, the Opposition was looking towards an innovative method of this kind even though it may carry with it some legal risks. That is a fair summary of the situation at the legal level.

The most important issue, of course, is the question of ministerial responsibility. My own view is that the only way this dual administration can stand up is if the Ministers-whoever they are; whether there are two, three or even 10 of them-are assigned to a particular department and become the Queen's Ministers of state because they are appointed to administer such departments of state as the Governor-General establishes. The Constitution does not state that Ministers can be assigned to administer bits and pieces of a department. It states, `administer such departments'. TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has had some form of consultation, informally, by letter or whatever, but Senator Button does not seem to want us to know too much about it. We may have to seek that information under the Freedom of Information Act, which, as far as I can see, the Government now regrets having supported when it was in opposition. Thank goodness for the Freedom of Information Act, which the coalition government brought in, because, if we cannot get such information voluntarily, we may be able to get it under that Act. The Prime Minister, in his statement of 11 August, which was repeated by Senator Button yesterday, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I am releasing a list of the functions to be performed by other ministers, but wish to emphasise that the list is indicative and will in no way prevent either portfolio ministers operating within the nominated areas or other ministers being given additional responsibilities over time.

It is a very flexible arrangement and it emphasises the fact that, in law and in constitutional terms, these Ministers are ultimately responsible for the whole of their department. I am a little concerned by other statements made by the Prime Minister on 11 August, and in the statement put down yesterday, in which the Government has tried to qualify in some way the degree of responsibility of the second stream Ministers. They are not junior Ministers; that is quite clear.

The whole ministerial tradition in the United Kingdom is based upon having senior and junior Ministers. But as I have pointed out, that is not the structure created here, nor does the Prime Minister refer to it as such. I do not know why Senator Tate did so in his speech. Even in the United Kingdom, under the rule of having senior and junior Ministers-very clearly junior Ministers-the tradition of accountability to Parliament has been very well established. We all remember that when Lord Carrington, the then Foreign Secretary, resigned at the beginning of the war with Argentina because of his feeling of failed responsibility on his part or on the part of his Department to warn the government adequately about the likelihood of the Argentinian invasion of the Falklands, not only he but also his junior Ministers resigned-even though the junior Ministers had absolutely no direct responsibility for any failure there may have been, tenuous and all as it probably was, on the part of Lord Carrington. The tradition of junior Ministers being held responsible along with their senior Ministers has been well established in the United Kingdom and that case was the most recent example of it.

It is very important, on the occasion of this new structure being established, that we affirm clearly-I am disappointed that the Government has not more clearly affirmed it-the full responsibilities and accountability of Ministers not only for their own personal actions but also in relation to the whole of their departments, the Parliament and the electorate. I believe that is essentially the right position and essentially the constitutional position. I hope the Government, in implementing this new structure that it has created, will acknowledge and act upon full responsibility of relevant Ministers for the whole of their departments.

It may be as a practical matter that portfolio and other Ministers will decide between themselves who will answer questions. But let us take the case of the portfolio Minister being in the House of Representatives and the other Minister responsible being in the Senate. I would expect the Minister in this place to answer any questions that may be put to him regarding the department with which his office is connected and for which he was sworn in by the Governor-General in the document that I have had incorporated in Hansard. That principle has now been clarified in the amendments to the Acts Interpretation Act, one of which we are dealing with in this debate. It is made clear that, where an Act relates to a portfolio covering more than one Minister, that Act will be applicable to all relevant Ministers. Any of those Ministers can exercise the statutory powers given, but only one of them may do so in any particular case, such as the signing of a document. I believe that this new structure does and ought to preserve the full effect of ministerial responsibility, and I hope that the Government will in practice observe that very high and important tradition of our public life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was most interested in the points that have just been made by Senator Durack. It is to those points that I wish to refer very briefly, although certainly not in the erudite fashion of Senator Durack or with his long experience.

SPEECH.PARA: The Administrative Arrangements Bill 1987, one of the two Bills before us, provides, inter alia, for an Australian Public Service Management Advisory Board, comprising part time members who will include the Commissioner, the secretaries of certain departments, a person with a trade union background and a person with private sector experience. The new body's functions will include the provision of advice to the Government on significant issues relating to the management of the Australian Public Service.

The Australian Public Service deserves a great shake up. On a number of occasions over the last six or seven years I have stood in this place decrying the fact that the employment structure of the Australian Public Service has discriminated against the employment of youth in the Service. Frankly, the position has been absolutely disastrous for youth. Consideration has been given to this matter by a number of Ministers though that consideration has not been reported to this Parliament. I would certainly like to hear from the Ministers a report from their departments about this question.

An honourable senator adverted to the fact that there is substantial unemployment in Australia and that this issue has not received the attention it deserved. Hundreds of thousands of people in Australia are unemployed; almost a quarter of teenagers who are not at school are unemployed. That is an absolute disgrace. The youth unemployment rate is almost three times the unemployment rate for older persons. To date nothing really effective has been done. Sure, we have had the Priority One: Young Australia program, training programs and so on but where are the permanent jobs for those people who have been trained? As far as the Australian Public Service is concerned, it is a question of declining job opportunities for youth as a percentage of total employees in the Public Service.

The position is as I stated in a notice of motion listed on the Notice Paper on Tuesday. The latest figures available to me and to this Parliament indicate that in 1966, persons under 21 years of age constituted 22.2 per cent of the Australian Public Service staff. This figure fell to 12.2 per cent in 1974 and to an all time low of 6.5 per cent as at December 1985. That is a disgraceful situation but it is repeated in many State public services. Initiatives must be taken to rectify that situation. I know that some initiatives have been suggested in one State. Those initiatives suggest that there is a need for a clear statement of support at policy level and that that is the starting point for any successful program which is aimed at employing a fair share of youth in the Public Service.

Time and time again the Government has stated that it is in favour of making youth a priority but the real test is whether youth is getting a fair share of employment in the Public Service, for which the Government is responsible, and it is not. Surely that is an indictment of the Government's own policy. It is not through lack of will on the Government's part because the Ministers concerned are very serious about the matter. I know that the Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters, Mr Willis, is very concerned about it. It is the structures in the Public Service that need attention and a bit of bucking up to ensure that they carry out the policy of the Government in respect of youth employment. I hope that what the Government is seeking to put in place in this legislation has that effect.

I now turn to the Minister of State Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. The point made by Senator Durack is a valid one. It is important to recognise-I think Senator Powell made this point-that the executive Government has the prerogative, both constitutionally and electorally, to determine the number of Ministers and portfolios. That is a decision for the Governor-General, strictly in accordance with the Constitution, on the advice of the Government. Obviously, the Senate does not wish to interfere with that prerogative but the Senate and, indeed, the people of Australia must ask some questions about ministerial responsibility. The point made by Senator Durack is a valid one. He indicated that in his view there is no constitutional bar to two Ministers having responsibility within the one portfolio. I am not so sure of that but I bow to superior knowledge in respect of this matter and take it that that is constitutionally feasible. However, it is important to recognise and to emphasise that if there are two Ministers, the question must be asked: Who has the ultimate responsibility and, in particular, who is accountable to the Parliament? The Parliament has the ultimate audit and control over those who exercise executive power. It is important that we know that the Ministers are accountable to this Parliament.

I raise one matter about the division of res-ponsibilities within portfolios which was referred to in the statement by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). It is associated with the matters we are discussing now. According to the division of responsibilities of the Special Minister of State, Senator Ryan will also assist the Minister for Community Ser-vices and Health (Dr Blewett) and have responsibility for a number of areas, one of which has taken my interest, namely, bioethical issues including the establishment of advisory structures. Bioethical issues are very important. They deal with life-not only the beginning of life but the end of life. Right to life issues-the basic right of individuals-have always been within the purview of the Attorney-General. After all, the Attorney-General is the member of Parliament responsible for the initiation of legislation into Parliament and its passage through the legislature, particularly Bills dealing with criminal law. We are dealing with issues about a person's right to exist being taken away, say, for example, by exercising euthanasia, and that would attract a criminal penalty. Surely it is an issue over which the Attorney-General should retain control. I believe in all the States this issue is the responsibility of the Attorney-General.

TALK.START.PARA: —Doesn't he still retain control by virtue of the need for him to present legislation on these matters?

—I do not know whether that means simply that Senator Ryan will be responsible for the co-ordination of these issues within the health portfolio and that the Attorney-General will have overall responsibility. I assume that that is the case. In respect of a national body concerned with reproductive technology, the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill 1985 recommends in paragraph 4.46 on page 54 of its report:

SPEECH.PARA: The body would be broadly representative and chaired by an eminent lay person. In matters falling within Commonwealth jurisdiction it would be responsible to the Commonwealth Attorney-General supported by an IDC (Interdepartmental Committee) including the Health portfolio.

Am I to assume that under the new administrative arrangements and division of responsibilities this area will be Senator Ryan's responsibility as it relates to the Department of Health? This recommendation of the Committee was, as far as I can recall, the unanimous view of the members of that all-party Committee. It is important to register that fact here and now so that we can have some clarification of the matter. I assume that the point made under the division of responsibilities within the portfolio is only an indication of the responsibility of Senator Ryan within the Health portfolio and is not intended to usurp the responsibility which ultimately bears on the Attorney-General in respect of these matters and that it particularly does not pre-empt a proper consideration of the Senate Select Committee's recommendation contained in paragraph 4.46 of its report.

I am not in a position ultimately to interfere with what is a government responsibility-establishing the number of portfolios and the number of ministries. There may be benefit in having this matter considered by a committee but that should not inhibit the exercise of proper administrative authority by those on whom the responsibility has been placed. In the ultimate I would certainly support the legislation that is before us. Whether this matter is referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations is beside the point. Ultimately I will support the Bill as it stands and hope that a clarification of the matter I have raised will be forthcoming.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills that the Senate is debating at the moment are the Ministers of State Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 and the Administrative Arrangements Bill 1987. The first Bill, the Ministers of State Amendment Bill, proposes to expand the Ministry from 27 to 30. As my Leader, Senator Chaney, has said, the Opposition will be opposing the Bill for one very good reason: at a time when the Government is talking about, and the community is demanding, smaller government, to expand the Ministry by three seems to run absolutely contrary to the theme that that would imply. If we really believe in smaller and more efficient government, there is no way that that is compatible with having an expanded Ministry, particularly when the Ministry was expanded purely for the purpose of allowing factional arrangements to be sorted out to satisfaction within the Australian Labour Party after the election.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us be quite clear on this. There was no science in expanding the Ministry from 27 to 30. It was sheer, cold, hard-headed politics on the part of the factional managers of the Government and a reluctance and inability on the part of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to exert his authority to the extent where he could keep the size of the Government within reasonable bounds. So there is no earthly justification for an expansion of the Ministry from 27 to 30. It will lead to bigger government, not smaller government. It will lead to less efficient management of government activities. It will lead to a further lessening of the role of the Parliament relative to the Executive, a constant trend for far too many years now. If we really believe in a parliamentary democratic system, it is about time we took it seriously and considered limiting the size of the Executive Government, and not continually expanding it. So the Opposition will oppose the Ministers of State Amendment Bill.

The second Bill, to which I will address most of my remarks, is the Administrative Arrangements Bill 1987, which gives effect to a quite fundamental restructuring of the Australian Public Service into different departments and a different structuring and ordering of departments. It also abolishes the Public Service Board, replacing it with a single Public Service Commissioner, with many of the other duties of the Board being farmed out to other areas and departments.

The Opposition has moved an amendment to refer the Administrative Arrangements Bill to the appropriate Senate committee. I note that the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine are not going to support our amendment and that, therefore, it will not be carried. Nevertheless, I wish to stress its importance. The Opposition will be calling for a vote on it because it is a very important and significant amendment. As do other Opposition senators, I accept the point which has been made by the Democrats and by Senator Harradine that in many ways it is the responsibility of the Government to order its executive and departmental arrangements. However, for us to say that the Government has carte blanche and that the Parliament has no responsibility to consider the most fundamental change in Public Service structures we have seen in a long time is an abrogation on our part of what is properly and entirely appropriately a parliamentary role of scrutiny. I hope, therefore, that those who have said they will oppose the reference to the Committee will think again, although I realise that it is a forlorn hope.

There are a couple of background points about the changes that have been made which I think we should take note of. I certainly wish to draw them to the attention of the Senate. Two key features have marked Labor's 4 1/2 years of reign in government. The first has been a massive increase in the size of government. There has been an enormous increase in the number of public servants employed either by government departments or by statutory authorities. An additional 44 statutory authorities have been created since this Government took office.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying that as a net figure? We have abolished a number of them, too. You had better refer to them.

—The Government might have abolished a few rats and mice but it has abolished nothing of any significance. There has been a very significant increase in the overall number of statutory authorities. There certainly has been an enormous increase, as the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) well knows, in the total number of public servants employed in departments or in statutory bodies. That is a trend that is quite contrary to the interests of this country. It is something of which we ought to be aware.

SPEECH.PARA: The second major thing that has happened over the last 4 1/4 years has been the tremendous increase in the politicisation of the Public Service. That, I believe, has been a building on the legacy first started by the Whitlam Administration between 1972 and 1975. Of all the legacies-and there were an enormous number-the Whitlam Government left this nation, the biggest and the worst was the politicisation of the Public Service. I thought that it had reached a very high level of art form under the Whitlam Government, but I have to say that the Hawke Government has made the Whitlam Government look amateurish in this context. The long term implications for this country of the politicisation of the Public Service are absolutely enormous. We have seen some recent classic--

TALK.START.PARA: —It fits in with banana republics, doesn't it?

—Very much so. One of the great problems of the banana republic nations of this world is that they have not had professional, non-political public services. So Senator MacGibbon is quite right in making that point. We have seen some classic examples of it in recent times. Perhaps the most spectacular was the one that occurred a couple of weeks ago with the outburst by the permanent head of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Charles Perkins.
—Come on. It happened in your period of government, too, and you did nothing about it. You know that.

—I will come to that. There is a fundamental difference between what has happened under the Minister's Government and what happened under the previous Government. The incredible fact of the Perkins outburst was that he made it against his own Government's policies and against the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard. What Mr Perkins said and the very fact that he said it constitute in the minds of the Opposition at least-it does not seem to be the case with the Government-a totally unacceptable intrusion into party politics by one of the most senior members of the Australian Public Service. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, in fact defended Mr Perkins's right to make political statements even though he did not necessarily endorse the content. But that defence by the Minister, if applied generally, would undermine fundamentally the apolitical nature of the Australian Public Service. Are we to assume that Mr Perkins, or anyone in his position, occupies some special position of privilege? The Prime Minister Mr Hawke, and the Government--
—Do not forget Mr Boucher as head of the Taxation Office.

—Yes, the examples are legion. I am using the Perkins example as perhaps one of the more recent and spectacular. The Prime Minister and the Government must not dodge this issue. The Prime Minister must tell the Australian public what is the standard of conduct expected from permanent heads of Commonwealth departments. The permanent heads and other senior public officials must live up to that standard. The slippage that has occurred in recent years will have a long term legacy for the future of this country. I will quote from a recent speech by a former very senior and very respected, I think by all parties, public servant in the form of Mr Peter Henderson, who retired a couple of years ago as the Secretary of the Department of Foreign Affairs. He made the point in a recent speech-and it is the point I pick the Minister up on in terms of `we did it'-that there is a fundamental difference. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is not so much the limited number of jobs for the politically acceptable boys and girls that should worry the community at large: that has always been with us in varying degrees.
Mr Henderson is right in that-

What is newer is the move towards politics in the upper reaches of the Public Service, so that when governments change, senior officials change as well. In my view that is likely to reduce the quality of objective, experienced, and informed advice available to Ministers, and to the extent that that happens, the performance of government is weakened.
Mr Henderson continues:
The disquiet at these developments has been most eloquently expressed within the past twelve months by the former Governor-General, Sir Paul Hasluck . . .

He is surely a man of impeccable reputation to people of all political persuasions throughout Australia. Mr Henderson quotes from an article written by Sir Paul Hasluck entitled `Politics in the Public Service: the New Corruption' which appeared in a recent edition of Quadrant. I will quote to the Senate two short passages from that article:

If political favour becomes a factor in advancement or appointment to the top positions (in the Public Service) the thoughts of all up-and-coming public servants will turn to the question: whom am I trying to please? Whom am I trying to serve?

The only sure and certain protection against authoritarian rule in Australian Government is a professional, competent, career public service, independent of the favour of Ministers and conscious of its one specialised role in the conduct of public affairs.
Those are the words of Sir Paul Hasluck.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody disagrees with that.

—I am pleased to hear that. I look forward to seeing the Minister's Government put into practice his acceptance of those views. The actions of the Hawke Government have been absolutely contrary to that during the period it has been in office. The increase in the size of government and the politicisation of the Public Service are the two backdrops that the community and the Senate need to take well into account when looking at the changes that have been proposed in the Bills before us.

SPEECH.PARA: Why have these changes been made? The obvious reason on the Prime Minister's part and the decisions that should be noted were taken three days after the election without any consultation with Cabinet, without any consultation with other than a handful of other Ministers. I understand that not even Senator Button, as the third most senior Minister in the Government and the Leader of the Government in this House, was consulted. I was very interested to see his reported reaction when he lost one of the key prizes of his own portfolio and one of the keys to the success of his portfolio, the Industries Assistance Commission. I am not necessarily saying that the IAC should not have gone to the Department of the Treasury, but I find it absolutely fascinating that the Minister, as the third most senior Labor politician in the land, lost that sweet pea without being able to say a word to pluck it back. That is an example of the type of approach that has led to the changes that have been made. Cabinet was not consulted; it was insulted. There was no liaison, as I understand it, with State governments, and despite the fact that many of the changes are going to have an effect on State governments, no indication was made of the proposed changes prior to the election; so the Australian people were not told. The net effect of all of this has been a great grab-bag of ill-conceived and loose-ended changes.

One of the Prime Minister's own Ministers was reported by Paul Kelly-and he normally knows a bit about these things-as having described the Prime Minister's efforts as akin to those of Mr Toad. He said:
He threw open the garage door, donned goggles and driving coat and then proceeded to terrorise the neighbourhood.

As with Mr Toad, the terrorising took place without any considered thought at all. The changes that have been made remind me a little of the writings of a certain gentleman in the year 210 BC, whose name was Petronius. Writing in 210 BC, he said:

We trained hard . . . but it seemed that every time we were beginning to form up into teams we would be reorganised . . . I was to learn later in life that we tend to meet any new situation by reorganizing; and a wonderful method it can be for creating the illusion of progress while producing confusion, inefficiency and demoralization.

That is precisely what these changes have produced. I do not normally place a great deal of weight on what journalists for the Australian Financial Review write, but there was a very interesting and excellent article in that paper last week by Jane Ford in which she detailed the great loss of morale, the chaos and the discord that have been created by the reorganisation of the bureaucracy and the way in which it was done. She pointed out that virtually no productive work has come out of most departments since the election and that it is very widely predicted within Government departments that very little of substance will appear for 12 months at best and two years at worst.

The disturbing effect on morale and the general disillusionment that has gone through the Public Service is a matter of very great concern indeed. If the Government believes it can get on with its programs in the way that it wishes while causing the great loss of morale in the Public Service that it has caused and the confusion that has arisen, it has another think coming to it. It is highly unlikely, in my view, that the changes that have been undertaken by the Prime Minister and the Government in the cause of so-called efficiency and effectiveness in the Public Service will in fact achieve those ends. Concerns in the Service as a whole and outside have run very wide and deep because many of the reforms have not been thought through; there are many loose ends still to be sorted out. Also, as I understand it, the efficiency unit headed by Mr Block has been disbanded. Mr Block continues as a consultant to the Prime Minister but the work that was set in train by him, which formed an important part of the restructuring, left many loose ends and the unit he was heading is not there to pick them up.

I wish to look at a few of the problems that I and the Opposition see with the restructuring. The key one is that there is a great deal of scope for confusion and avoidance of responsibility within departments and particularly between Ministers and their departments. For example, the Prime Minister, in his statement announcing the new ministerial arrangements on 11 August, said:
The ultimate responsibility for the portfolio . . . will rest with the portfolio minister--
That is, the so-called super-Minister. He also said that the purpose of the reorganisation was:

. . . to enable portfolio ministers to be released . . . from the detailed administrative work so that they could focus on the strategic direction of the portfolio and its contribution to Government priorities.

If the ultimate responsibility rests with the portfolio Minister and if he will be accountable, as the Prime Minister says he will, to Parliament for the overall operation of the portfolio, how can he be released from the detailed day to day work? More importantly, or at least as importantly, where does that leave the junior Minister? If the super-Minister is ultimately responsible, what real role-what responsibility, what accountability and what authority-does the junior Minister have? The scope for conflict and confusion between super-Ministers and junior Ministers is absolutely enormous. Looking at some of the groupings, the mind boggles as to how this system is going to work. I wonder how Senator Gareth Evans feels he will get along over the year ahead with Mr Peter Duncan, for example. They are members of totally opposing factions and they hold totally different views on an enormous range of issues. That is just one of many examples.

What will be the relationship between the junior Minister and the portfolio Secretary, the senior public servant for the expanded ministry? That is not clear. The Prime Minister's statement mentions a working relationship between the super-Minister and the portfolio Secretary. It also mentions a working relationship between the so-called Associate Secretary and the junior Minister, but it says nothing at all about the relationship between the Associate Secretary and the senior Minister or the relationship between the real Secretary and the junior Minister. The whole thing is a dog's breakfast of potential confusion and lack of responsibility. There is an enormous scope for getting things wrong and, more importantly, for passing the buck.

There is a great imbalance between the work loads of the various ministries. Some of the groupings also look very odd. Why on earth would one put local government into a grouping with immigration and ethnic affairs? As Senator Chaney mentioned earlier, the grouping of the arts, sport, the environment, tourism and territories-Mr John Brown's super-ministry-comprises several totally unrelated areas. Similar points could be made about other groupings.

The number of departments, it has been said, has been reduced from 28 to 18. But where will the actual savings occur? What overlap and duplication will in fact be eliminated? The comment is made in the Prime Minister's statement that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs is to be abolished and replaced by a commission. When will that happen? What are the legal provisions relating to that measure? What is its constitutionality as far as the Minister is concerned? Are there problems in this regard? Still further legislation will be necessary to effect the full breakup of the Public Service Board. We do not know what that legislation is; we do not know when it is coming in; we do not know what its implications and effect will be.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is unusual about that, for goodness sake?

—What is unusual about it is that we have a government that has brought things in in a piecemeal manner leaving an enormous number of loose ends to be followed up, but the Government expects the Parliament to agree to all of these things without any serious consideration. It is for that reason that we on this side of the chamber have moved the amendment to refer these matters to an appropriate committee-the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations or whatever may replace it in any changed committee arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very important that the Parliament have a chance to look at these matters because it is crystal clear-clear beyond any doubt at all-that these arrangements have not been thought through. They are in many respects ill-conceived. I am not in any way suggesting that there is no desirability in a restructuring but, for heaven's sake, if we are going to restructure the Public Service-a measure which will have long term effects not just on this Government but on successive governments and therefore on the conduct of public life and public service in this country-we owe it to ourselves and to the future to make sure that we get it right. I believe there are considerable doubts as to whether that is the case on this occasion. At the very least we owe ourselves the responsibility of making sure that we have a much closer look at the matter than we have had the opportunity to do to date. I conclude by supporting Senator Chaney's amendment on behalf of the Opposition in relation to the administrative arrangements and I reiterate that we will oppose the expansion of the Ministry, which is proposed for quite unnecessary and illogical reasons.
