TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate. I indicate at the outset that the Government will not support the amendment which has been moved by Senator Chaney on behalf of the Opposition. While Opposition senators were speaking I was reminded of these lines from Tennyson's poem Ulysses:

SPEECH.PARA: Yet all experience is an arch wherethro'
gleams that untravell'd world, whose margin fades.
For ever and for ever when I move.

The Opposition has had some nasty experiences in the last few months, and I understand that. But the objection seems to be on the one hand that the Government has moved quickly on this issue while another speaker has put the view that the Government has moved slowly on the issue. Honourable senators opposite cannot even make up their minds about that question.

Senator Chaney started off by saying, `Look, we thought of this in 1984 and we had a rethink in 1987'. It is all very well to think about these things. Government Ministers have been thinking about these things for some time too. When the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that there was no agenda of the Government in relation to these matters, that was absolutely correct. It was not duplicity. Individual Government Ministers have thought about these things and, of course, have discussed them for a very long time as it is quite natural for Government Ministers to do. One is not debarred from thinking on the basis that one is a member of this Parliament. Of course, Government Ministers are not debarred from thinking any more than the Opposition appears to be. So, if I may say so, the sort of churlish approach to this legislation adopted by some Opposition senators in the course of their contributions is really disappointing.

Senator Chaney gave a revisited version of his Bonnie Prince Charlie speech, of the government in exile. He went on to chastise the Australian Labor Party for doing some of these things, as he says, for factional reasons. Goodness me, what would Neil Brown say about all that? What would Senator Chaney say? Only a month or so ago he was touted widely as the only suitable person to be the Leader of the Liberal Party of Australia. He modestly on television awaited the call, which he did not get. These things happen in political parties, and I do not retreat from that for one moment. I think the honourable senator should recognise that, having been here for some time.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not prepared to touch on the issue of a bit of honest debate?

—It is all very well for Senator Chaney to come in here and spout motherhood cliches about honest debate, to occupy the position of the moral minority in Australian politics, which he does, and make a virtue of all that and say that other people retreat from honest debate but that only the Liberal Party here is capable of honest debate. I thought that Senator Powell made some telling comments about that. Political parties change their views from time to time. Is that dishonest? I do not know whether it is dishonest or not. I would not have thought so. I do not make these high sounding moral judgments in the political arena as the honourable senator did in his speech. We do not retreat from honest debate. It is just that in this particular period of political history we do not have much to debate with, and that is a tragic thing for the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of issues were raised by various senators. I found the discursive discussions by Senator Tate and Senator Durack interesting. I was intrigued to find that Senator Short had heard of Petronius and was prepared to quote him. I did not find that contribution or, indeed, the contributions from Sir Paul Hasluck as being particularly relevant. Nobody disagrees with that. Senator Short's speech was full of allegations about politicisation of the Public Service, vast growth in Public Service numbers, and things like that. All are totally unsubstantiated allegations. It is true that in the first two years of this Government, the size of the Public Service increased significantly. That has not been so in the last two years. In fact, I refer the honourable senator to the Prime Minister's statement of September last year on streamlining of the Public Service and the number of initiatives that have been taken by the Government to reduce Public Service size in the past year or so. There is no point in coming here in 1987 and attacking the Whitlam Government. I thought that honourable senators opposite would have got over that in the last period of opposition. I do not see much point in that.

I thought the punch line of Senator Short's speech was his comment that the `mind boggles'. I would have thought that that was not an entirely new experience for him. I thought his mind was boggled before he started. I think to come in here and say that his mind boggles at what the Government has done in terms of streamlining departments, reducing the number of departments, streamlining administration and so on is slightly overstated and absurd. The honourable senator then indulged in a little fantasy about overlap and duplication and whether particular Ministers would get on well together, and things like that. It is in his political interest that they do not. He ought to realise that. We are quite happy that they will. However, if his Party has to face three more years in opposition, one of the best things that could happen to him would be for Ministers not to get on well together. We are prepared to take the risk of that and he ought to be as well because it may give his Party an opportunity that it has not exercised in the last three years.

Senator Short says, `We want to make sure that we get it right'. So the Opposition wants to have a go at it in a Senate committee to make sure `we get it right'. What does the Opposition really want? Does it want us to get it right or does it want the confusion that the honourable senator predicted in the course of his speech will take place? The Opposition has to make up its mind what its sordid political priorities are in respect of that particular issue. One could go on debating these issues but I am not sure that there is any point in doing so because, in a decent debate, one has to be able to get one's teeth into something. There is nothing in the speeches from Opposition senators in connection with the two pieces of legislation before the Senate.

I want to refer briefly to some serious contributions that were made to the debate. First of all, I have had the opportunity of discussing with Senator Powell of the Australian Democrats the amendment which they will move in the Committee stage of the legislation. While the Government will not support the amendment, we fully support the spirit of it and I will give some undertakings in relation to that in the committee stage.

Senator Harradine raised an issue which he has raised on a number of other occasions. First of all, let me mention the question of bioethical issues which are the responsibility of Senator Ryan as Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health. A number of bioethical issues arise in the health portfolio in terms of administration. In relation to those issues, Senator Ryan will have the responsibilities which have been reposed in her. However, the human rights legislation, for example, will still be within the purview of the Attorney-General. Nothing which this Government does in a legislative way will be affected by that allocation because these matters are ultimately dealt with by Cabinet before legislation is brought forward.

Senator Harradine's important point was in relation to the question of youth. I am not trying to denigrate the point I have just referred to in saying that. However, the point that Senator Harradine gave most attention to was the question of youth employment in the Australian Public Service. Senator Harradine will be aware of the Budget Speech made last night by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in which the question of youth unemployment was again addressed. The Government is increasing funding for traineeships from $14m to $45m in this Budget, providing for an extra 13,000 new trainees. At the same time, there will be a new program at a cost of $31m to provide short term vocational training opportunities for unemployed young people. I could refer to a number of other matters in the Budget Speech which relate to this issue.

Senator Harradine, in the course of his remarks, drew attention to the fact that in 1966 junior employees constituted 22.2 per cent of the Public Service and that by 1985 the number had declined to 5.5 per cent. I am advised that 1966 was a peak year-an artificially high year in terms of the recruitment of junior employees. I just want to draw attention to one or two factors which influence representation of youth as permanent officers of the Australian Public Service. First of all, there have been changes in education patterns which have seen an increased proportion of youth completing final year high school. This has resulted in an increase in the average age of young people applying for appointment to the Public Service.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. I ask him whether he adheres to the view he expressed in a speech on 7 August when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: I fear however that though we have been going in the right direction, we have not been moving as quickly as the externally imposed circumstances demand.

Given that the Budget, which has been described by Ross Gittins as the `she'll be right' or `do nothing' Budget, in fact does not change the economic settings which applied on 7 August, why did the Government bring down a Budget which will not significantly contribute to the more rapid movement sought by the Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the time that speech was written, which was about a week before it was delivered, and indeed at the time it was delivered, the best expectation, given no significant policy changes on the outlay or revenue sides other than those which were referred to in the election policy speech, was that the Budget deficit would be about $1 billion. That expected outcome changed very substantially, principally for two reasons: first, it became apparent that the tax base broadening measures which the Government legislated for in the previous couple of years were yielding a great deal more revenue than had been anticipated at the time-an increase in revenue of the order of $1 billion.

ANSWER.PARA: Also, largely as a function of the Budget being presented one month later than usual, we had two full months pay as you earn taxation receipts, which confirmed what some people might have earlier suspected, that is, that the PAYE tax base was larger than had been previously assumed. In other words, for reasons which could not have been foreseen with any degree of certainty at the end of July or even in the first week of August but which became much more certain, the Budget deficit, other things remaining equal, was about $1 billion less than was previously anticipated. That is a pretty significant movement. I am not particularly hung up on deficit fetishes, but a movement of that size is certainly significant.

On a more general plane, I do not think anybody is pretending that all of the country's problems are solved. The Treasurer's comment, repeated I think many times yesterday, that the country has turned a corner is, I believe, to any rational person beyond dispute. One could also add that we are making progress in the right direction at a significant rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister tell the Senate the date that the Government learned of this extra $1 billion? Can he also tell the Senate whether he believes that $1 billion of extra tax revenue constitutes a change of settings which is going to significantly accelerate the process of adjustment which is required?

—In reply to the first part, I could tell Senator Chaney, but I will not. If he wants to know the answers to questions like that he had better start winning elections instead of losing them. I am not sure what he was getting at in the second part, but it seems to me that he is endorsing the notion that there is only one road to fiscal responsibility. There are, of course, two roads to fiscal responsibility, and most sensible people would use both to some extent.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: RURAL AND PROVINCIAL ELECTORATES: SWING TO THE GOVERNMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, refers to the recent election results. Is the Minister aware that in a great many rural and provincial electorates throughout Australia there were swings to the Government at the July election? What economic factors and policies has the Government noted as being of particular importance to rural and provincial Australia to which these swings can be attributed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Maguire's question suggests, there were in fact significant swings to the Government in a number of rural seats, in particular in the 22 seats targeted by the National Farmers Federation (NFF) as the seats in which it could destroy the Government. Indeed, in those 22 seats the Australian Labor Party (ALP) held all of the 11 seats it previously held and won three others from the Liberal Party or the National Party of Australia, and included a positive swing in all of those 22 seats targeted by the NFF. The overall two-party preferred vote swung to the ALP in the National Farmers Federation's 22 targeted seats by an average of 0.17 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us face it: although the NFF tried to put a thin veneer of disguise over this, the objective of the leadership of the Federation was to get rid of the Labor Government. According to its account, it collected more than $10m for a political fighting fund. I am not sure how much of that it spent during the election campaign or, for that matter, how much it did in fact collect, but its purpose was to get rid of the Labor Government by concentrating on 22 marginal seats. As it turned out, the Government got a significant swing to it on average in those seats and in all but one of the seats which were already held.

The conclusion that has to be drawn from that is that the people in the country are not fools, as the cabal of right wing ratbags which has hijacked the National Farmers Federation obviously assumed they were. In particular, those who follow these things will remember the very high profile campaign which the cabal that runs or has hijacked the NFF ran against the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax and which had negligible impact on the agricultural sector. It was not a question of pursuing issues which were of any particular concern or which had much relevance to the economic welfare of the agricultural sector. That agenda was set not with the interests of farmers in mind, but with the political interests in mind of the cabal of right wing ratbags who hijacked the organisation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer and refer him to the following statement appearing at page 11 of the Budget Speech:

QUESTION.PARA: Now that we have eliminated the budget deficit we will be repaying $1,000 million of Commonwealth overseas debt this year and the same amount of domestic bonds.

I ask the Minister: First, does he agree that, since our external balance of payments is in deficit, any such repayment of overseas debt by the Commonwealth Government simply means, as a matter of inexorable arithmetic, that an equal and offsetting amount of $1,000m will have to be borrowed from overseas by some other Australian resident? Secondly, does the Minister agree that, since the Budget is not in surplus, even on the basis of the creative accounting employed by the Treasurer in arriving at the figure for the deficit, the repayment of $1,000m, or any other figure, of Commonwealth domestic bonds in 1987-88 can be effected only by either drawing upon the Commonwealth's cash balances with the Reserve Bank of Australia, which is equivalent to printing money, or issuing other forms of Commonwealth securities, such as treasury notes, to the same $1,000m extent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to the first part of the question-I think Senator Stone himself put in this qualification-other things being equal, the repayment of $1 billion of government debt held overseas would require an offsetting borrowing by someone else. I think that is a tautology, other things being equal. However, other things are not equal. This has some relevance to the question which Senator Stone asked me yesterday and which I have now had a chance to read thoroughly. One of the things which are not equal is that the $1 billion of asset sales which the Commonwealth proposes for this financial year reduces the public sector borrowing requirement which would otherwise have applied and also, in accordance with the internationally accepted accounting conventions, takes $1 billion off outlays. If those assets were sold on the Australian capital market-again this is a tautology, other things being equal-it would require that there be private borrowings $1 billion higher than they otherwise would be.

ANSWER.PARA: But for this year other things are not equal. A major component-I shall not specify the figure the Government expects, but a very large component-of the $1 billion of asset sales will accrue from the sale of the surplus land at the Australian Embassy in Tokyo. That will be sold on the Japanese capital market, not the Australian market.

TALK.START.PARA: —And taxed?

—No, we do not believe that it will be. That very large figure has to be deducted from the $1 billion Senator Stone had in mind. In regard to the retirement of domestic bonds, what Senator Stone said is correct, or at least to the extent I could get down the points he made; but if he looks at the Budget Papers in total-I cannot give a precise reference-he will find a specific reference to the bonds which are being retired being replaced substantially, if not entirely, by an issue of treasury notes.

—If I may ask the Minister a supplementary question without canvassing that part of his reply which appeared to constitute a response to my question yesterday and without making a statement on the matter, I would simply point out that the decision to repay the $1,000m of Commonwealth debt overseas will mean, and must mean-I am sure the Minister would agree--
—What is the question?
—Order! I am listening to ascertain whether there is a question. So far there has not been.

—In these circumstances will the Minister agree that the appropriate answers to these two questions were yes and yes respectively? If so, will he indicate what was meant to be the purpose of this empty boast on page 11 of the Budget Speech?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The `empty boast' reference is a particular interpretation. I would regard it just as a statement of fact. There is no empty boast. In regard to the two questions which Senator Stone asked yesterday and which he has raised again, I have already answered the second one. If the money were to be raised on the domestic capital market, an equivalent amount would have to be raised; but in this case other things are not equal, as I said, and the greater part of those borrowings will take place on the Japanese capital market, not the Australian market.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to Senator Stone's first question yesterday is that arithmetically the answer is yes-that is, that, if Government assets are sold within the same capital market and other things remain equal, Government borrowings would be reduced and private borrowings would be increased, unless money were taken from the consumption stream to finance the purchases on the private market. Even if that did not happen-and it is possible, indeed likely, that it would happen to some extent-even if the arithmetic worked out that way, there seems to be a perception in the capital market that there is a difference between governments borrowing for a certain purpose, for example to re-equip an airline, and private businesses borrowing in the same market for exactly the same purpose. In other words, even if the arithmetic were beyond question-there are a couple of doubts about that to which I have already referred-the market does not seem to agree that it is exactly the same thing. Senator Stone used to talk a lot at one time about rational expectations. It would appear that there are also some irrational expectations around, animal spirits and all that.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HIGHER EDUCATION INSTITUTIONS: LINKS WITH INDUSTRY

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce seen a letter by Senator Macklin to the Editor of the Australian newspaper of today in which he criticises the views apparently expressed by the Minister on the inadequacy of research and teaching links between higher education institutions and industry? Will the Minister say whether Senator Macklin has correctly interpreted his views, and clarify his position on the issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was about to say that I was surprised, but indeed I am not surprised that Senator Macklin should write such a letter-probably not on the basis of having read the speech I made, but on the basis of Press reports about which some other commentators, including a very distinguished educationist in Professor Karmel, have also seen fit to comment. I saw the letter. The speech identified three things which the tertiary education system should be doing and which I personally and other Ministers in this Government regard as very important. First, it should be producing graduates with breadth and depth of skills in various disciplines. Secondly, it should be engaging in basic and applied research, leading to new and improved products and services and technical skills. Thirdly, the tertiary education sector should offer expertise to industry.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Macklin's letter suggests that the Government took a totally utilitarian view of research. I regret to say that he tends to bind to the perennial argument as to the relative merits of basic and applied research. I did not seek to bind to that argument. I think there should be a balance between basic and applied research in tertiary institutions. I want to make the point that I went out of my way, in the speech to the seminar in question, to endorse the report by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, Universities under Scrutiny, when I said that careerism, pre-professionalism and occupational programs have put general and liberal education on the run. I continued:
This is a totally undesirable situation. Creativity and innovation are unlikely to be nurtured in an environment where only occupational and functional knowledge and skills are valued.

However, I also make the point that high quality researchers are likely to become involved in both pure and applied research. There are some very distinguished Australian researchers who fall into that category-for example, Professor Graeme Clark, the inventor of the bionic ear and recipient of the Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd Australian of the Year award in 1985. It is important to clarify these issues because it is a very important debate about the future of our university sector in particular. I regret that Senator Macklin has embarked on the debate without reading, it appears, what he purported to criticise and to comment upon.

Having said that, I think we have a long way to go in Australia in terms of achieving those objectives-for example, achieving the objectives of closer relationships between universities and industry, achieving the objectives where university and tertiary education expertise is offered to industry and achieving a balance between the basic and applied research funding in particular faculties. We have a long way to go in these matters and I do not think that anybody or any institution should be immune from criticism or comment about those matters just as I think that no politician-neither Senator Macklin nor myself-should be immune from comment or criticism about our views. I have seen the letter. I think it arises from a misinterpretation of what I in fact said, and I take the opportunity to correct that misinterpretation here.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer the Minister to the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission's recent report Efficiency and Effectiveness in Higher Education which, on page 85, describes mature age students as `one of the success stories of higher education' because, amongst other things, it has given greater opportunities for higher education to `disadvantaged groups such as women and those of low socio-economic status'. In view of this, what will be the impact on mature age students of the Government's decision in this Budget to approve an additional intake into higher education in 1988 of 5,800 school leavers but to provide additional funding for only 3,500 to 4,000 of these places? Does this mean a reduction in the enrolment of new mature age students of some 2,500, thus putting an end to the `success story' referred to by CTEC?

—I am sure that whatever the outcomes of the new decisions, they will not mean an end to the success story of mature age entrants. I will seek from Mr Dawkins a more specific response on the expectations of mature age enrolments for the next academic year. However, I point out to Senator Macklin that as we are constantly improving the participation rates of secondary students through to the end of Year 12 and as, for example, girls have, and have had for some time, a higher participation rate to the end of Year 12, the proportion of persons in the community needing to seek mature age entry is constantly being reduced. We now have a much different pattern of people, say those in their early twenties, and we are developing different patterns every year in terms of greater participation by disadvantaged groups. The great bulge of mature age students which we saw in the late 1970s and 1980s is no longer there. However, it is important to the Government's ongoing equity and economic objectives that mature age people have the opportunity for higher education and training. I am confident that they will continue to have such opportunities under the new arrangements and within the new range of places that have been described. However, I will seek further specific information about the division of new places for next year among the different age groups.

—Can the Special Minister of State comment on allegations that a secret report of the Business Regulation Review Unit (BRRU) establishes that there will be a very high cost ratio for the private sector in the Australia Card program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been participation by the Business Regulation Review Unit in developing the costings of the Australia Card system. For example, the Unit was represented on the working party which considered the cost to the private sector of compliance with Australia Card uses. It helped determine the request for details, the organisations contacted and the follow-up and assessment of responses. The Unit was equally disappointed-as were other government agencies-at the paucity of the responses. I think that is an important point. We went out seeking and inviting submissions from the business sector about the cost implications to it and we did not get a very great response. However, we have been able to make some estimates of those partly because of the original assessments made by the BRRU.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition to its role in the working party, the Unit also provided comments on reports to Cabinet on the assessment of private sector costs in the Australia Card cost benefit analysis. I must stress that these comments are not secret reports and do not provide alternative cost assessments. Both convention and law protect Cabinet documents from being made public and the Opposition, we expect, would wish to retain that protection if ever it got back into office. However, all documents relating to the assessment of private sector costs which can be made public have already been made available to Mr James Porter, MP, under a freedom of information request. Suggestions that the BRRU, had extrapolated a general theory of a ratio of two to one government to business paper burden cost to the Australia Card program are nonsense. In fact, Dr Moran, Director of the BRRU, stated that no such relationship was found in the Australia Card program. I take this opportunity to table a copy of a letter from Dr Moran to this effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Home Affairs, as the Minister responsible for information co-ordination. Is the Minister aware of a report in the Melbourne Herald on 24 August that the Government has agreed in principle to implement a national advertising campaign to `improve public awareness of its proposed Australia Card'? Can the Minister confirm these reports? Can he say whether the campaign will proceed and if so, when? What is the estimated cost of the campaign and where are the funds for it to be found in the Budget Estimates?

—Some consideration has been given to a government advertising campaign in relation to the Australia Card. No final decisions have yet been made. Further meetings will be held before a final decision is made. It is generally conceded that when there is a large item before the Government, some information program is entered into to have that explained. Because we have not yet made a final decision, I cannot anticipate any costs of such a potential campaign.

—I ask a supplementary question. What justification does the Government propose to give to the Australian people for such a blatant misuse of taxpayers' funds on a party political propaganda campaign?

—I am sure that when Senator Short was the member for Ballarat between 1975 and 1980 he constantly raised in his own party room government advertising expenditure to support government programs. He is just being consistent here today in raising these particular matters. It has been the policy of all governments in recent years, be they Liberal or Labor, to use various information programs in which to sell various things to the public. It would be ridiculous ever to suggest that one should adopt certain proposals and then never have them explained.

—I address my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications who represents the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It refers to the current situation in the Republic of Belau, sometimes referred to as Palau, in the western Caroline Islands, part of the United Nations Trust Territory of Micronesia administered by the United States since 1947 and lying about 2,500 kilometres north of Darwin.
—Thanks for the geography lesson.

—That is the end of the geography lesson. Why has there been no apparent response from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to the considerable public concern shown about the escalating level of violence in Belau in the past few weeks-in particular the murder of Mr Bings Bedor, father of two prominent supporters of the nuclear free constitution which Belauans have voted for since 1979, and intimidation of the judiciary which forced the Chief Justice of Belau to resign on 25 August because of threats to his family? Has the Australian Government made any representation to the United States Government asking it to respect the wishes of the people of Belau who have voted for their nuclear free constitution nine times in eight years? Finally, is the Government prepared to ask the United Nations Security Council to support the request of High Chief Yutaka Gibbons for a peacekeeping mission to be sent to Belau?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vallentine's questions always seem to vary in inverse proportion to the size of the country or the territory with which she is dealing. There was a plebiscite in Palau on 21 August, observed by a visiting United Nations mission, which approved acceptance of the compact of free association with the United States by a vote of 73 per cent. Under that compact Palau will be self-governing in free association with the United States, which retains responsibility for defence and security matters. Earlier plebiscites failed to attain the then required 75 per cent majority. A referendum on 4 August amended the Constitution to enable the compact to be approved by a simple rather than that previous 75 per cent majority.

ANSWER.PARA: The 4 August amendment does not remove the non-nuclear provisions of the Palau Constitution. The three-quarters majority is still required to approve the use, testing, storage or disposal of harmful substances, including nuclear weapons and waste. Under the compact the United States may not use, test or dispose of such harmful substances, and has the right to operate nuclear-capable or nuclear-propelled vessels and aircraft, under the `neither confirm nor deny' doctrine.

The Australian Government considers that the compact has been negotiated and approved in a manner consistent with the rights of the Palau people to self-determination, believing that the decision now taken on the compact was a matter solely for the Government and people of Palau. Accordingly, this Government has not made any representations to the United States Government about Palau. As to the spate of violence in that country recently, we, of course, regret those acts. However, we do not consider it appropriate for a UN-sponsored peacekeeping force to visit the country. It is a matter for the appropriate Palau authorities to maintain the necessary law and order. I just add, finally, that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade have responded in these terms to expressions of concern about Palau which have been addressed to the Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to the Budget Speech by the Treasurer last evening when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: We are also developing services such as tourism into major earners of foreign exchange.

Can the Minister confirm that this year's Budget includes a provision of only some $300,000 for improvements and, I believe, for maintenance of workshops and store facilities, at the Darwin Airport? Does the Minister agree that this makes a mockery of the Australian Labor Party's charade of support for tourism in that our major international northern airport remains nothing but a tin shed? Can the Minister confirm whether there are any current arrangements with private people for the development of an appropriate and proper airport at Darwin?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an obvious need for an upgrading of the Darwin Airport terminal facilities and I have no doubt that, with the arrival in the Parliament in particular of Senator Collins for the Northern Territory, we will be hearing a good deal more on this subject in the near future. Of course, the big questions are what kind of a terminal facility it will be and who will pay for it, and subsidiary questions as to where it will be put and so on seem to have exercised a lot of enthusiastic concern in recent times. I have been holding off addressing this question until the future of the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) became clear-as it now has in the light of the Budget decision about airport terminals and the announcements that have been made about the start-up date for the Corporation in consequence of that.

ANSWER.PARA: Darwin is one of the airports that are not yet incorporated in the FAC but which it is intended will be in the future. It is, accordingly, a question of major capital investment, which I think can probably be best addressed in the context of the establishment of the new FAC early next year. I have already had a preliminary discussion with Mr Fred Finch, the Northern Territory Minister for Transport and Works, on this subject a few weeks ago. We are in the process of making further arrangements to talk with him, and I can assure the honourable senator that the airport's needs are acknowledged. It is just a question of how they will be paid for, by whom and when and where the facility is to be located. They are all questions on my agenda and they will be addressed sensibly in due course.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer whether he heard former Treasurer Howard commenting on the Budget and the state of the Australian economy on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation program AM this morning. Can the Minister say whether this is the same John Howard who had major arithmetic problems with his calculations prior to the 11 July election? Can the Minister also say whether Mr Howard's comments on AM this morning contained similar arithmetic inaccuracies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was an arithmetic inaccuracy in Mr Howard's comment this morning but I think it would be going too far to describe it as an inaccuracy similar to the spectacular incompetence displayed by the Opposition when it cut out and pasted together its taxation policy during the election campaign. I do not think we can anticipate in our lifetime to see again such a dramatic and spectacular demonstration of incompetence from any political party or any political party leader as we were fortunate enough to witness back in the middle of July. Specifically, on the wireless this morning, Mr Howard said:

ANSWER.PARA: Business investment is worse now than it was and it has been at any time over the last 25 years. I mean, business investment as a percentage of GDP in this country now is lower than it has been at any time, I think, going right back to the Whitlam period and beyond. So we really are at very low levels.

I table a copy of the table that shows business investment. In fact, business investment as a percentage of gross domestic product in 1986-87, the year to which Mr Howard was referring, was 10.5 per cent, which was a higher percentage than in all but three of the 14 years since 1971-72. Of course, the Government would like to see a higher level of business investment spending and expects to see a significantly higher level this year.

There is one other relevant point that should be made about this. The figures for total business equipment investment show a fall in both 1985-86 and 1986-87 relative to the immediately preceding year. However, that aggregate figure masks a very substantial change in the composition of business investment; in particular, the very marked decline in the purchase of motor vehicles by business during that period. When the changes in motor vehicle purchases are quarantined from the rest of business equipment investment we find that business investment-all these figures are in real terms-increased by 7 per cent in 1986-87. On the quality of investment, for example, the $650m which is being sunk into the new Brisbane Airport as a sop to the demon from the north by John Howard and Malcolm Fraser, in their declining years in government, and for which there is no functional need, is very poor quality investment. The increase in business investment expected this year is expected to be concentrated in the internationally traded sector of the economy; in other words, in the area where we need it most. One would expect also a low level of motor vehicle purchases by business.

The final point that ought to be made about the decline in motor vehicle purchases by business, which is almost certainly associated with the introduction of the fringe benefits tax, is that a level of motor vehicle purchases was being sustained by a tax shelter. In other words, motor vehicles for which there was no functional need were being purchased in large volumes by business. To put the point another way, until the introduction of the tax reform measures which this Government has legislated in the last couple of years, a significant amount of what was in fact consumption expenditure was being misdefined as business investment. TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for lunch I was replying to some matters raised by honourable senators in the debate. Particularly I was replying to some points made by Senator Harradine about youth employment in the Australian Public Service. Senator Harradine made the point that juniors constituted 22.2 per cent of the permanent officers in the Service in 1966 and that that had reduced progressively to 5.5 per cent in 1985. There are a number of factors which have influenced that decline and I will refer briefly to them. Firstly, I refer to the changes in education patterns which have seen an increased proportion of youth completing final year high school, resulting in an increase in the average age of young people applying for and gaining appointment.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, there are changes in the proportion of young people electing to complete tertiary education before entering the work force and generally more intense competition for positions resulting from changes in the labour market generally. Much of this has to do, of course, with increased retention rates. Thirdly, there are changes in legislative provisions for appointments, most notably the abolition of discriminatory practices such as the marriage bar and age limits. I take that to mean that there has been a greater accessibility for older people, married women and so on, to the Public Service work force. Finally, there is the question of reductions in overall appointment rates for the Australian Public Service due to constraints on the growth of the service and to a decline in overall separation rates.

Those matters are offered as some explanation of what has happened between 1986 and 1987 in terms of the participation rate of young people in permanent work in the Public Service. Having said that, Senator Harradine really directed a question when he said that Mr Willis and others were concerned about it but what were they doing about it. I referred Senator Harradine earlier to the Budget statement of last night and to a number of measures in it which were directed to the general question of youth unemployment. I add to that in respect of the Public Service that it is expected that the number of young people entering the Australian Public Service will increase through the Government's Australian traineeship system. Under the system some 770 officer trainees were taken in on two intakes during 1986 in a range of departments and authorities in all States and Territories. Seven hundred and eighty-eight office trainees have so far been taken in on three intakes this year with about 67 still to be taken on in New South Wales and Victoria as part of the third intake. A large number of the 1986 trainees will be appointed to the Australian Public Service on completion of their traineeships this year. Traineeships in other employment areas in the Public Service are also being examined.

The Government recently announced that from 1988, whenever occupations are covered by traineeship arrangements, recruitment of 16- to 18-year-olds without year 12 into the Australian Public Service will be undertaken only via the traineeship system. I have just referred to the figures involved. These arrangements could create some 1,500 traineeships in 1988-a significant increase in the number of traineeships offered this year. This, I believe, demonstrates a Government commitment to start redressing the long term decline in the share of young people in Commonwealth employment. The new Public Service Commission, which is the subject of debate in this chamber at present, will also be addressing the problem of low youth application rates and low acceptance rates by youth. It is considering better targeted recruitment campaigns, the timing of selection tests to maximise the number of youth applicants, et cetera. That relates to the school year. The Australian Public Service Joint Council has established a sub-committee to examine youth employment in the Australian Public Service and the terms of reference of the sub-committee are geared towards examining policy alternatives aimed at increasing the employment of young people in the Australian Public Service. Senator Harradine will, of course, appreciate that those things are designed to reverse the trend of recent years. They will take a little time to take effect, but the Government believes that they will be significant in addressing some of the problems to which the honourable senator referred.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think some of my moaning had something to do with it?

—Well, I am quite prepared to allocate largess where it is due and certainly the honourable senator has been very persistent about this issue. I acknowledge that. Senator Harradine also asked some questions about bioethics and the allocation of bioethics matters to Senator Ryan as Minister Assisting the Minister for Health and Community Services. I am advised that the Australian Health Ministers Conference-comprising Commonwealth and State Ministers-has agreed to set up a national bioethics consultative body covering the broad scope of bioethical issues. Senator Ryan, as the Commonwealth Minister, is to take the lead in that group in the further development of this policy and in the establishment of proposed advisory structures in the area of bioethics. The Attorney-General, however, retains the responsibility for human rights issues generally and, subject to Cabinet, would be responsible for any human rights legislation which, in my interpretation, includes the various matters to which Senator Harradine referred in his earlier comments.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short in his speech made some comments about Public Service growth which I found somewhat elusive in the sense that I do not quite know what is required from me by way of response. It is true that in the year 1982-83 there was a 5.49 per cent growth in the Australian Public Service. For most of that year, of course, the Public Service was under the administration of the former Liberal Government. In the year 1983-84, that is, the first full year of the Labor Government, there was a 4.28 per cent growth in the Australian Public Service. In the year 1984-85 there was a 2.37 per cent growth and in 1985-86 a 1.81 per cent growth. I said in my earlier comments about what Senator Short had to say that there had been a significant growth in the early years of this Government, that part of that growth was inherited from the Liberal Government and that there has been a decline in growth in the years 1984-85 and 1985-86, and of course a further decline in the current year.

I think I have addressed the main matters that I was asked to address, which I regard as points of substance made by honourable senators in the course of the debate as distinct from points of merely passing rhetorical interest. I thank those senators who have contributed points of substance and I commend the Bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 10, clause 15, proposed paragraph 22 (3) (f), line 4, leave out ``2'', insert ``3''.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is not disposed to accept the amendments moved by Senator Powell. If I might say so, as I have already indicated to Senator Powell, we fully understand the spirit in which the amendments have been moved and regard that as consistent with the views of the Government on these matters. However, there are a number of reasons which I wish to advance as to why the Government is not keen to accept the amendments. Senator Powell will be well aware that clause 15-proposed new section 22 (1)-of the Administrative Arrangements Bill 1987 provides for the Board in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) There is hereby established a body to be known as the Australian Public Service Management Advisory Board.
(2) The functions of the Board are:
(a) to advise the Commonwealth Government on significant issues relating to the management of the Australian Public Service; and
(b) to be a forum for consideration of major management activities affecting the Australian Public Service as a whole.

The Government's view is that the functions of the Board are clearly related to major management issues across the breadth of the Australian Public Service. The proposed membership of the Board reflects that. It does not include specific subject matter expertise on the Board in relation to any particular matter such as equal employment opportunities. There are other forums in which specific matters of this kind can be discussed, such as the Joint Council and its standing committees on women in the Service and the equal employment opportunity minority groups. On the question of equal employment opportunity generally, the Efficiency Scrutiny Unit of Mr David Block recommended:

devolve responsibility for equal employment opportunity . . . to departments with Department Heads being required to report progress in [that area] in their annual reports to the Parliament-the Government would emphasise that these activities are to be maintained at least at their present level and the Government may wish to maintain a very small monitoring unit with the new [Public Service] Commission . . .

Subsequently, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has endorsed the maintenance of a monitoring capability in the Commission. As recommended by the Efficiency Scrutiny Unit, equal employment opportunity will be maintained at least at its present level and departments will continue to be required to report progress in their annual reports to Parliament.

There is no intention to amend the relevant section of the Public Service Act other than to replace the word `Board' with the word `Commissioner'. The Commission will have an identified Equal Employment Opportunity Unit in its structure. First the Commission will develop service-wide statistical indicators of performance and monitor performance using the continuous record of personnel. Secondly, it will assist agencies in developing agency specific indicators and including them in their programs. Thirdly, it will observe equal employment opportunity principles throughout its work of developing policy for personnel management and in the staffing and training of the Senior Executive Service. Fourthly, it will conduct high level policy development and provide advice on equal employment opportunity to Australian Public Service agencies.

Evidence of the Government's commitment to equal employment opportunity is included in the Budget Speech in the references to and the sums of money appropriated to the question of Aboriginal employment development policy. Insofar as recruitment to the Public Service is concerned, the Commission will have responsibility for overall recruitment policy, including the approval of selection and assessment procedures and equal employment opportunity monitoring. This will ensure the effectiveness of the development of, for example, the Aboriginal development policy in placing Aboriginal people in the Australian Public Service.

I said at the beginning of my remarks that the Government appreciated the spirit of the amendment but is not disposed to accept it because, again as I said at the beginning, the Board is a small body with advisory functions in respect of overall management issues and there will be within the purview of that body an equal employment opportunity unit and the existing mechanisms relating to equal employment opportunity will be maintained and enhanced. For that reason the Government is not disposed to accept the Democrats' amendment, but of course the amendment will be remembered and the Government will pursue these issues as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition first saw this amendment before the luncheon suspension today when Senator Powell indicated that she proposed to move it. I mention that because it was not possible for the Opposition, in its full party meeting, to consider the proposition which had been put forward by the Australian Democrats. I was concerned to examine it on behalf of the Opposition to see whether it was required to ensure that equal opportunity principles were maintained in Public Service employment, a principle that the Opposition certainly embraces without any reservation, and whether it appeared that the change suggested by Senator Powell was necessary to achieve that.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to thank the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) for making his officials available for a brief discussion on the matters, when I was able to obtain the information which he has now put before the Committee on the equal opportunity provisions which will be in place, under the revised arrangements, to assist the Public Service to meet its equal opportunity objectives.

The Australian Public Service Management Advisory Board, the body which would be affected by this amendment, is made up of a number of senior public servants: the Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Commissioner of the Public Service, the Secretary to the Department of Industrial Relations, and the Secretary to the Department of Finance; and then there is freedom to nominate other Secretaries at the discretion of the Prime Minister. Then there is room for two outsiders, people who are not part of that upper echelon of the Public Service, to be appointed. One is to be nominated after consultation with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and is presumably to represent trade union interest in some way; and the other is a person with management expertise from the private sector. I assume that the interest of the Government in having that sort of person flows from the same interest it had in appointing Mr David Block to advise it on the structure of the Public Service. I think that has proved to be an excellent appointment and, as the debate on the substance of the Bill illustrated, the ultimate results of his work have been to produce a pattern which is broadly in line with what the Opposition has been advocating. So we can see the force of having somebody from the private sector.

The question which I think then has to be addressed is whether there is an interest in equal opportunity in employment which is not going to be adequately looked after if there is not some additional special representative. The point which weighed heaviest with me in determining that I thought such a person was not necessary was the point that has now been made by the Minister in committee; namely, that there will be an identified equal opportunity unit within the formal structure so that there will be a continuous process of advice in that area which will take into account the concerns which have been raised by this amendment. In other words, this is an area which is being catered for within the formal administrative machinery. I think anybody who has had anything to do with the people who staff that machinery would know that they are usually people with a very strong commitment to the principles of equal opportunity. Certainly that has been my experience.

When thinking about the question outside the area of discrimination on the grounds of sex, and in looking at problems of Aboriginal employment, for example, where there are major long term problems that require the long term dedication of government to achieving improvement, it does seem to me that the sorts of mechanisms which have been set up by the Government are substantially appropriate and do not require the insertion of some representative on this advisory board with particular expertise in that field. Having to deal with this matter in the short time that I have had to consider it, and after consultation with a few of my colleagues, I indicate that the Opposition will not support the amendment.

There is absolutely no reason why the people who are appointed under proposed new section 22 (3) (f), the people nominated in writing by the Prime Minister, should not have background expertise in that and other areas. I draw that to the Government's attention. Similarly the Government has a fair amount of room to move in terms of the people it appoints as Secretaries. Obviously, given the fact that three lots of legislation have been introduced in the last three years on the question of equal opportunity, I think it would be fair to say that the Government will be bearing that in mind in making appointments to this Board.

They are the reasons why we have decided not to support an amendment of the sort which is being pursued by Senator Powell. We hope that there might be some other opportunities to look at this issue of equal employment opportunity again. It is clear that the Government has rethought some of the administrative approaches and has changed some of the administrative arrangements which were put in place. It may well be that we could have an opportunity on some other occasion to discuss the effectiveness of these new procedures after they have been in place for some time. We will not be supporting the amendment, although again, in common with the leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), I would say that we totally support the sentiment behind the amendment, namely, the maintenance of equal opportunity principles in Commonwealth employment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) for his response and the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) for his comments. It is somewhat comforting to be assured of the maintenance of an equal employment opportunity unit within the new Public Service arrangements. However, I do have some questions which I think are important in this context. I have to say, first, that I am disappointed by the rejection of the amendment to secure a position on the new Board under the provisions of this legislation for a person whose specific responsibility and expertise is in the area of equal employment opportunity-for one particular reason, that is, that all too often, while the issues of equal opportunity may be there in the body of thought and action in any organisation or group, they are all too often not there in the upper echelons. We see that on the front benches of the Government and the Opposition and in the proportion of women and of course other disadvantaged groups in decision-making positions. That alone is a reason for suggesting quite strongly that, in the case of the Public Service, the peak advisory board having a person directly designated with this responsibility and a person known for having this expertise would be a very important step in the sort of example which this morning in my speech on the second reading I suggested that I believe the Government has a responsibility to set. SPEECH.PARA: However, the question that I need to have answered, to give greater comfort both to the Democrats and to a range of other groups who are very concerned about this issue in the restructure of the Public Service, relates to the size of the unit which it is intended will be involved. We are talking of the need to continue a process which is under way but which already is far behind its proposed timetable. At the moment there are 45 departments, or a figure at about that level, which are without approved equal employment opportunity plans or which still have to set up their plans. At the moment this is all a little speculative because what is a department, who is in what department and so on is difficult to ascertain, as I discovered when working on a question without notice this morning.

We are something like half way through the established program, as I understand it. That is just in the setting up of approved plans. The monitoring process still has to go on in all departments once they have their plans set up. It is important to be assured that the unit that is set up is not simply window dressing. I do not suggest for a moment that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce is not sincere in his understanding of the issue, but we would be very concerned if the unit to be established were not of sufficient size to be able to carry out a big ongoing task and one which already is not moving at the pace we would like to see. The unit has a range of tasks and the Minister has outlined those as seen by the Government.

Furthermore, although the Minister suggested that the Management Advisory Board is made up of people who have a broad management role, he said that it did not include specific expertise. I would challenge that statement because it is specifically suggested that the two people who are to be appointed under proposed section 22 (3) (f) in writing by the Prime Minister be people of specific expertise in relation, on the one hand, to trade unions and, on the other hand, to the private sector. The argument for a third person with specific expertise in the area of equal employment opportunity, understanding and dedication to seeing that the opportunities of the disadvantaged are met in Public Service employment is as important as, and to me more important than, having someone whose background is sufficiently expert in trade union matters or in the private sector.

Senator Chaney is tilting at windmills if he thinks that either one of those two people will be a comfort to people concerned about equal opportunity, or that the prime ministerial appointments will cover our desire for someone on that Board with an interest in equal employment opportunity. For example, finally the trade unions have managed the gigantic number of three women on their executives, and one woman has advanced to a top executive position at last. This has happened despite many years of attempts at affirmative action. That does not lead us to have very much confidence that this is the area where we might find someone specially devoted to equal employment opportunity. Certainly someone could be devoted, but the trade union track record is not good enough. I do not think there are any women in the union movement, in the Australian Labor Party or on the Government side who would be prepared to say that that record is good enough. The record in the private sector is also poor and women in the private sector are still clustered in the lower paid, lower status employment areas. To date neither the private nor the public sector has been able to advance the interests of women and other disadvantaged groups significantly.

I accept the Minister's personal concern in this area. There has to be some scepticism, in our view, of undertakings in this kind of environment. For that reason I would ask the Minister to attempt to assure us at least that the unit to be set up will be adequate and will be able to carry out the big job that is ahead. I underline our disappointment that such a key position as a member of the new Board will not be given to someone whose specific interest, expertise and brief are in the area of equal employment opportunity.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

SPEECH.PARA: It is a challenge to those of us who have concerns that history should change its pathway, indeed that politics should change.
