SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate was adjourned yesterday I was making the point that the Government's motion on this occasion to continue the previous system of determining which senators are to be long term and which are to be short term following a double dissolution election, despite the 1983 amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act, was cynical and unprincipled. This obviously represents a shabby deal done with the Australian Democrats which has the effect of giving the Democrats three long term senators compared with one under the system provided by the 1983 amendments to the Act. I was also pointing out that the Democrats' agreement to this shabby deal illustrates the extent to which they have sold their souls to blatant political opportunism over the years. I referred to the statement in this chamber on 4 June this year by former Senator David Vigor, explaining his reasons for resigning from the Australian Democrats. He said that the initial honesty, openness, tolerance, fair dealing and compassion of the Democrats had been thrown out the window in recent years.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Robert Ray, who I assume will speak later in this debate, will no doubt try to tell the Senate that the reason why the Government is so outrageously compromising its integrity in this matter is that the Senate had not agreed to use the new system of determination of the length of term of senators prior to the last election and that to adopt it now, knowing its impact, would somehow be wrong. I put it to the Government that such an assertion would be arrant nonsense.

I repeat what I said several times yesterday-that the Senate had agreed to the new system by the very act of incorporating the proposal in the 1983 amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act. Indeed, in the debate on those amendments on 2 December 1983 Senator Ray made an important contribution and when this amendment was being considered, amongst other things he said:

What this is intended to do is provide a guide for this chamber, if it wishes to use it, to determine who are short term senators and who are long term senators. I would think it is a guide which, if we set it up in advance and we could all agree to it in advance, we should use.
Later in the debate he said:

But if we can agree, at least in an ethical way, that it is a fairer system to have half Senate quotas applied to a double dissolution vote to determine who is short term and who is long term then we will get to a situation where that pattern continues and this Senate does not have to use political interference.

They were the words of Senator Ray in December 1983. After he had spoken in the debate the Senate agreed to the amendment to which he was speaking. In my view this makes it quite clear that the Senate did agree to adopt this system. This is the first time since the 1983 amendments that they have been put to the test because this is the first double dissolution election since then. It will be laughable, indeed ludicrous, and certainly a disgrace if the Senate does not, of now, adopt the new system. If it does not then the question must surely be asked as to why this amendment was made to the Act in 1983 at all. There were good and valid reasons which were explained eloquently by the now responsible Minister, Senator Ray, during the debate. Indeed, Senator Ray had the task of shepherding the various amendments through the Senate on that occasion.

I will quickly refresh the minds of honourable senators as to the main reasons for the change in 1983. The reasons were four-fold. Firstly, it would remove the incentive for the government of the day-of whatever political persuasion-to do political deals with minority parties in the Senate, deals which may well not be in the best interests of the nation. Secondly, it would be more equitable. Under the old system it is possible for a minority party to have a long term senator with only 7.8 per cent of the vote whereas a major party with as much as 45 per cent of the vote may finish up with only two long term senators despite the fact that the third person on the major party's list almost had a full residual quota. The third reason for support of the amendment at the time was that it would prevent any party which might have an absolute majority in the Senate from determining all its senators to be long term senators and all Opposition senators to be short term senators. Fourthly, the change made in 1983 would totally eliminate political interference in this part of the electoral process. Those were the points that the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform had in mind when it proposed the change in the first place. They were also the points that Senator Ray and others articulated so well in December 1983 when the proposal was debated in the Senate and incorporated without dissent, other than what I will describe as perhaps a technical dissent on the part of Senator Harradine.

It cannot be logically argued that the Senate has not agreed to the new system. It agreed to it in December 1983 when it accepted the amendment to this effect introduced by the Hawke Government to the Commonwealth Electoral Act. The Governor-General's Speech at the opening of Parliament earlier this week mentioned the desirability of fewer elections. This cynical, shabby motion that we have before us now from the Government will work in total contradiction to the words of the Governor-General's Speech. This motion is a sleazy act of cynical and rank hypocrisy on the part of the Government. The Democrats have indicated that they will be supporting the Government's motion. I urge them to reconsider because support for this motion would demonstrate that the Democrats have lost all semblance of political or ethical principle. The Government's refusal to recommend to the Senate on this occasion the adoption of the system of rotation of senators agreed to in 1983 makes a mockery of the Government's proposed acceptance of the concept inherent in section 282 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act-the section inserted on the initiative of the present Government and accepted by the other parties. If the Senate does not adopt the method of rotation proposed in section 282 then it is fair to ask why the section is there at all. We know why it is there; I have already outlined the reasons. It is incumbent on the Senate to act logically and responsibly. The Government's motion is illogical, irresponsible and shabby. The Leader of the Government, Senator Button, obviously knows this; that is why he did not debate the matter when he moved the motion yesterday. The motion represents a deal with the Australian Democrats which this chamber must not allow idly to pass. The Liberal and National parties therefore oppose the motion and urge the Senate to pursue the approach recommended by the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform and accepted by this chamber in 1983.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's motion with regard to the long and short term senators as proposed by Senator Button will receive the support of the Australian Democrats. The previous speaker, Senator Short, has come lately to this particular area. He gave us a potted history of the method by which long and short term senators have been chosen. I think it is useful for people to know what the actual situation is. The Constitution is silent as to the method by which the Senate will determine long and short term senators. The Senate has been given the constitutional power to choose long and short term senators by any means it so desires. During the election campaign a number of Opposition members raised this particular point and indeed thought that the amendments to the electoral law somehow or other overrode the Constitution. The fact is that they do not override the Constitution. The situation is--
—No one suggested they do.

—I am sorry, Senator Short; they certainly did suggest it. I can tell the honourable senator the names of the Opposition members who suggested it, if he likes. The situation is that the proposal with regard to a recount was first mooted by me in the first Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. During that particular operation, because we had so much on our plate-indeed we had the total revision of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, something that the Liberal and National parties in all their time in office never got around to doing-many of the items were dropped out and could be considered only by the second Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform.

SPEECH.PARA: The method that was then proposed on the voice of the Chairman of the Committee at the time, Senator Robert Ray, was finally inserted into our second report and was accepted by the Senate. However, it is interesting to note that the method of simply taking the order in which people have been elected has been around for quite some time. It was suggested at that time that, if a change were to take place, it was fair and reasonable to say that that change would take place prior to an election in which one would use that particular method. That seemed to us and to the Committee a reasonable operation. It so happened, of course, that before the last election no such change was mooted. Quite simply, the reason that proposal is in the Electoral Act is to provide guidance to the Senate in determining long and short term senators. There is no mystique about that. Whether the Senate now or in the future decides to use that is entirely up to the Senate. It is a very useful piece of information, particularly when one looks at a number of the States to determine how the numbers fall out. It is particularly interesting, for example, to look at Victoria. The person who ended up at number 11 was a National Party senator, Senator McGauran, who ended up as number six on the countback under section 282. It was an interesting exercise and I might have ended up in a similar situation if I had got a few more of former Senator Georges's votes. It is a very useful exercise and I would certainly defend the insertion of section 282 in the Electoral Act. It is very useful data for the Senate to have when making its determination on long and short term senators.

However, the Opposition spokesman, Senator Short, went even further. He decided to do a little hatchet job on the Australian Democrats, saying that deals had been done, et cetera. He did not actually go on to say where and when the deals had been made or what anyone was to have got out of them. I dare say that he will not be mentioning this outside the chamber, for obvious reasons to do with the law. If the Government were to enter into some deals I would have thought it ought to repay the favours that it got from the Opposition when it passed most of the Government's legislation in the last Budget, against the votes of the Democrats.

Let us go through a few of those items railed against by the Opposition in the House of Representatives and then passed by it in the Senate. The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1986, which was to do with wine, is an example. Hansard shows Mr Carlton in the other place as having said that this was a `further blow to citrus growers and processors'. On and on he went. He said further, `We deplore the Bill's effect on the industries that will suffer under its provisions'. Then the Opposition voted for the Bill. The Australian Multicultural Affairs Bill 1986 is another example. Mr Cadman said:
We believe that the Government could not have handled this matter in a more insensitive manner . . .
We in the Opposition do not agree . . .

Then the Opposition in the Senate voted for it. The Income Tax Rates Bill 1986 and cognate Bills were criticised by the Opposition in the House of Representatives but voted for by the Opposition here. The Australian Land Transport Amendment Bill 1986 is another example. Mr Tuckey said, `This measure is not a sensible solution'. However, the Opposition voted for it. The Social Security and Veterans' Affairs (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill was condemned by the Opposition but voted for by it. The Opposition condemned the reintroduction of tertiary fees in the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) and cognate Bills and then it voted for them. The Opposition said that the reason for the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1986 and cognate Bills was simply to raise more money from the overburdened taxpayer, then it voted for the legislation.

If the Government really were in the business of making deals with the Opposition parties it really ought to see where its true interest lies and do a few deals with the Opposition, which has been much more supportive of Government legislation than have the Australian Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our future lies in principles, not in deals.
—How do you spell that?

—I think Senator Short spells it `principals'. The situation is very clear. With regard to the operation of legislation in this place, we have looked at each piece of legislation and determined our attitude to it on its merits. I suggest that if honourable senators think through the issue they will see why we came to that decision very early on when we gained the balance of power after the 1980 election. We have held the balance of power since 1 July 1981. The reason was an obviously political one, which was that not to do that would simply have embroiled us in threatening the government of the day, the then Fraser Government, with the non-passage of all of its legislation unless we got particular items in our policies up and running. We determined very early on that that just was not on. It was not in the interests of the country that that occur and it has not occurred since then. In fact, it has never occurred. It is very easy to throw around the types of accusations that Senator Short threw around yesterday and again today; it is much more difficult to disprove them. They are a little like the abominable snowman. They are not accessible to disproof because one can simply go on and raise another conspiratorial instance of where one believes some particular deal or another has occurred.

SPEECH.PARA: To return to the substance of what is going on and put it into perspective, when one looks at the old method and does one's sums on who will get what, one sees that under the old method the Australian Labor Party would get 17 long term senators and under the new method it would get 17. Under the old method the Liberal Party of Australia would get 15 long term senators and under the new method it would get 15. Under the old method the National Party of Australia would get one and under the new method it would get three. Under the old method the Democrats would get three and under the new method, one. Therefore, the debate basically is not between the Labor Party and the Liberal Party-I see Senator Brownhill is entering the chamber-it is obviously about whether the National Party will end up with one or the Democrats will end up with one. Essentially that is the point of the exercise.

TALK.START.PARA: —What sort of a deal are you doing with the Labor Party?

—If Senator Brownhill had turned up the speaker in his room he would have heard that point mentioned before. Obviously, he was not interested in the debate. He has just wandered into the chamber and found it on so he has now decided to interject. For Senator Brownhill's enlightenment and edification of the points I have been making, I refer him to the Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly the question is whether the parties in this place will be supporting the old or the proposed new method. Before we even knew the determination of the Cabinet with regard to which method the Government would be proposing to the Senate I said to many members of the Press: `A reasonable bet on working out which methods the various political parties will be supporting is to address the matter in terms of the parties' self-interest and find out which system they would get more under'. I maintained that in the Senate debate they will be marshalling their principles to support their self-interests. Of course, the best position on which one can stand is when one's principles coincide with one's self-interest. Fairly clearly, the situation is that under the proposed new change to the electoral Act, the Labor Party would go into the next election, which is, of course, what we are really interested in, with 17 long term senators and the Opposition parties would go in with 18.

I am glad that Senator Brownhill came into the chamber because I point out that the problem that would arise after the next election, if there is a half Senate election, would be directly caused by the National Party voting with the Labor Party. Quite frankly, I have absolutely no compunction about where our vote will go because it was the National Party which increased the size of the House of Representatives and the Senate and caused the type of problem that will raise its head after the next election. If there is a series of elections without double dissolutions, it is likely that this place will end up with a tied number, which would make the entire parliamentary system unworkable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—It would make it unworkable because the Leader of the Opposition in the other place would control the Parliament. In this place, if a party gets half the number of votes it can defeat any Bill. That is part of the constitutional compact. A party needs half the number of senators plus one to get a Bill passed.
—You would get some seats in a half-Senate election.

—That may very well be the case. I am simply saying that if in a half-Senate election the electorate divided in such a way as to provide the Labor Party with three senators and the Opposition parties with three senators, we would be moving closer to each party having half the numbers. For a party to get four senators it has to get roughly 58 per cent of the vote.
—We are working on it.

—Undoubtedly Senator Richardson was working on it for the last election but he did not get anywhere near that figure and neither did the Opposition parties. However, for a party to get three senators it needs roughly only 43 per cent, and the Labor and Opposition parties got close to that figure in every State. This matter is nothing new. I forecast this exercise in terms of increasing the size of the Parliament in my response to the legislation when it first went through this place. There is a very real problem facing us with regard to that issue. It is not one that stemmed only from the increase in the size of the Parliament; it is one which stemmed from the increase in the size of the Parliament connected with the very odd constitutional problem that there is a nexus between this place and the other place. Despite the fact that all the political parties in this place support the breaking of the nexus, we have not been able to convince the electorate to do so. So every time we increase the size of the Parliament, we are going to increase it by two or four in every State-whatever the prevailing number happens to be; but it will be at least two-and we will be in the situation in which we are in today.

Now that Senator Brownhill has wandered into the chamber for want of anything better to do-doubtless he has read his Bulletin and newspapers today-I would like to read a letter from one of his colleagues in the other place which shows the type of hypocrisy the National Party goes in for. The letter was written by the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) on 9 October 1986. Honourable senators who are still interested in this area will remember that we had a very interesting debate in this place on the service retirement pay and superannuation Bill, and the war service Bill-the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Amendment Bill. The Government, as a result of decisions made in the last Budget, was going to have a one-off reduction in war service payments. The letter was written on 9 October, and that date is important. In answer to a constituent's letter the honourable member for Lyne stated:

Whilst I know that the Coalition Senators will do all they can to block the proposed amendments I cannot speak for the Australian Democrats and would point out that they have let the Coalition down badly over past issues when they voted with the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following Address-in-Reply be agreed to:
To His Excellency, the Governor-General,

May it please Your Excellency-We, the Senate of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled, desire to express our loyalty to our most gracious sovereign and to thank Your Excellency for the speech which you have been pleased to address to Parliament.

I am deeply honoured to have been asked to move this motion in reply to His Excellency's Speech. I am also pleased, Mr President, to be one of the first to congratulate you on your re-election. It also pleases me to congratulate all those who have been elected or re-elected to this Senate and, in particular, to welcome the record number of newly-elected senators who join me for the first time in this chamber. It is interesting to note that the election of 17 new senators represents a record for contemporary elections. This is a demonstration of the greater volatility of the Senate in recent times and a reflection of the more common occurrence of double dissolutions. In the 87-year history of the Parliament there have been only six double dissolutions-in 1914, in 1951, in 1974, in 1983, and in 1987. Their more frequent incidence in recent years seems to indicate a pattern for the future with its corollary that perhaps none of us can be assured of the traditionally long career in the Senate.

His Excellency the Governor-General, in his Speech at the opening of this, the Thirty-fifth Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia, indicated that the Government would pursue in its third term a range of proposals designed, on the one hand, to build a stronger, more competitive and more efficient economy and, on the other, a fairer and more compassionate Australian society. This encapsulates the Government's broad strategic approach. It is an approach which, particularly in current economic circumstances, demands of the Government a high degree of self-discipline, the need for rigorous analysis of policy options and great courage in the implementation of decisions, once made.

I believe that the Government has demonstrated such discipline and courage in its first two terms of office. I am proud to have been associated with this period of political history and look forward to the achievement of some of the goals established by the Government in the long and difficult process of national reconstruction.

The approach of the Government throughout its first two terms of office has been understood and accepted by the majority of Australians. This is reflected in the return of the Government with an increased majority in the House of Representatives. There is no doubt, however, that the Government's approach is sadly misunderstood by many. It is apparent from a cursory analysis of the election results that Labor, whilst gaining seats, lost support from some sectors of its traditional base. I freely admit this. I know from my experience as State Secretary of the Western Australian Branch of the Labor Party since 1981 that some Party supporters, disillusioned with their perception of the Government's performance, grudgingly cast Labor votes because the emergence of the so-called New Right signalled the need to close ranks.

Nor has this problem of perceptions been made any easier by certain members of the media who, influenced more by popular cliches than by scrutiny of the facts, refer to the Government as having sold out on Labor principles or of there being little difference between Labor and its conservative opposition. Such accusations are easy to make but are not borne out by any objective assessment of the facts.

It is of course important for the Government to spend adequate time explaining its goals and objectives, its broad strategy and the component parts of this strategy. If there has been a fault of the Government it has been that, busily involved in the gruelling processes of policy formulation and administration, it has failed to give a high priority to the equally important process of explaining what it is doing and why and how it is doing it. There is a responsibility on governments to take both supporters and the larger community into their confidence. This Government must address this problem or suffer a loss in support and, more importantly, the gradual but inexorable decay of its traditional base.

Having said this, I return to my point that the Hawke Government has approached the business of government in a refreshingly thorough, rigorous and disciplined way, that it has shown the courage to take the required tough decisions and that, despite adverse economic conditions, it has achieved a great deal both in terms of reconstructing and revitalising the economy and in terms of the gradual achievement of a more just and equitable society.

Few governments, even in better economic times, could lay claims to social achievements such as the introduction of Medicare, providing medical security for all Australians, including the two million not previously covered in any way; an 8.1 per cent increase in pensions compared to a 2.5 per cent increase during Fraser's years so that pensions are now 24.4 per cent of average weekly earnings with guaranteed indexed increases to keep pace with inflation; vast improvements in rent assistance to the poor, particularly those with children; the easing of poverty traps for social security beneficiaries and the introduction of the family package, directing tangible benefits to those in greatest need; a 42 per cent increase in public housing together with assistance to over 200,000 people through the first home owners scheme; a massive redistribution of income from the wealthy to the poor-demonstrated in the latest Budget-by means of a thorough restructuring of the taxation system and the redistribution of revenues through the social security system; the progressive provision of superannuation for the whole work force; the sensitive handling of industrial relations through the accord and support for improvements in wages and other conditions in an orderly and fair system and in consultation with unions; a substantial rise-from 36 per cent in 1983 to nearly 50 per cent in 1987-in the number of children completing full secondary education with a commitment to raise the retention rate to 65 per cent by the first half of the next decade; a 12 per cent employment growth in four years, averaging 3 per cent per year-double the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average; the doubling of child care places; a wide range of initiatives for women, including creative and now widely accepted initiatives in the areas of equal opportunity, discrimination and affirmative action; and a record in conservation and environment equalled by no other government in Australian history.

Apart from recent decisions to seek a World Heritage listing for the wet tropics of north-east Queensland and the commitment to protect the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests in Tasmania, the Government has also shown its commitment to the environment by acting to protect the nation's natural wonders at the Franklin River, the Great Barrier Reef, Shelbourne Bay, Kakadu, Uluru, and the scenic beauty of the Denmark area in Western Australia. All of this, and much more, has been achieved in a period of severe economic restraint caused by the collapse in Australia's terms of trade, affecting our international competitiveness.

Apart from these social initiatives-although each of them has economic implications-the Government has shown the same thoroughness, the same application, to other key areas of concern to traditional supporters. Areas worthy of greater dissemination and a source of considerable pride to those of us close to the political process are the Government's initiatives in restructuring various industries and the handling of the economy. There are many other real achievements. While I do not intend to list these, I will draw attention to one-the Government's approach to the question of peace and disarmament.

Of all the areas in which Labor has-and I admit this again-lost its traditional base vote, the peace and disarmament area is the most significant. The presence of two nuclear disarmament independents in this chamber is testimony to this. Yet again I believe that if our supporters were fully aware of the Government's record they would be both surprised and impressed. I believe that the Government's handling of this important question has been appropriate and sensible. The planned movement, as expressed in the defence White Paper, towards greater defence self-reliance, based on an acceptance that Australia faces no immediate threat, the emphasis on greater involvement for Australian industry in defence procurement, the active engagement of the Government in a catalytic role at international disarmament fora, the redefinition and strengthening of Australia's role in joint defence facilities are all precursors to any more fundamental repositioning of Australia in world affairs.

In the complex and sensitive area of international relations, change must inevitably be painstakingly slow. It would be irresponsible indeed to upset the delicate balance which currently exists between the super-powers. Change must also, for reasons I will explain shortly, gain the support of the community at large. There exists in the Australian community an historically-based insecurity which cannot be ignored. In this context, unilateralist positions, or those that pose under a different name whilst expressing the same views, are no more sensible or appropriate than those which uncritically accept existing defence arrangements and alliances as static and unchanging, or those which see the defence of Australia as some sort of continuous ideological holy war.

In this regard I object most strongly to those activists within the peace movement who believe that they have a monopoly on principle and morality; those who spurn anyone who cannot in all sincerity accept uncritically and totally a cluster of beliefs some of which, I feel, bear only tenuously on questions of peace and disarmament. Each of us has his or her own way of working towards personal goals. You do not have to bleed to show that you have a heart: you do not have to pray to demonstrate the presence of a soul. I have been actively involved in the peace movement since the early 1960s. My commitment is no less strong now than it was then. The way I choose to express my commitment is no less legitimate than those who choose to wear their commitment on their sleeves.

Setting aside this brief digression, Mr President, I think I have demonstrated what I believe to be a commendable record of achievement by this Government. There are, I believe, a number of reasons why these are not fully understood by our traditional supporters. Apart from the already mentioned fact that governments must spend more time explaining what they are doing, it should be understood that there are, in any pluralist society, a number of constraints on any government involved in the process of change.

The first such constraint is, of course, the state of the economy. The massive collapse in Australia's terms of trade, for example, has been a major constraint on the introduction of new programs or on the extension of existing programs. A second constraint, frequently overlooked, is that governments of whatever political persuasion must seek and gain a reasonable level of community support for planned changes. It is an axiom of politics that no government legislates in a vacuum. Any government which acts as if it is somehow removed from the community it serves will quickly suffer the electoral consequences of such insularity. It follows that governments must attempt to create a climate of acceptability for their ideas. The educative role is equally important as the legislative role. A third constraint is the fact that this is a mixed economy in which government actions have a direct bearing on the private sector. As the major employer and engine of economic activity, governments must win the confidence of the private sector. Only by healthy activity here can revenue be generated to fund programs of reform.

There is now added complexity in the increasing interdependence of the world economy. It is no longer possible to make decisions in an exclusively Australian context. The impact of such decisions on the rest of the world is now an important part of the equation. And this is not because of deregulation and the opening up of the Australian economy. This new interdependent world pre-dated the decision to deregulate. Prior to that decision we were simply hiding from reality.

Given these and other constraints, governments, if they wish to survive long enough to be effective, must tread warily. The pace of change is thus slow. Party members and supporters with high expectations are understandably critical of the rate of social and political change and frequently intolerant of the constraints limiting the speed of a reform government's actions. Often this critical focus obscures appreciation of the substantial gains being made, the social changes being wrought. But this does not reflect any selling out of principle, nor does it imply a loss of philosophical direction. Those who fall into the trap of accepting this line of argument are, I believe, confusing means and ends. Labor's socialist objective is concerned with the achievement of a society in which each individual has a right to enjoy a life with dignity, security and equality. This is the end. This is the absolute at which we aim. The means of achieving this end, the processes leading to this product are not absolutes. They are and should be the subject of constant discussion and debate.

The success of Labor governments, both nationally and in the States, is a product of a more hard-headed approach to this question of means and ends; of finding innovative ways of achieving agreed objectives. Nowhere is this more evident than in Western Australia where only last week the Government, through judicious management and entrepreneurial flair and despite current economic difficulties, brought down a surplus Budget. Despite a fall in Commonwealth payments to the States of about 11 per cent since 1983-84, the Government has achieved a degree of expenditure control highlighted by the fact that Government expenditure as a proportion of gross State product, which is a measure of total activity in the State, has declined by more than 13 per cent since 1983-84.

It has achieved the surplus Budget in part by creative initiatives designed to generate alternative sources of revenue at the same time as stimulating economic activity. Two key examples are the Western Australian Development Corporation and Western Australian Exim Corporation. Established as profit-based commercial trading enterprises they have successfully helped in generating additional Government revenues; enhancing the Government's role as an industry co-ordinator and analyst in economic development; increasing local ownership in industry; assisting local firms in marshalling the financial resources necessary for large scale development projects; further developing the State's financial sector; and expanding the market for State products by promoting exports.

The success of these ventures, together with prudent yet imaginative management, has resulted in Western Australia out-performing most other States with reference to the standard economic indicators. For example, Western Australia experienced employment growth of 2.7 per cent in the 12 months to July 1987-higher than all States other than Victoria; the highest level of actual new fixed capital expenditure per capita in the 12 months to May 1987; the highest total value of new dwelling approvals per capita in the 12 months to April 1987, indicating strong building activity; and the highest increase in the value of retail sales between April 1986 and April 1987.

The obvious good standing of the State was made possible by the Western Australian Government's creativity in finding new ways of reaching old goals. These new ways were not found in order to forsake fundamental Labor principles but as the only way, given the current economic and political climate, of achieving such goals.

I hope you will forgive the parochialism in these comments, Mr President, but forms and precedents dictate that I direct some of my comments to my home State. It is also, of course, the State which elected me and the State which I am both attached to and fondly proud of.

I wish to conclude on a more personal note. I want to thank all of those people who have made my transition into this new role so much easier. I refer in particular to you, Mr President, and to the staff of the Senate and the Joint House staff who have been uniformly pleasant and helpful. I am impressed by the creative flexibility of this group and by their willingness to service without complaint the smallest of needs. I also want to thank the many people who have assisted and supported me throughout my career firstly in union then in party politics, and who have assisted me in entering the Senate. In particular I thank my family, immediate and extended, for the support they have given me.

Few people outside of politics realise the stresses placed on the family by a political career. Apart from the frequent absences and intrusions into family time, family members are often faced with discrimination and disruption to both their professional and personal lives. I thank in particular my wife Jenny for her support and counsel, despite the fact that she has suffered personally. I also thank my children, Daniel and Kate, for their understanding and acceptance of the many compromises that have to be made when juxtaposing family life and a political career.

I trust that, with time, all of us involved in the daily cut and thrust of politics will adopt and practice a set of principles which respects the privacy and dignity of family life and regards personal attacks on family members, without the strongest foundations, as improper and unacceptable. I look forward to a rewarding life in the Senate, a life that will be busy, arduous and sometimes stressful, but never lacking in interest and variety.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling on Senator Collins to second the Address-in-Reply, I remind honourable senators that this will be his initial speech in this chamber and I ask that the honourable senator also be extended the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have much pleasure in seconding the motion and I add my congratulations to you on your re-election as President of the Senate. My first speech in this chamber is going to be very parish pump, for which I offer absolutely no apologies whatever. I come to this place as only the second Labor senator from the Northern Territory, after 12 years of very distinguished service by my predecessor, Ted Robertson. Despite Ted Robertson's numerical problems he was at least marginally more fortunate than the Territory's first representative in the House of Representatives, Harold Nelson. Ted Robertson at least had a vote; Harold Nelson did not.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite Harold Nelson's eunuch-rather than unique-status in the House of Representatives, he did not let that stop him. He became a very forceful advocate for the needs of the Northern Territory. In his maiden speech, delivered in 1923, he talked about the need for a north-south railway-I am glad Peter Walsh has gone-constitutional development for the Northern Territory, an increase in mining activity and the development of Asian markets for the Territory. At first glance it would seem that the Territory's agenda has not changed all that much over the last 60 years. In fact, there could be few places in Australia where the social, political and economic landscape has changed as dramatically as it has in my home-dare I say it-State of the Northern Territory.

When I first arrived in the Northern Territory just 20 years ago the city of Darwin was a place straight out of a Somerset Maugham novel-10,000 people of the most diverse ethnic mix imaginable living in tropical isolation. Fifty miles north were the very beautiful Bathurst and Melville Islands, the home of the Tiwi people of whom my wife Rosemary is one. I remember some years ago when I was learning to speak Tiwi my wife explained to me that the word `Tiwi' itself means `the chosen people'. The reason for that is that the Tiwi felt for thousands of years that they were the only people on earth. They were well aware of the existence of the mainland, of course, only 50 miles away, but believed it was pukamami, forbidden, because it was inhabited by the souls of the dead. When I first arrived in Darwin 20 years ago there was considerable evidence for believing that was true. Eighty per cent of the work force were public servants, as indeed I was myself. The only sealed road was the Stuart Highway. It was not much of a road at that. As a result, in the wet season one did not do much because one could not, and in the dry season one did not do a lot because the wet season was coming.

The Territory has changed a great deal since those times but I fear that the perceptions of the Territory, particularly in southern places, have not. The misconceptions and mistrust which particularly bedevil Territory-Canberra relationships still need to be broken down. Canberra, regardless of which government is in power, is seen in the north as a place dedicated solely to strangling the Northern Territory at birth. Canberra is certainly seen that way. The Northern Territory is seen in many quarters in Canberra-some quarters more than others, I must say-as a bottomless pit for Federal money with no return on the investment. In the 1980s that view can be easily disproved. Last year the Northern Territory's mining industry turned over $1 billion in production. Its percentage of the Territory's gross domestic product was the highest of any State or Territory. Substantial progress has also been made in the trade drive into Asia. Last year the value of exports from the Northern Territory to Asia doubled the amount of imports from the same region. That is a performance that has yet to be echoed on a national level.

The growth of this Northern Territory will continue and I say with some feeling that it is in both the economic and strategic national interests of this country that the Commonwealth continues to stimulate and encourage that growth. To its credit, this Government has shown that it is prepared to do exactly that. The gold industry is a case in point. Gold production in the Territory doubled in 1986 and is set to double again this year. This is due in no small part to the Government's decision not to impose a gold tax. I had my heart in my mouth last night, for no good reason. Many marginal prospects in the Northern Territory would have remained idle if such a tax had been imposed. One of the most promising new prospects in an advanced stage of proving up is the very substantial Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd deposit at Coronation Hill.

I was encouraged to hear the Governor- General outline the Government's defence agenda for the next three years. The strategic vulnerability of northern Australia provided the greatest incentive at that time for the federation of the States. Little of significance has been done until now to bolster northern defences except to talk about it. This Government has made the most significant commitment to Northern Territory defence in memory, a fact grudgingly conceded by even its most trenchant critics in northern Australia. That development is dramatically underpinning the Territory's economy at this time. The redevelopment of the Tindal Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) base near Katherine is currently the largest development project in the Northern Territory. Over $200m has already been committed to that project and it will be worth $1 billion by the time it is completed. When finished it will be 11 times the size of the Amberley RAAF base in Queensland, currently the largest RAAF establishment in Australia.

With the assistance of the recently established Northern Territory Industrial Supplies Office (ISO)-a wonderful incentive of mine, I must say-many local companies have been successful in gaining lucrative contracts from the project. However, the ISO believes that the process for letting future defence contracts can be even further improved to enhance the competitive nature of Northern Territory companies. I have raised this matter with the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and I hope that the early involvement of the ISO in the tender process will result in a good flow of contracts to Northern Territory firms for the relocation of the 2nd Cavalry Regiment in the Northern Territory and future work on the Jindalee over the horizon radar installation in central Australia.

Tourism is booming in the Northern Territory. Final figures for the last year will show that nearly three-quarters of a million people visited the Northern Territory last year, despite the fact that one could fit our population into the Victorian Football League football grounds. As predicted, the federally funded sealing of the south road has brought a flood of tourist traffic into the Northern Territory which is causing some short term problems, placing a great strain on tourist infrastructure along the highway. The Northern Territory Tourist Commission chief, Mr George Dunne, says, and truly, that our wilderness and our wildlife are the keys to the Territory's tourist boom. Our two major tourist attractions are the Uluru and Kakadu national parks-world heritage country, steeped in Aboriginal history. I was very fortunate in being able to work for quite a number of years in Kakadu when I was employed by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. I am constantly dismayed, however, by public statements by senior Northern Territory Ministers that publicly advocate that all stages of the Kakadu National Park-indeed, the Minister for Mines and Energy has said this on many occasions-stages 1, 2 and 3, should be opened to mining. It is the view of people like that that the environmental and tourist aspects of the park should be subjugated to the interests of mining.

Kakadu, apart from its spectacular landscape and water birds, is the greatest repository of Aboriginal rock art in the world. The park has 5,000 rock art galleries. Also, the flora and fauna of the Yellowwaters billabong is spectacular. I should point out that 80 per cent of the water birds in Australia are there despite, I might also add, a very healthy collection of those very large sets of teeth on legs, Kakadu's crocodiles. A very important person to the Northern Territory over the next three years is going to be the newly appointed Minister for the Environment and the Arts, Senator Graham Richardson. Indeed, I would think he could do himself a favour if he could manage to break one of those crocodiles in on a lead and take it with him on his trips. If he did so, he would not have to worry about any further demonstrations.

Kakadu National Park is, and always was, a compromise. The agreements were signed for Kakadu the same day as the agreements were signed for the Ranger uranium mine. It was part of that deal. Like all compromises, its present and future users can never completely satisfy all of the competing interests in the park. It is fair to say, though, that until now the compromise between Aboriginal, environmental, tourism and mining interests has been as successful as one could possibly expect. I do not hesitate to say, however, that when it is necessary, as it is, to give more weight to any one of those competing interests, priority must rest with the environmental interests of the park.

Kakadu is now outstripping Uluru as the major tourist attraction of the Northern Territory. Despite serious Budget restrictions, this Government has funded both parks to the tune of $10m in the last financial year-I noticed last night the very healthy investment that has been made this year-making Kakadu the most heavily funded national park by a country mile in Australia. There is one pressing need upon which I have already made representations to the Minister, namely, the establishment of a Kakadu Park board of management based on the same successful model as the board currently operating at Uluru and, indeed, the board operating at the Northern Territory Conservation Commission's Gurig National Park at Cobourg Peninsula.

Most of the visitors to the Northern Territory, despite the sealing of the south road, still arrive by air. Darwin Airport handles as many aircraft movements a year as do both the Cairns Airport and the Perth Airport. However, it is an inadequate, ugly and inefficient front door to Australia. The replacement of that terminal will be a primary objective of mine in this coming term. I was very pleased to see in the Budget Papers presented last night that $4.5m has been allocated to upgrading Alice Springs Airport which, considering the extent of the traffic going out to Ayers Rock at the moment, is very welcome indeed.

I wish to raise a number of general issues because of their impact on the Northern Territory. The campaign to oppose the Australia Card has generated considerable debate. Some of it has been ill-informed. Some of it, I do not hesitate to say, in my view has been over the top. In keeping with the spirit of this speech, I will not dwell on that campaign, except to say-and I must say it-that unprincipled opportunism rather than principled opposition has certainly marked at least some of the contributions to the debate. I am disappointed at statements from the Northern Territory, Queensland and Tasmanian governments that they intend not to co-operate with the Commonwealth request for a national computerised linkage of births, deaths and marriage registers. I would remind honourable senators that the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card advocated this measure as an essential reform in the fight against fraud and organised crime, particularly in the drug trade. Despite being split on the question of the card with a photograph, it was the Committee's first and unanimous recommendation that the computerised link be implemented whether the card was introduced or not. The only people who are going to benefit from the political opposition to this reform are those defrauding the Commonwealth. Quite clearly, it is in the national interest that those two issues be separated in the manner that the Joint Select Committee itself separated them.

I welcome the reference by the Governor-General that a royal commission will be established to inquire into the disturbingly high number of Aboriginal deaths in custody. I was very pleased that a Northern Territory judge, Mr Justice Muirhead, will be the commissioner. I have known and respected Jim Muirhead for many years. He is an eminent jurist who achieved some public prominence as the judge who presided over the Chamberlain trial-a trial that, despite the controversy, he conducted impeccably. I have written to the relevant Minister expressing some views on the conduct of the commission and in particular that it should investigate, at least in a general sense, the number and circumstances surrounding non-Aboriginal deaths in custody. I have no doubt that this Parliament, and the people of Australia, will be anxious to receive the recommendations of that Commission.

The Northern Territory was the scene of the most extraordinary case in the history of criminal justice in Australia. Two people, with a history of providing nothing but love and care for their children, were convicted, in the case of Lindy Chamberlain, of the cold-blooded murder of her own nine-week-old daughter, and in the case of Michael Chamberlain, of being an accessory to that murder. The Crown provided no witnesses to the murder, no weapon, no motive and no body. The Chamberlains were convicted largely on the basis of expert forensic evidence. We now know, as a result of the royal commission conducted by Mr Justice Morling, that much of that evidence was dreadfully wrong. The Morling Commission found that the `bloody handprint' on the baby's jumpsuit was marks made by red sand. The pool of baby's blood under the seat containing that magic ingredient, haemoglobin F, turned out to be not blood at all but, in the view of the commission, probably a spilled milkshake. The sprayed pattern of blood on the dashboard-that dramatic evidence; the baby's blood pumping from a cut throat-turned out to be sound deadener sprayed on the car by General Motors-Holden's Ltd when it was manufactured.

Lindy Chamberlain spent 3 1/2 years in Berrimah Prison and the Chamberlain family have spent years in hell on the basis of that now totally discredited evidence. Many suggestions were made in the course of this matter to ensure that this could never happen again. Some of them, such as the selection of expert juries, horrified me. However, Mr Justice Morling recommended in his report, which was tabled in this House, what many forensic scientists have been calling for for years-the establishment of a national forensic laboratory to set uniform standards for forensic testing throughout Australia and to monitor the application of those standards. I will be pressing this Government for the implementation of that recommendation.

Many statements have been made about the celebration of Australia's Bicentenary. It is important, at least to me, to debunk some of the statements. A great many have said that 26 January 1988 will be our second centenary as a nation. Some very important people have said that. That is nonsense, of course. We are not even celebrating our first centenary as a nation. That will not occur until 1 January 2001. When the British prisoners and their gaolers arrived in Australia on 26 January 1788 only the eastern portion of Australia was claimed for King George III. It was not in fact until 1829 that the western portion of Australia was claimed by the British, and not until 1879 that the Torres Strait Islands were claimed.

Prior to Federation in 1901 we were a collection of independent States and, indeed, if it had not been for the creation of this Senate, modelled on the United States Senate, we could well have remained so. Comparison with the American experience is instructive. I have been hard put to find an American who can remember the date of the arrival of the Mayflower, let along celebrate it. The most significant day of celebration for Americans is 4 July, the anniversary of the promulgation of the Declaration of Independence. The recent American Bicentennial was indeed the 200th anniversary of that day. Let us get straight what in fact we will be celebrating. The 26 January 1988 will be the 200th birthday of the city of Sydney, not the birth of the nation of Australia, and that city is entitled to it. Acknowledging that fact, one of the Bicentennial projects-and I have been a member of the council in the Territory since its inception-that I was truly enthusiastic about was the erection of a giant birthday cake in Kings Cross. I think possibly the reason I was so enthusiastic is that it was going to be built 3,000 kilometres away from where I live. But if any place deserves a birthday cake, Sydney does. I was very sorry to read in the Press that that big cake has hit the wall and it has been replaced by a far more tasteful and relevant monument to the Bicentennial-a giant anteater with 200 candles stuck on its back. With due respect to your home town, Mr President, I do not think that Melbourne's claim to be the cultural centre of Australia is under much threat.

When we consider the state of the current debate-this is where I get very provocative-on whether we should remove the flag of a distant nation, albeit one that is as historically and culturally important to us as Britain, from our own national flag, it is arguable that we are in truth not a nation yet. I confess freely that I am one of those Australians, however few, who would dearly love to see the Southern Cross without the Union Jack run up our $10m flagpole next year. I am pleased that the Northern Territory, even before actually becoming a State, has been the first to produce a unique, striking and truly Australian flag-the first without the Union Jack-and featuring the Southern Cross and Sturt's desert rose in the Territory colours of black, white and ochre.

Much has been said about the participation or otherwise of Aboriginal people in this Bicentenary. It has been stated, and fairly enough in my view, that a far more significant date for Aboriginals to commemorate would be 25 January 1788, the last day on which they enjoyed the undisturbed occupation of this colony. The year 1988 will, however, be a birthday of sorts for Aboriginals, a birthday which will highlight the extent of the injustice, dispossession and indeed dehumanisation of those people that have been inflicted upon them since 1788. The year of 1988 will be the twenty-first anniversary of the granting of citizenship to Aboriginal Australians, the attainment of their adult majority as Australians. Just 20 years ago, in 1967, we graciously allowed Aboriginal people to join us as citizens of a country that they had been part of for 200 bicentenaries.

Critics of the protest of Aboriginals and others complain of, as they see it, the preoccupation of the protesters with past injustices. If injustice and maltreatment were things of the past, that criticism might have some validity. It is, however, that sad history which is responsible for the continuing injustices of 1987, and it is those injustices that concern me.

The attention paid quite rightly to the deaths of Aboriginals in custody should not overshadow the much more serious problem of the number of premature deaths of Aboriginal people out of custody. Thousands of Aboriginal Australians living on cattle stations, in fringe camps and in urban slums right around Australia will enter 1988 still living in the same squalor and deprivation of their forebears since they were dispossessed of their land 200 years ago and dying from it. I hope that 1988 will produce a concentration of effort by Aboriginal organisations and by Federal, State and Territorial governments tangibly to improve the living conditions of these most neglected Australians. I agree with Charles Perkins: the Bicentenary should be a time when it can all hang out. Let the First Fleet re-enactment arrive if it can, if it does not run out of money or sink on the way. Let Aboriginal Australians use 1988 in any way they see fit.

Whatever 1988 may or may not be, it is certainly the bicentenary of Aboriginals and non-Aboriginals living together in this country. In the past that was achieved by the lives and culture of the former being sacrificed out of hand for the convenience of the latter, a reality in much of Australia today. We all have our hopes for 1988. One of mine is that 1988 can be celebrated at least by an acceptance of that reality by all Australians, and some commitment that a future relationship can be based instead on true equality and mutual respect.

The full constitutional development of the Northern Territory will create Australia's seventh State. It will bring to the Federation of States a unique community. There are over 60 nationalities represented in the Northern Territory, the largest being the Chinese and Greek communities, and of course one-quarter of our population being Aboriginal Territorians. Thousands of Aboriginal Territorians have been fortunate to have largely been able to retain their very special lifestyle, languages and religious practices. The magnificent Aboriginal art of the Northern Territory is drawn from a living, not a dead, culture. Apart from that, that industry provides the Northern Territory with export earnings of currently around $4m a year.

But Territorians, in my view, cannot be sold out for a short term grab for statehood. Statehood should not occur at all without full Federal representation. There seems no reason to me to have it otherwise. I have consistently been of that view. In all of the time that I was a member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly's Committee on Constitutional Development, and as a Northern Territory delegate to two constitutional conventions, I held the same view. Indeed, I was on common ground in this with the former Federal member for the Northern Territory and the Territory's former Chief Minister, Paul Everingham.

The Senate was created deliberately on the basis that its membership would be totally divorced from the number of people in its constituent States. Federation would never have been achieved without that arrangement. It would be a sellout of future Territorians to create the precedent of a second-class State with second-class representation in the States' House, the Senate, even on a temporary basis. Temporary solutions in politics have a horrible habit of becoming permanent. Last week the Northern Territory Government proposed a campaign for statehood followed by, to my astonishment, a formal referendum next year. That referendum proposal is foolish and premature. Research by the Government itself last year indicated that 70 per cent of Territorians were either indifferent to or opposed to statehood. A `no' vote at a formal referendum held next year is not going to do too much to advance the cause of statehood for the Northern Territory.

One of the other problems is that a number of people in public life, to my sorrow, are portraying statehood as being the quick fix for all of the perceived Aboriginal problems of the Northern Territory. Let me say this: a referendum which will produce a result polarised on Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal lines is not going to help much to advance the cause of statehood for the Territory either. A far more sensible approach would be to initiate the campaign, certainly, and then to follow it with further research on the attitude of Territorians to the question. I will continue to work in this Parliament, as I did in the Northern Territory Parliament, for the achievement of statehood for the Territory, but only on the basis of it being on just terms for all Territorians.

I am conscious of the traditions of the Senate. I am aware of its history and the crucial role that it played in the founding of Australia as a new nation. I acknowledge its role as a House of review, and I acknowledge the great contribution of its committees to our parliamentary system of government. During the coming term there will no doubt be many issues before this House and its committees of crucial importance to the interests of the Northern Territory. The needs of the Northern Territory are great, but so is its promise. I will endeavour, during this coming term, to work for the further realisation of that promise by serving both the Northern Territory and the Senate to the best of my ability.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!-Before I call Senator Stone, I remind honourable senators that this will also be a maiden speech and I ask that the honourable senator be extended the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to commence my remarks by congratulating Senator Beahan and Senator Collins on their maiden speeches, although I would have to say to you, Mr President, that I had the strong impression in the case of Senator Collins that that was no maiden-that was an experienced person. Before contemplating this occasion I referred of course-perhaps I should not say `of course' but I regard it as a matter of course-to what I suppose is the bible of honourable senators, that is, Odgers's Australian Senate Practice. I found there that not merely is it a tradition but it is a time-honoured custom, as Mr Odgers said, that a new senator making his initial speech is heard without interjections, which you, Mr President, have been kind enough to remind the Senate of. But the balance to that-as in all these things there is balance-is that a new senator should not strain the traditions by being unduly provocative.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had some experience in drafting and I always like words such as `unduly', but I do assure you, Mr President, and indeed all honourable senators, that I do not propose to be provocative at all on this occasion. I did, however, have one qualm when I read that sentence, which I did only this morning, because it occurred to me-but I am sure this is not the case-that perhaps the injunction might also extend to the honourable senator's attire. Mr President, I hope you would not so rule as I would almost certainly have to remove my tie because, although I may say in that case that perhaps it could find a home in one part opposite, my tie is that of the H.R. Nicholls Society, of which I have the honour to be President. It is a most civilised body whose discussions were graced on one notable occasion, I should inform the Senate, by no less a person than the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh). I would like therefore, however, to assure honourable senators that when I put on this tie this morning I had no intention of being provocative on this occasion.

I suppose that there have been few more surprising translations to this place than mine. I look back upon the extraordinary-at least, extraordinary to me-events of the past few months. I believe I am correct in recalling that I was first approached to stand for the Senate for the State of Queensland on or about 4 June. I had never before that time been a member of any political party and, if I may confess a secret-a rather open secret-I had never before voted National. I have to add to that list of events, or non-events, the fact that also I never expected to return to Canberra in any formal capacity, and certainly not in this capacity.

These things tend to excite some attention in various quarters, and I have noted that some others have reflected upon the wisdom of this course on my part. One or two have even raised the thought that perhaps someone like myself, coming to this place so late in one's career, indeed having terminated an earlier career, might not have what I think they were kind enough to call staying power, and that after a brief period here I might find myself unattracted by this place. I assure you, Mr President, that those people may put their minds at rest.

Indeed, I recall that in 1971, when I was appointed Deputy Secretary (Economic) of the Commonwealth Treasury, just after Sir Frederick Wheeler had been appointed Secretary to the Treasury, my wife, who is a very wise woman, said to me, `Well, if you can last seven years under Fred, you will deserve to be Secretary to the Treasury'. I did indeed last those seven years, and I hope to last an equal number of years at least in this place.

I would like also, because I think it is appropriate to do so on this occasion, to note another comment that has been made in one or two quarters by some who have purported to express amazement at what they have asserted to have been my alleged attitude to the Parliament in my previous capacity as a public servant. I would like to do so in order to lay to rest very firmly, and I trust finally, any myths of that kind. In doing so, I wish to express, on the contrary, the deep respect in which I have always held the Parliament. In this my first speech in this illustrious place I would like to express my deep sense of the honour which has been conferred upon me by the electors of the great State of Queensland, and also my gratitude to the Party which has chosen to put me forward for that honour, including, if I may interpose a personal note, more than 5,000 Queenslanders who departed from their party tickets to vote for me personally.

I express those views about the Parliament, and in particular about this chamber, because of my sense of the abiding importance of the role of the Senate in the Parliament of the Commonwealth. As you may know, Mr President, I am a Western Australian. I hail from a very small hamlet-I would not think it is even dignified by the word `hamlet'-called Korbel, which is vicariously distinguished by being only about 30 miles from Doodlakine. Western Australians, like Queenslanders, have always tended to resent what they have, rightly or wrongly, discerned at times as domination from what they have chosen to call `the eastern States'. Therefore, the role of the Senate as a defender of our Federal Constitution comes naturally to me. If it had not done so, 30 years in the service of a Commonwealth government located, so far as its central administration is concerned, wholly in Canberra would certainly have led me to that conclusion. The fact is that in matters of government I have come increasingly to the view that small is beautiful.

I would like to turn now to one or two aspects of the Governor-General's address to which I think those remarks are relevant. On page 13 of the printed version of His Excellency's address to us earlier this week, he referred to the Government's intention to support an increase in the term of the House of Representatives to four years, and raised something of a smile on the part of members and senators assembled by saying that he trusted that in that case fewer elections would also result in less cost and inconvenience to the electors. I do not propose to canvass the issue in question, other than to say that, while I personally see merit in longer terms of office for our parliaments, I would oppose to the death any proposal to couple such a measure with proposals which would have the effect of reducing the role and powers of the Senate. I would therefore note in passing that, if the Government wishes in due course to seek truly a consensus upon this in itself rather non-contentious matter, it would be wise to confine its proposals to a very narrow purpose.

On another matter relating to what is sometimes loosely called State rights, at page 12 of his printed address His Excellency also referred to the current work of the Constitutional Commission which, he told us, will be recommending changes to the Constitution, and doing so next year, in our bicentennial year. On election night, on 11 July, the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, said, in a remark which evoked a warm response from all Australians, that the things that unite us are more important than the things that divide us. Again, let me simply say, without further canvassing the particular matter, that I predict that few things will divide us more, and more savagely, in our bicentennial year than any action on any proposals coming forward from that Commission which seem likely to undermine the established Constitution of Australia.

At another point in his remarks His Excellency referred to the Government's agenda for environmental action and he promised that the Government would consult with the Queensland Government and other interested parties in proceeding towards the nomination of the wet tropics of north-east Queensland to the World Heritage List by the end of this calendar year. Again, without canvassing the issue, I say that I am strongly in favour of processes of consultation but I only wish that processes of that kind were followed more at the outset of such matters than when firm positions appear to have been taken on the part of some of the interested parties.

Finally on this question of the federal nature of our Constitution, His Excellency referred in the concluding paragraphs of his address to the Government's commitment to the further development of local government. He went on to say that attention would be given by the Government to arrangements for the devolution of programs to local government. My rather simple view of the relationships between the Federal Government and local government is that by and large they have increased, are increasing and ought to be diminished. Recently in the State of Queensland there have been certain developments in this area which give rise to some disquiet there. I shall examine-objectively I trust-the facts of that matter but I foreshadow that this matter may need to be raised on another day in this place.

I meant to say earlier that I would return to the H. R. Nicholls Society-not to talk about that Society as such, but rather to talk about the topic to which the energies of that Society are directed, namely, the state of our industrial relations system, the system of wage determination and the determination of other conditions of employment in Australia, the effects of those systems on the capacity of the Australian economy to perform effectively and productively for the enhancement and enrichment of the lives of Australian citizens and Australian workers in particular and, above all, the role of trade unions in a free society and the power and privileges that trade unions have come to command in Australian society. I do so having in mind the great importance of this topic, not merely for the State of Queensland but for Australia. While we are at present directing our attention to the Budget brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) last night and all the macroeconomic questions to which that Budget gives rise, I am inclined to think-in fact, I do think-that there is no question in Australia today that is more important to the future of our economy and our society than the role of trade unions in that society.
The Governor-General had something to say relating to this question on page 3 of the printed address. He began by saying that the Government would continue its wages policy:

. . . which over the past four years has, together with the mature co-operation of the trade union movement, provided the foundation for outstanding employment growth, increased economic competitiveness and enhanced industrial stability.

I have very much in mind my need to remain non-provocative, but I want to say that 4 1/2 years on in the life of the present Government Australia now has external debts of $109 billion, just over three times the indebtedness that we had only 4 1/2 years ago. If one prefers figures for net indebtedness, as some people do, one finds that we have net indebtedness to foreigners today, after deducting the debts that some foreigners have to us, of $83 billion. That compares with a figure of only $21 billion 4 1/2 years ago. It is certainly true that our wages policy, together with the mature co-operation of the trade union movement, has provided the foundation for outstanding growth in something-and I suggest that that one thing it has provided the foundation for is growth in our external debt.

As to those factors providing the foundation for increased economic competitiveness, I am under the impression that that increased economic competitiveness in recent times-which I welcome-has come rather from the crash in the value of the Australian dollar. Some would argue that the combination of our wages policies and the mature co-operation of the trade union movement had been the single most important contributor to this crash.

As to the enhancement of industrial stability, views will no doubt differ. At a time when our coal mining industry is in turmoil and after the unhappy disputes over the past few years at places such as Mudginberri and in the Pilbara-I had some knowledge of the dispute in the Pilbara in my then capacity as a non-executive director of Peko-Wallsend Ltd; a capacity I no longer have-we have seen the degree to which our industrial stability has been enhanced. His Excellency went on to say:
The continued reform of outmoded work and management practices to raise productivity will also receive the attention of the Government over the life of this Parliament.

I certainly welcome that thought. I note that in the financial year just ended, 1986-87-and these figures are provided in the Budget Papers which were tabled in this place last evening-non-farm gross domestic product rose by 1.9 per cent in real terms. Employment grew by 2.3 per cent. That is another way of saying that national productivity fell by almost half of one per cent. Forecasts for the year 1987-88, in which we now find ourselves, provide for the growth of non-farm gross domestic product of 3 per cent. Employment is forecast to grow by 2 1/4 per cent, thereby suggesting an assumption of productivity growth of three-quarters of one per cent. This unhappily low growth in productivity is notwithstanding the special arrangements said to be made under the second tier of the present wage determination provisions deriving from the wage case concluded earlier this year.

At a later stage of his remarks in this area, His Excellency went on to remind us that, during its previous term of office, the Government was presented with the report of the Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems, the so-called Hancock report. Again, bearing in mind the conventions associated with a speech of this kind, I do not want to go into that matter in any depth. I do not in any way want to be contentious in doing so, but I do note that the Government has already abandoned its original proposals for transferring the jurisdiction for actions under sections 46d and 46e of the Trade Practices Act from the Federal Court of Australia to the proposed new Labour Court. That proposal, which was, of course, a central feature of the Hancock report, has been abandoned. Similarly, the Government has abandoned other proposals which were a central feature of the Hancock report for denying to employers their access to civil law remedies in the real courts of the land unless they had first obtained permission to bring an action there from the proposed new Labour Court.

Most recently the Government has abandoned proposals to increase and strengthen the existing sanction provisions in the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Act-provisions which have in fact been in disuse since the O'Shea case of the late 1960s-and in other relevant legislation. I urge the Government-I do so in no contentious spirit-to learn from this experience, not to proceed with the proposals to constitute a new Labour Court and not to proceed with proposals to enforce-I emphasise the word `enforce'-amalgamation of small trade unions, and so on. One reason for my concern about the Labour Court is that, apart from any other consequences it may have for our industrial relations system, I firmly believe that it will result in bringing the real courts into disrepute.

I conclude on this area by referring to the Governor-General's statement that the Government will also be finalising its policy on employee participation and industrial democracy, following a period of extensive consultation. Those are very sensitive issues. Again, the conventions of speeches of this kind preclude my saying many of the things that I would like to say about them.
