On this occasion I simply wish to say that I cannot think of many matters which have a greater capacity to divide our employer groups from our trade unions-or, more particularly, not so much from the trade unions but from the workers whom those employers employ-than these measures.

It is obvious that there is a role-I totally support such a role-for greater employee participation in our industries. There is a role for a greater recognition of the interdependence of interests between employers and employees. We need to see an end to the zero sum game mentality with which some people approach these questions. We need to see an end to the `them and us' mentality. I say again to the Government side of the Senate that those entirely desirable objectives will not be had by legislating for them, and they will not be had by forcing workers into a much smaller number of even more powerful trade unions, which by definition will be even more divorced from the localised concerns of the individual work places in which those trade unions' members operate.

Mr President, I hope that I have not transgressed unduly on the accepted canons of debate on such occasions as this, and I hope also that in sedulously seeking not to transgress them I have not erred on the other side by being dull. If so, perhaps I can be more lively next time.

In conclusion, Mr President, I thank very much the staff of the Senate for the many courtesies which in the very short time I have been here they have already extended to me. I express my belief in the traditions of this place of which you, sir, are the custodian. I thank the Senate for the courtesy with which it has heard me.

TALK.START.PARA: —I again remind honourable senators that Senator McLean will be making a maiden speech and I ask that he be extended the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, please accept my sincere congratulations on your re-election to your distinguished office and please extend my congratulations to your deputies also. I congratulate my fellow senators on their excellent maiden speeches.

SPEECH.PARA: To rise in this place is an honour afforded relatively few Australians and, like all who have done so before me, I savour the special feeling of pride and apprehension-pride in having been chosen, yet apprehension as to whether one is able to fulfil the great expectations placed upon us by our fellow Australians. This shared honour, Mr President, is our great bond; a bond not only among ourselves but to our people. Australians of all States, all persuasions and all circumstances must always be able to trust that our common and sincerely held intention is to serve them first. This common bond is their assurance that good will come from our efforts. Despite the imperfection of the process which occurs here, of which I am now a part, great good has come from it in the past. We salute all who have gone before us in this great service.

I take particular pride in rising in this chamber as an Australian Democrat. I might add, sir, that having contested seven elections for upper house chambers, State and Federal, I am somewhat relieved at finally having arrived. It has been a demanding and challenging thing to create a true citizens' party for Australians; one without vested interests and with the ideology of participation; one based on the principles of honesty, tolerance and compassion and one emphasising involvement of its grass roots membership.

I was a foundation member of the Australian Democrats and have held most State offices of my Party during its first 10 years. I know its strengths and weaknesses and I know the calibre and intent of those who founded it, who built it, who represent it and who belong to it. To them I say, `Well done and thank you'. I pay special tribute to my colleagues and predecessors, especially former Senator Colin Mason who rendered 10 years distinguished service to the people of New South Wales.

As my colleague Senator Powell did when she addressed this chamber for the first time, I must confess to being a typical Democrat. I think I know what is conveyed by such a label and I take pride in it. Of course, Mr Acting Deputy President, we Democrats claim no monopoly on honesty, tolerance and compassion, but we are different in that our Party does confer upon us the special privilege, indeed an obligation, of independence of thought and action to a degree enjoyed by few others in this place. We have also, rather presumptuously, undertaken to strive to maintain honesty not only among ourselves but also in the general political forum. Since we take both these challenges seriously our behaviour may be judged by some as odd. We therefore seek the forbearance of our colleagues in these matters.

In gathering my thoughts for this speech I read the maiden speeches of all my Democrat colleagues and quite a few others. It seems a common practice to reveal something of one's philosophical self, of one's motivations and aspirations, and I will do this briefly. We are all, of course, the product of our past but the psychologists tell us that along the way a relatively few and especially profound experiences shape us. These have been referred to as focal experiences. I confess to being a determinist in this respect and I believe that four or five extended experiences have left their mark upon me in my progression towards this new and exciting focal experience. I will cite them briefly because they will explain how I will behave here, what I will fight for and why I will fight for it.

I am the son of a coal miner and my mother was the daughter of a tin miner, and this explains a lot about me. I was raised among honest, hardworking people who knew nothing of real wealth or position. Although I was not raised in poverty, I saw enough of it to understand it. Such origins can sometimes give rise to a cynical, resentful acceptance or to a quiet determination. In my case it was fortunately the latter. Believing that a good education was the best thing they could offer me, my parents made great sacrifices to send me to an expensive and fine private school. This, the second of my focal experiences, was a very powerful one indeed. It gave me the opportunity of mixing with people of vastly different origin and circumstances, but most of all it left me utterly convinced of the profound importance of the educational experience. It also guided me to education as my profession and to an extended tertiary education.

It was at this time, as an undergraduate in the mid 1950s, that I was conscripted to national service in the Army. I did not find this a negative experience at all. I rather identified with attempts to inculcate in me and others qualities of leadership, endurance and physical and moral courage. I took a commission in the Citizen Military Forces and then in the Australian Regular Army (ARA) specialising in adult education and training. So, for almost 20 years I had an Army connection, and significantly these were the Vietnam years. Although I was fortunate not to see active service, I did have the good fortune of serving in the United Kingdom with the British Army on the Rhine. I therefore retain a real interest in, and have some understanding of, matters relating to defence in general and service life and veterans' affairs in particular.

In 1974, after 10 years ARA service, my family and I had lived in several countries and my children had attended a dozen or so schools and so the vagaries of service life induced my resignation-the same reasons which continue to cause the alarming resignation rate which we see today amongst service people. To this point in my life I had been essentially apolitical. I believed that the only vote worth having was a swinging one. Then followed an experience which changed me entirely.

Under the excellent Whitlam program called the Australian assistance plan I took up a fascinating role as a social planner with the Central Coast Social Development Council based in Gosford, New South Wales. I was a social catalyst in the community. It was my role to help, at the local level, in defining community objectives and priorities, marshalling resources, formulating plans and initiating and co-ordinating social action at the grass roots. It was a profound experience which taught me a great deal. I became convinced that at least some communities, indeed most, have great capacity to solve their problems if governments provide them with some resources and information and as little obstruction as possible. Furthermore, communities often work with great efficiency, responsibility, economy and accountability.

In short, I grew to believe in people power-power to the people-in the devolution of power out of bureaucracies and down to communities. I became hooked on participation; I became sceptical of elitism and disillusioned with some representation. I was a first hand witness to cronyism, obstruction and the downright lack of imagination of some in elected office and some in public service. In embryo and unconsciously I became an Australian Democrat. It only needed something to galvanise my new political being. Little did Don Chipp know when he resigned from the Liberal Party out of his frustration and disillusionment that so many others bearing their own discontent would seize the opportunity of forging a new political force that would so quickly achieve the balance of power in the national Parliament. That is history now and I am proud to have been a part of it.

My most recent focal experience, of course, has been to play a part in the founding and building of this instrument of people power, that is, the Australian Democrats. Mr Acting Deputy President, as you realise, as do all senators, to be politically involved is, in itself, very demanding. To successfully build a new political party is an extraordinary achievement.

I am sure that His Excellency in his opening address was covertly saying that we in this place must be more than law makers: We must adopt a much more innovative and imaginative role as primary change agents in society. The last three or four decades have seen an explosion in knowledge about society. We have observed, quantified, analysed and documented every conceivable aspect of our lives, yet we have hesitated to take control over our collective selves. We have not faced our responsibilities as change agents. The great challenge is for us to do so in a manner that is in line with an emerging democracy and which preserves civil liberty.

It is my view, sir, as a former social planner and social actionist, that governments must in future be much bolder and further sighted. There must be increasing emphasis upon initiatives which result in substantial and relatively rapid social change. Let me give an example of what I mean. It seems that many of our more serious social problems result from the negative aspects of urbanisation and are therefore correctable. I am thinking of drug abuse, rising crime rates, social alienation and aggression in all of its dimensions. Processes of deurbanisation and reurbanisation can be set powerfully in motion simply by a system of taxation zones which induces people to move from cities to rural and semi-rural locales. The very processes of relocation are socially and economically stimulating and new energy technologies offer a potential industrial base for such relocations. Energy can, of course, now be efficiently grown from sugar, wheat, sugarbeat and cassava. Therefore, the energy-employment-deurbanisation triangle offers great potential for innovation and bold government action. This type of massive social change can be readily effected within our free enterprise framework at quite low levels of economic cost and with huge social benefit. The trigger is, as I suggested, tax zoning.

Perhaps I can give another example of what I mean by bold social and attitudinal change that Federal Government could readily effect. This time I refer to another area of personal experience, namely, defence. Clearly, in a nuclear age and an essentially peace-seeking country, there is sense and great benefit in shifting emphasis in our defence thinking, organisation and materiel from the offensive to the defensive and from the predominantly military to the predominantly civil defence model. I am certainly not advocating neglect of our defences but rather a shift in emphasis. After all, in this country we still substantially fund our civil defence, our coastal patrols, our voluntary rescuers, our bushfire fighters and other critical organisations by selling cakes and lamingtons on street corners. Yet we resentfully spend annually billions of dollars on the maintenance of clearly inadequate and demoralised defence forces. This is fair neither to ourselves nor to those who have chosen to enlist in these inadequate and grossly neglected services. I hasten to add that, having been there myself, I have great admiration for them and sympathy for their circumstances. We can do much better. A substantially integrated structure, simultaneously providing for civil and military defence needs, is both desirable and possible. I can already hear the outcries of the traditionalists but I did not say that I was proposing bold and far-sighted models. I suspect that the community at large, especially young Australians, would regard such changes and opportunities most favourably. Voluntary service and training in the diverse areas of civil-military defence and community service would once again be attractive as we become decades and generations removed from the bitterness of the Vietnam experience.

As an educator, I must call on governments to face boldly the implications of our having created a near literate and numerate society. Through the expenditure of billions of dollars, by making education largely free and compulsory, and over several generations we have almost achieved universal literacy. Furthermore, we claim to be encouraging Australians to be critical thinkers, yet we sit back and let ourselves be force-fed vast quantities of junk and we move inexorably towards a national cultural malnutrition. An examination of any video outlet, any magazine or news stand or a night's viewing of television will attest to this junk diet and an analysis of crime and violence statistics starkly illustrates its effects.

Historically, in Western society, the church, the school and the family have been the repositories and transmitters of accepted value-sets. All three are under siege from materialism and are less and less effective in these roles. The vacuum has been filled by entrepreneurs who have successfully contrived and marketed value-sets and sub-cultures for profit. The youth sub-culture is a striking example. As legislators we must be prepared to make judgments about the merits of such value-sets and sub-cultures and to take steps to arrest and reverse processes which we see as social decay.

As people become more educated and have access to more and more information they will inevitably demand greater participation in the decision-making process. If democracy does not move in that direction it will not survive at all. I have a strong conviction, therefore, that electoral reforms which provide for heightened participation must be given high priority.

In the 10 years since my predecessor, Colin Mason, proposed citizens' initiative to this chamber the climate has moved significantly towards it. Certainly, the Australian Democrats will propose it again in the very near future. Clearly, the current debate in the community concerning the Australia Card proposal and the refusal, so far, to grant a referendum on the question will dramatically heighten interest in mechanisms for citizens' initiative. It is ironical that any Australian can go to a special place, called a TAB, in even the smallest town, take a piece of paper off the wall and express an opinion. We offer our opinions about the most irrelevant of questions such as, `What will win the third race at Randwick on Saturday?' and that sampling of opinion will be processed in the most sophisticated computer in the land. Indeed, the results of that opinion sampling may be seen on every television screen in the country that evening in the form of the TAB odds. Yet we cannot have a say about whether we should have a national identity card, a new national flag or nuclear ships in our harbours. Such ludicrous contradictions will not be tolerated by the community much longer. We, as Australian Democrats, intend to ensure that.

Governments of today and tomorrow must be bold, imaginative, innovative and far-sighted. Australians will increasingly demand that they be so. I look forward eagerly to serving the Australian people and my Party in the pursuit of structures, processes and legislation which promote justice, democracy, freedom and the quality of life of Australians now and in the future. I truly believe that the Australian people wish the Democrat presence in this place to be a lasting one. I congratulate my Leader, Senator Janine Haines, on an excellent election campaign which clearly enhanced the public profile and image of our Party. I am deeply honoured to serve my country in this way. I thank my wonderful wife and family for their support and sacrifices and the members of my Party and the voters of New South Wales for their confidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Bishop I remind the Senate that this is a maiden speech and ask all honourable senators to extend the customary courtesies to Senator Bishop.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —As I rise to speak on this occasion as a senator for the State of New South Wales I am deeply conscious of the honour that has been bestowed upon me. I would like to place on record my thanks to the voters of New South Wales for their confidence, to the President of this chamber and to other honourable senators, and to officials and staff of the Senate itself for the courtesy and help that have been extended to me.

SPEECH.PARA: For me this is the fulfilment of a schoolgirl aspiration. At the age of 17 I decided that I wished to pursue a political career. I have asked myself many times why I chose politics so early and I can say only that it came from a study of history. History showed me that the world had two groups of people: firstly, it had those who were part of the decision-making process and actually had some say in the direction that the nation in which they lived took. The second group of people were those who had decisions made for them. I determined that I wished to be part of the decision-making process.

Again at the age of 17 I chose to join the Liberal Party. I chose it for a very specific reason. It stood for the things in which I believed and, indeed, in which I still do believe. In particular, it espoused four freedoms: the freedom of the individual, the freedom of choice, the freedom to pursue excellence and the freedom to seek reward for effort. In the Liberal Party those freedoms were available equally to men and to women. So it is with a little pride that I stand here as a little bit of history-that I should have become the first elected woman senator for the State of New South Wales, the mother of all parliaments. I have also asked myself why it has taken so long and I have answered: `It is the strength of the competition'. I console myself in the comfortable knowledge of the excellence of the contribution made by senators who have preceded me.

I come to this chamber with areas of specific interest and areas in which I feel I have gained some expertise. My major area of interest is the Pacific Basin, our own region. Since the early 1980s I have been a member of the Pacific Basin Economic Council (PBEC). In the last 12 months I have been a member of the executive of the Australian committee of that Council. It is a private sector organisation which comprises national committees of Australia, New Zealand, Japan, the United States, Canada, Korea and Taiwan, with a regional committee that covers the states of the Association of South East Asian Nations, the Andean states, the Pacific Island states, and the Latins so that they, too, can have a choice in this important body.

The words and the terminology that I use in the pursuit of lessening protectionism and lowering tariff barriers as well as non-tariff barriers are `freer and fair trade', as distinct from `free trade', which in the current world is an impossibility. No nation will ever relinquish all of the controls it uses, be it the mechanism of realigning its currency, dumping, or various mechanisms that are not seen as being tariff barriers themselves. At the meeting of the PBEC in Seoul last year I had the honour of chairing a session entitled `Trade Initiatives in the Pacific Basin'. On that occasion I was able to give to an audience which largely comprised Japanese and Korean delegates a paper which looked particularly at the question of agriculture and the barriers to trade in agriculture. It was important on that occasion to make the point, as I did, that if we are to see freer trade in our region it is necessary for Japan and the newly industrialising countries which follow in her stead to open their barriers and allow reciprocity which will permit the sort of trade which allowed Japan to grow to prosperity in the post-war period through a lessening of barriers and the growth of manufactured goods. It is interesting that the resistance to that argument is lessening at successive meetings. I was in San Francisco this year when again the question of agricultural trade was raised in forums with Japanese and Korean delegates. Finally, the rhetoric is beginning to change.

In recent years in Australia we have particularly felt the effect of protectionism in the area of agricultural trade. Between the years of 1973 and 1984 we saw the European Economic Community, by the use of its common agricultural policy, go from being a net importer of food to being a net exporter of food. In the 1980s we have felt the effect of subsidised wheat exports on our markets and we saw the bipartisan group of parliamentarians go to Washington to put our case for the United States not to export subsidised grain.

Our problems really began in the 1970s. The oil shock of 1973-74 and the recycling of OPEC dollars led to a very high growth particularly in the newly industrialised countries and the lesser developed countries. During that period there was enormous growth. The volume of trade in agriculture in those countries developed by 34 per cent and in lesser developed countries by a staggering 120 per cent. So there was planning in the major food producing countries. There was increased investment in research and development and in grains themselves. There was increased development and investment in acreage. There was a general belief that prosperity in the trade of food would continue to grow. Although the volume of trade had grown by 34 per cent, the price of that trade had also increased to 34 per cent. Thus we have reached the situation in the United States now where the debt that has been escalated by farmers, which in turn has put banks which are dependent on agricultural business at risk, has resulted directly from that recycling of OPEC dollars back in the early 1970s.

The growth came to an end with the world recession in 1981-82. It was then that the International Monetary Fund (IMF) stepped in to reschedule loans of debtor nations. It required two fundamental changes in policy by those debtor nations. When looking at the World Bank and the IMF, it is interesting to see the degree to which those organisations are becoming involved in the internal policies of member nations. It is quite a serious and growing problem. In the period 1981-82 when the debt crisis became great it required, firstly, that the debtor nations become self-sufficient in food and, secondly, that they cut back on imports. They did that very effectively. The growth in our export of foodstuffs from the developed to the developing world was largely based on a change of taste with a developing middle class. When these factors were phased out and debts had to be met, they were very effective in becoming self-sufficient in food again and in cutting back on imports-mainly ours. We now have the classic result of protectionism. We have stockpiles of agricultural products. We have declining commodity prices and we have a clamour for additional protection.

Historically, we can look back even further to the inception in 1947 of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). In 1947 agriculture was covered by the GATT, but in 1955 the United States of America said that the question of trade in agriculture and food was more important than just trading in a commodity. It said that it was about national security. This is an argument that we are now encountering from Japan, Korea and like countries. It then opted out of the GATT, and other countries, seeing what the United States had done, did likewise. They simply said, `If you are not going to be bound, neither are we'. So that slow but gradual buildup of protected agricultural industry began as early as 1955. It was good to see that there was a bipartisan approach by this Parliament to the problem. We need to phase out trade in subsidised agricultural products. It was good to see that bipartisan approach in insisting that agriculture became the dominant item for the multilateral trade negotiation round which is presently going on.

Having stressed the importance of trade in agriculture, I now turn to what I think is the growth area for trade in Australia. It lies with the services area. This is not in any way to decry the importance of a healthy manufacturing sector, but I would like to make some comparisons. Measured as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP), the following statistics are quite revealing. Manufacturing industry is now 17 per cent of GDP, down from 29.3 per cent in 1959. The health industry is now greater than our retail industry, at 6.9 per cent. The education industry is now larger than our construction industry, at 5.7 per cent. The business services industry is larger than our mining industry, at 6.1 per cent. In 1986 tourism became larger than agriculture in GDP terms. To put it another way; one Japanese tourist visiting Australia is in monetary terms equal to the export of 20 tonnes of Australian wheat.

By 1988, 30 per cent of all world trade will be done in services. This should be compared with 1888 when 70 per cent of all trade was done in agriculture. The forecast for the year 2088 is that only 10 per cent of world trade will be in agriculture and mining. Australia is presently dependent upon agriculture for 40 per cent of her export earnings, 40 per cent on the extractive industries and 20 per cent for the rest. We have a major problem which we have to face. Our major extractive export earner is coal and coal is in for a tough time.

Not only are we in the position where our major trading partners simply renegotiate contracts, but also we have to realise that that same trading partner has equity investments in mines in southern America, that South Africa is selling coal on the spot market at a most attractive subsidised price. And more and more worrying for Australia is the fact that there is a very large deposit of coal in Kalimantan in Indonesia which is highly accessible, which is superior in grade to that which we take out, particularly of the southern coal mines of New South Wales.

We have been able hitherto to be able to get away with some of our work practices and some of our on-costs on the basis that we were selling a superior product in coal. But once the grade of ore from Kalimantan comes on stream we are in for a really tough time. It was interesting to hear the Treasurer (Mr Keating) say in the Budget Speech last night that he expected, or hoped, that gold would make up for the loss of earnings in the coal area. There is no doubt about it; the service area is where the service competitive edge for Australia must be honed.

The Pacific Basin is a place which we have regarded with benign neglect. It is no longer the tranquil place that its name suggests. Earlier this year I was in Fiji at the time of the coup. It brought home, I think, to all of us who were present that the change and challenge of the Pacific and indeed the Western Pacific, which is our bailiwick, has not been attended to in our policy decision making. Our relations with Indonesia are at an all time low. Our trade with the countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations has diminished in the last four years by one per cent. Clearly, we do not have a good record in dealing with the nations in our own neighbourhood.

I spoke earlier of the profound influence that history has had on my career. Well, the history of this country also records that on 3 December 1854 the Victorian gold miners revolted against legislation which required them to produce on demand, under penalty of #5, their miners' cards. This resulted in the Eureka Stockade. I sincerely hope that history does not repeat itself in the present climate and that the freedom of the individual of which I spoke earlier remains just that-the freedom to be an individual.

In the last two years I have had the honour to serve my Party as President in New South Wales. I have made a particular point of being very active and serving the people in the west of Sydney. I have made a decision and an undertaking to open my office in Parramatta, the demographic heart of Sydney. It is important, I feel, that the many people who vote Liberal in those areas are served by a representative when they have no other opportunity at this moment to be so served. I am concerned with the grass roots aspirations of the ordinary people of Australia. We hear in debate much discussion about trade unions and trade union power. However, trade unionists are just awfully good Australians-Australians who care as much as anybody in this chamber about the hopes and aspirations of their children and their children's children. The Australia that I want to see and hope to leave to my children and my children's children is one that pays heed to those freedoms that I began to speak about at the beginning of my speech-the freedom of choice, the freedom to pursue excellence and the freedom to seek reward for effort.

As I go forward to serve not only the members of my Party-because I have now been elected to an office which must be more important and broadly based than just those who support us-I sincerely hope that I will keep in mind the grass roots Australians for whom I have so much admiration and respect and with whom I wish to stay very much in contact. I have been honoured to have a hearing such as this for my maiden speech. I know it is customary to place on record again one's thanks to one's family and to one's friends, all of whom have been of assistance. I do not want to do that in a pro forma or merely formal way. I feel that all of us who come into the political arena who have husbands or wives or children have to come with a team effort, with a willingness for it to be a family commitment, or the life simply is not possible. I do hope I have earned the support that my family has given me. I hope I have earned the support that my friends and my Party have given me. I hope I will continue to earn the support of the people of New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for your contribution, Senator Bishop. Before I call Senator Burns, I remind honourable senators that this is his first speech in this chamber. I therefore ask all honourable senators to extend the normal courtesies to him in the course of his speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with a tremendous amount of pride that I stand in this chamber tonight, feeling the power which has been placed in my hands by the electorate of Queensland-power that I will be using in the interests of the people of that electorate and in the interests of all Australians. I also have a deep sense of humility in terms of the trust that they have placed in me and my ability to discharge that trust 100 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: In my experience of dealing with people who have been either politicians or budding politicians I have heard them when congratulating each other make such comments as, `Isn't it great, you are now in the House; you are a parliamentarian', as though that were an end in itself. I want to make it clear to everybody in the chamber and to those people out there listening on their radios that my position in the Senate represents to me only a tool, such as a carpenter or cabinetmaker would use to produce a beautiful piece of furniture, or a weapon that one would use in defence of oneself. I see my role as a tool or a weapon to be used at appropriate times. I will be seeking to create a better life for all Australians and to defend them against excesses and exploitation.

Senator Stone made a comment in which he used the word `provocation'. I guess that is a word with which I have a lot of familiarity. I find it difficult when waging a spirited defence or fight on behalf of people I represent to be otherwise. I guess that feeling is similar to the one behind a statement which people make so many times, that they will not talk about religion or politics. These are probably the two matters upon which most arguments develop and which are the most interesting that we talk about in life.

I understand the role of the House; I understand the attitude people have about States rights. I am an Australian from Queensland standing in this House. I have long believed in Father Christmas. I no longer believe this is a States House in the sense that it was when it was set up all of those years ago. In those days it was appropriate to regard it as such. But I saw a Labor government destroyed by an action of this House in 1975, and it was certainly not in the interests of the reputation of this House and what it was seen to stand for. I have seen our Government in Queensland, for its own narrow, selfish political ends, ignore the fact that electors in that State had decided that they should be represented in a particular way by a particular party political senator and send another person who did not represent those views. So I understand how the House works, and I hope to make a contribution to seeing that it works in the best possible way in the future. I hope never to see an experience such as I observed in 1975.

I had a very early knowledge of the need for political activity on behalf of trade unionists. After all, they and their families make up the majority of the community in Australia. I was raised in a family. My father was a railway engine driver all of his life; my mother was a housewife. They said to me then: `When you have the vote, vote for the Australian Labor Party; a crook Labor Party is better than a good Liberal Party'. I question, I suppose, the level of intellectual understanding of life and where it goes embodied in that statement, but I do not question their experience and the correctness of what they were saying to me, as it has been shown to me over a period of time. They also relayed to me their political experiences in terms of putting faith in Labor politicians rather than Labor Party policy and Labor Party principles. When my grandmother was approached by a politician who had been in the Labor Party all his life-she had voted for him for some years-he said: `You know, dear, I had to leave the Party; the Party has changed'. My grandmother said: `Mr Grant, you've changed, not the Labor Party'. So I learned a few lessons even as a young boy about what life showed one, what principle was about and what I should do given the opportunity.

My experience as a trade union officer with the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union, the metal trades group of unions and the Trades and Labour Council of Queensland helped to create within me a strong desire-a determination-to serve those people who were forced to band together as trade unionists to seek reasonable wages and working conditions within an environment permeated by the greed of the majority of employers who required low wages, unsafe working environments and insecurity of employment. These were the means by which they terrorised workers into accepting their role as factory fodder to be used in the pursuit of more and more profit. I have read some articles about the 1898 shearers dispute. When I talk to some people about it they say that I am old enough to have been there, but that is not true.

I heard Senator Stone talk about the real courts. What I say now is not intended to reflect at all on current courts. I have read an historical document which indicated that during that shearers strike a Chief Justice in Rockhampton who was hearing a case suggested that the police should have used their revolvers on the strikers because they were creating a problem with the free labourers. I am sure that that experience did not encourage people to have more support for the real courts and less support for the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission which was set up later. I would suggest that both of these areas have a role to play in our community in terms of creating the right sorts of conditions by making decisions which are seen by all to be good decisions in law, that care about people and ensure a proper, fair and equitable opportunity for all in the community.

I mentioned the word `power' a while ago. I have found that people seem to look at this word and say, `Well, it is disgraceful'. They seem to think that someone is intending to stand over someone else-that someone is intending to misuse some ability that he has. In my view, `power' is a word that should be used often because it can be used to create good circumstances for people in the community. It can create better living standards and it can be used to defend people. However, power can also be used for evil.

The trade union movement that I worked for was a very defensive organisation. All that it worried about was living standards, industrial health, wages and working conditions. That union allowed employers to set the agenda in respect of manufacturing and job opportunities. I must say that in those days the Australian Labor Party to some degree tended to head in that direction. However, the Labor Party still argued about other things. Of course, the trade union movement is so often accused of taking into its hands power and doing things that are against the interests of the community. However, the trade union movement talks about things like disarmament, world peace, being opposed to the use of nuclear weapons and directing funds that are now used in the so-called pursuit of defence. In fact, it is very hard to think of an intercontinental missile being a defensive weapon because it can be used to destroy the other person before it destroys us. I am sure that our best means of defence lies in trying to create the sort of world where we can all live in peace, using an international court to resolve our problems, and having more consideration for people wherever they live. We should be seeking an increased quality of life for all of them.

The trade union movement has been at the forefront of the struggle for civil liberties. Aboriginal people are amongst those who have had fewer civil liberties as a group than any people in this community. I must say that the trade unions were involved and helped, as did the Labor Party when in opposition, in the days when little money came from governments to help these people. So the trade union movement has a very good principled and moral attitude in that regard.

I was interested to hear Senator Bjelke-Petersen talk about people marching in respect of the ID card. I can remember one night being the guest of the Queensland Government in a watch house cell because I dared to take into my hands, as did about 5,000 other people, the right to march down the street to protest against uranium mining. The situation is as the honourable senator says-it depends on what one represents; not whether one wants to put forward a point of view to which one has a right. The right to march is there if one wants to seek to destroy or discredit a Labor government. In fact one is welcome to do it. However, if one is going to do something that will help the workers to oppose the National Party Government in Queensland, one will find oneself on the end of police action.

I have always believed, and I state here for the record, that the majority of police in Queensland are decent people. It is not untrue that a lot of people who criticise them seek their help when they are in trouble. That is a true statement. There are many police who give that help. There are many who see their job as one that is needed in the community and they handle that job in a responsible and humane way. However, a small group of police is prepared to be used by any government of the day, as a Labor government did in 1948 against the trade union movement, and beat people down in an unmerciful way. So I do not want to be treated to another dose of hypocrisy about the use of marching to protest about something with which we disagree.

The trade union movement has been in the forefront of protection and conservation of the environment. I join with my friends in the Australian Democrats in regard to their attitude to those things. I recall that when we sought to stop mining on Fraser Island, which is probably one of the most beautiful islands in terms of beach area that one would find, we were threatened by the State Government with all sorts of dire results. Finally, the island was mined. I do not enjoy having to say this, but I must note that the Fraser Government at that time prevented the mining by some use of sanctions as far as exports were concerned. That is why it was good to hear Senator Chris Puplick say that he also agreed that we should preserve the rain forests in north Queensland. But there again we have a situation in which police have been used against strikers as they were in the South East Queensland Electricity Board dispute in which people were arrested and charged incorrectly as a result of an appeal to a higher court. Police were used against those people.

Senator Graham Richardson, our Minister for the Environment and the Arts, went to north Queensland and was attacked by short-sighted, unthinking, fascist-type people-there may be some risk in using that term because I intend to go up there myself. He was attacked and it appears that he got very little help from the local constabulary. I must say that my advice to him would be that next time he should take the Australian Federal Police with him. I do not believe that he should be subjected to that sort of thing when he is carrying out a task, which has the support of the majority of the people of this country, to protect an area which is so beautiful and pristine as is Fraser Island and that I mentioned a moment ago.

However, the maintenance of such areas do not seem to concern the Queensland Government at all. In fact, the Queensland Government seems to have a propensity for getting people to knock down historic buildings at night time. I am surprised that it does this because it does not like paying overtime. However, apparently the Queensland Government gets these people to work on the cheap. One can go to bed one night thinking about going the next day to have a look at something that is historic and can never be replaced and find that overnight it has been destroyed. I am talking about things old and not so old that have a place in the hearts of the people of Queensland. Again, this shows the concern of the Queensland Government for anything decent.

The trade union movement supported, as has the Labor Government, the proposition of public ownership of enterprises. I will fight fervently for those public enterprises to be maintained and owned in the interests of the community.

The trade union movement, as I said a moment ago, has always been fairly defensive when faced with those people who seek to exploit the community by shifting pieces of paper around at the stock exchange and in the banking system. Those people will have to pay the bill for better social services and for whatever reductions in taxation can be given to the ordinary people in the community. After all, to give those who create the wealth, those who make things with their hands and those who give their services and use their brains to create a better opportunity and to increase their standard of living, it is fairly obvious that those people who shift the paper around will have to pay the bill. When we look at the wealth they have accumulated, we see that there is plenty there to give away without leaving them destitute.

People talk about what is in the best interests of this country. Who should decide this? Should it be the owners of the means of production and finance? My answer is no, it should not. Should it be the labour movement, which seeks a broad input which is consensus oriented? My answer to that is yes. Workers participating in enterprises have been successful in West Germany. Many employers and other people have accepted that as a way in which industry can operate, but only on the basis that they feel that tame cat unions have pandered to the wishes of employers. But I am one of those people who believe, and the trade union movement is an organisation which believes, that we should involve the trade unions in decision making so that, in the process, they accept responsibility for certain results and certain standards of performance in the production of goods and services.

Some people talk about participation in the way in which they might, if they were an official in a government, suggest to a condemned man, `How would you like to go-would you like to be hanged or put in the electric chair?'. He would be participating in the decision. The end would be pretty much the same and not pleasant. The involvement of workers in the important area of retraining and in the restructuring of industry is tremendously important. We can see the way in which the two-tier wage argument by the Australian Council of Trade Unions was put together and the resulting decision about how people could justify to the Commission an increase in wages for various classifications. Ten years back down the track nobody would have thought that certainly the Metal Workers Union would have accepted that we would have to forgo some traditional ways in which we worked-in some cases receiving some additional money and in some cases being guaranteed job security-albeit they were very impractical and very ineffective ways in which to operate.

Let me say that that way of operating, by using two or three people to do a job that one or two should do, we were taught by employers. Under the old system of cost-plus after the war, the more something cost the more profit was made. Of course, when it came to the situation of contracts with fixed prices, the trouble began. We were asked to break out of the traditional way in which we had seen things. I must say that we were not encouraged to do it because of the way in which it would affect us. But in more recent times we have come to realise that it is not possible to stand still and that, if we are selfish, we in fact do harm not only to the community, but also to ourselves and to those we care most about.

Some years ago a document called the prices and incomes accord was put together. For the first time, a government and the trade union movement agreed to a centralised wage fixing system which at least dampened down wage increases and set up principles by which wages could be given. We must look at that in light of the fact that in the previous 18 months the Fraser Government was in power and there was an escalation in prices of some 9 per cent which meant a loss in real wages of 9 per cent and no wage increases at all. Anybody who thought the trade union movement could accept that, even if it had wanted to, was quite foolish and certainly ill-advised. For the first time the Government and the trade union movement were able to get together in the interests of the total community. That was an important stage for both the people in the working community and the Government to reach.

Primary industries have always been a very important part of our productive effort. They have also brought in a lot of income from overseas for many years. The old saying that Australia rode on a sheep's back testifies to that in history. The mining industry has contributed a tremendous amount in that regard. Miners have gone down into the bowels of the earth and risked their lives, and some have lost them, whereas the people in charge have only had to worry about losing their profits-and they do not seem to have done that in recent years. They want to cut costs, cut workers' wages and cut workers living standards and they never look at cutting their own profits. I say that because it is my experience.

It is hard not to get into a debate with Senator Stone, because he says things that really need to be discussed. I would not say that he was right, even if I thought so, because he might assume that I agreed with him, and I would not want that to happen. He talked about there being an enlargement of debt, and it is true that that has happened. Senator Bishop said that there had been a reduction in manufacturing from 29 per cent in 1959 to 17 per cent in 1987. Anybody who thinks that that reduction has occurred by accident either has not kept up with what has been written in the newspapers or has not read documents that have come out of this Parliament or have been publicised and distributed by other organisations in the community.

There had been a definite policy to destroy manufacturing industry, particularly in Queensland, and to foster the mining and minerals industry and, of course, the primary industries as a whole. No wonder that occurred. That policy has had a tremendous effect on the balance of payments. If we want to understand how, we have only to consider the value of a shipload of wheat exported from Australia to Europe and compare the cost of transport and the invisibles-the money that goes overseas-with our ability to develop technology and to develop markets to which we could send the same ship full of computers. This would be of tremendous assistance in trying to turn around the balance of payments. I am not suggesting that farmers should no longer grow and export wheat, but I am suggesting that the manufacturing industry is of vital importance to this country.

The trade union movement again came good, as it always does, and produced a document, a copy of which I have here, called Australia Reconstructed, which seems to have been criticised by everybody in the Opposition. But my impression is that they are always careful not to read it before they criticise it. I am sure that anybody in the New Right who read it would do so with a fairly jaundiced eye and would not look objectively at it.

What is our position with regard to what took place in the past? In this country we have been using ancient machine tools, many of which are over 50 years old. We have had bad management and a dishonest response to union and government measures. I refer here to the heavy engineering package and other forms of assistance which the Government has given in terms of training and retraining and to the question of wage restraint and the higher profits that went with that at a time when we were being continuously told by Liberal-National Party governments that, if we were prepared to forgo wages, higher profits would result and more investment would go back into the industry so that jobs would be created. That is what we were stuck with.

We now have a different situation. We have a trade union movement that wants to see amalgamation so that it can become more efficient in the way it approaches its daily work and in the way it can contribute to a more efficient industry-not for higher profits for a few people, but to create riches for the whole community which can be reallocated through taxes or other measures which can be introduced by the Government, or in some cases by negotiation between the parties at the levels of management and labour. That document is a strategy which goes to the question of fairness and equity.

Let me quote a couple of items dealt with in the document. It talks of investment for import replacement, export expansion and industry modernisation. I do not know anybody who would oppose that as a principle or a goal. It also talks of new product, process and new enterprise development. Any self-seeking or even a decent businessman would want that. It then talks of management and work practices to improve the efficiency of enterprises. How could anyone argue against that? It also deals with dispute settling procedures. I have always advocated dispute prevention procedures. It deals with occupational health and safety. A healthier person in a safe working environment will always produce better quality and greater quantities of goods and services. It deals with industrial democracy and workers having a right to a say in the community and in what they do. There is also the obtaining of equal opportunity, particularly for women, which the trade unions have successfully struggled for and won.

That is the background I come from, and it is from that background and from that point of view that I will be struggling in this chamber by way of debate and influence, and outside the chamber as well, on behalf of people who have those sorts of goals and aspirations that are in the interests of the whole of our country. Let me say, though it may be seen to be foolish, that there will even be occasions, when someone from the other side comes up with a good proposition, when my innate honesty and integrity will not allow me to disagree.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for your contribution, Senator Burns. Before calling Senator Tambling, I remind honourable senators that this is the honourable senator's first speech in this chamber, and I would ask that the normal courtesies be extended to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is indeed a challenge to respond to the Speech by the Governor-General to the Parliament. I have enjoyed and appreciated the courtesies that have been extended to me in the past few weeks by the 16 other new senators in this chamber and also by the staff of the Senate and the Parliament generally and many other people who have encouraged me in coming here. I have also enjoyed the confidence and support of my predecessor in this place, Senator Bernie Kilgariff, and of my wife, Sandy. I have had the opportunity to represent electors in the Northern Territory at four levels of government-local government in Darwin, the Territory Parliament itself, the House of Representatives, and now in this Senate. Therefore, this is hardly a maiden speech. However, like my Senate colleague from the Northern Territory, Bob Collins, who spoke earlier today, I will never be apologetic about being parochial in my advocacy for the Northern Territory, and it will be a real pleasure to take up causes in this place for all Territorians. I will reciprocate the trust and support of my Northern Territory electorate and party political supporters and my family.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I would like to illustrate some of the issues of the Northern Territory by taking some of the Senate's time to concentrate on examples of a few vital and involved Territorians. Their lifestyles and their contributions to the community will be the types of issues and concerns I would like to become involved in in this place. Thanks to the history books, the achievements of the early explorers and pioneers of the Northern Territory have been recorded for posterity. Names like McDouall Stuart, Leichhardt, John Flynn and Hudson Fysh spring to mind. But what of the present day pioneers who have put their faith in the future of the Territory by settling there and contributing to the development of this great frontier part of Australia? Many people are today accepting the challenge of living and working in a part of Australia they believe has the potential to become the greatest State of Australia.

Take Maurice Blake and his family, who have sunk $2.5m into a lime plant near Mataranka. They have done it alone with no government help, and after four years of getting operational they look forward to full production, which could be worth $7m a year. The lime will be processed for gold mines, as a neutraliser for the acid in the rock during gold extraction, and a big percentage is being used at the Ranger uranium mine.

Can honourable senators imagine ice-cream being manufactured in and exported from the tropics? It seems an unlikely idea but that is exactly what Helen and Frank Lo Castro hope to do when their applications for the necessary licences are approved and they appoint overseas distributors. Theirs is an extraordinary story of persistence and hard work, which started in 1977 when they started a home occupation business producing and packing gelati on a small scale machine imported from Italy. They have now expanded into frozen pizzas and three packaged frozen beef dishes. Frank is Italian, a builder by trade, and he and Helen, who is Maltese, met in Darwin and married. He spent a year building their new factory on the outskirts of the city and Helen took on the production, marketing and delivery of their products. At present they distribute only throughout the Northern Territory and have not yet made inroads interstate. For the past three years though they have been sending samples to Brunei, Hong Kong and Singapore, and with the help of Austrade when their licence applications have been approved the sky will be the limit. The Lo Castros borrowed heavily to get started, and their persistence and faith in their product should soon pay dividends.

Another brave venture in the Top End of recent years was the establishment south of Darwin of a crocodile farm. The brainchild of Malcolm Eardly, it was considered as crazy, financial suicide, and many other unkind things, but today his faith has been justified. He is no longer connected with the venture, but thanks to his foresight the crocodile farm is a thriving enterprise with an assured future. It has three shareholders-Lowan Farm Products, which incidentally is another modern pioneering effort, Territory Milling and Hannon Properties.

Since the passing of legislation allowing the farming of crocodiles for their skins, the Darwin Crocodile Farm has found its feet after an initial period when it was kept afloat by tourism. The first shipment of skins will be ready for export in October and firm offers from potential customers in France, Singapore, Germany, Italy and Japan are expected soon. In full production the farm expects to reach $1m in exports. With the other two farms in the Top End it is estimated that the export earnings will exceed $5m in the initial stages, and much more later. Top End saltwater crocodile skins are considered the best grade in the world and will be eagerly sought.

A director, John Bache, says the present rosy situation is the result of six years of research and development and a colossal gamble on whether crocodiles could, in fact, be bred in captivity and whether legislation could be passed allowing skin farming. He says the prospects today are excellent because of the legality of Australian crocodile farms which safeguards overseas buyers through a tagging system of the skins.

Another of the thriving enterprises in the Top End is the 60-acre tropical fruit farm established at Humpty Doo, south of Darwin, by K and M Farms. In only one year this has developed into a million dollar industry with the potential to become a multimillion dollar industry. K and M Farms can be described as the `brains and brawn outfit'. The brains are supplied by business manager Fred Karlson and the brawn by Harry Murray. Harry is a real down to earth latter day pioneer who came to the Top End about 20 years ago after a varied career which included growing apples and pears in New South Wales. The farm's main crop is now rockmelons, but it also produces watermelons, butternut pumpkins and all tropical fruits. After experimenting with the infertile soil in the area and adding the necessary trace elements and fertilisers, Harry has found that the farm can cope with a double planting of melons every year. Further experiments such as this could see the success of triple planting.

Together with Arnhem Produce and Homestead, K and M Farms has formed a new company, Brolga Exports, to give continuity of exports. Rockmelons and mangoes are exported to Singapore three times a week when they are in season and markets in Europe are being singled out and explored. According to Harry Murray there is no shortage of markets. The limiting factor in his business is a shortage of land and the high cost of water is also crippling, with one seasons's bill being around $25,000. Harry is the sort of guy who works from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m. at peak periods. He has the real pioneering spirit and he says he loves the life and would not consider leaving.

Another spectacular success story in the Northern Territory is concerned with health. It is the Menzies School of Health Research, established as a joint venture of the Northern Territory Government, the Menzies Foundation and the University of Sydney. The school was conceived as a centre of excellence in research and post-graduate education on matters of relevance to health in tropical and arid regions of the Northern Territory. Special characteristics set the Territory apart from the rest of Australia in that its health problems are those of both developed and developing societies. The Territory has a need for special programs of health education and research, particularly in the areas of heart disease, trachoma, chlamydia, hepatitis B, alcohol-related diseases, nutrition and infectious diseases generally. Research and educational programs are already under way in these and other areas. In the longer term the school will expand its activities into the South East Asian areas, particularly in the field of post-graduate studies.

The development of the school was made possible through the activity and support of many individuals and organisations. The Menzies Foundation offered to provide money to meet the costs of a director for the first three years. International academic standards were ensured by the agreement by the University of Sydney to recognise the school as a department of its faculty of medicine and financial security was assured when the Northern Territory Government agreed to provide funds for the school for an initial period of five years. With the tightening of the economy, fund raising has become a major issue. Fund raising from corporate and private donors is necessary to develop new initiatives and complement the basic funding from the Northern Territory Government and the Menzies Foundation. Specific research projects are funded by seeking grants in open competition with the best researchers in Australia and overseas.

In an overview contained in the school's first two-year report, the director, Professor John Mathews, said there was no doubt that the greatest challenges in preventive medicine were in the area of Aboriginal health. In the short term the possibilities for preventive social action were limited by the availability of funds, the difficulties of delivering preventive and health care programs to those in greatest need, the differences in social perceptions of health and the causes of ill health and by the limited numbers of highly trained Aborigines who could develop, explain and implement programs in Aboriginal communities. He said that there was a need for more Aborigines to be trained in relevant administrative, technical and professional skills to help resolve some of these difficulties.

Professor Mathews pointed out that not only would the school contribute to the national and international research efforts to reduce the toll caused by high blood pressure, diabetes, heart diseases and cancer but it was also uniquely placed to discover new strategies for the prevention and treatment of health problems which are particularly frequent in northern and central Australia. For example, although otitis media is a major cause of deafness and educational impairment in Aboriginal children the primary cause is unknown and there are no effective means of treatment or prevention. The school has developed a multi-disciplinary program of research to test the hypothesis that otitis media is caused by infection of the ear by chlamydia, the germ which also causes trachoma. If this proves to be the case, this will have important implications for the prevention of ear disease by means of a vaccine to prevent chlamydial infestation. The Federal Government could play an important part in ensuring that the work of the school continues by giving it what it needs most-money.

In the field of education much is being done. At one end of the education spectrum in the Northern Territory is the newly established Northern Territory University College, financed entirely by the Northern Territory Government since the Federal Government declined to provide finance before 1991 at the earliest. Courses started in February this year and include Bachelor of Arts and Bachelor of Science. Post-graduate enrolments for Master of Arts, Master of Science and Doctor of Philosophy will be accepted from this year onwards. Under a contract degrees will be awarded to graduates by the University of Queensland until the college becomes an independent university.

Commonwealth expenditure per capita on tertiary level education in the Territory is lower than in other States. The provision of funds on the same per capita basis would go a long way to financing the university development. Proof of the need for a university lies in the fact that at the beginning of this year 247 students enrolled and 206 attended. Next year the Northern Territory University anticipates that more than 400 students will participate.

At the opposite end of the spectrum are the schools of the air at Katherine and Alice Springs. The Katherine school covers 800,000 square kilometres and services 225 students. There are 18 teachers backed by a clerical staff of eight. The Alice Springs school covers 1.56 million square kilometres covering the area north to Renner Springs, east to the Queensland border, west into Western Australia and 300 kilometres into South Australia. Fourteen teaching staff, supported by five clerical staff, provide education for 142 students. The principal, Fred Hockley, says the greatest change in his 5 1/2 years has been the introduction of the home video loan scheme, the brainchild of Malcolm Fraser in 1981 and continued by successive governments. He said that the scheme cut down the disadvantage of isolation and that educational television programs could be copied by the school of the air and sent to outback students, providing an invaluable service. It is to be hoped that this scheme will continue to be funded by the present Federal Government. Mr Hockley points out that the proliferation of television dish antennae has not eventuated. In the area covered by the Alice Springs school of the air only 15 per cent of families have a satellite dish to receive Australian Broadcasting Corporation programs, giving the lie to the belief in the south of a boom in information to the outback.

Another great change was the shift in status of the school's pupils. In 1982 between 75 and 80 per cent of the pupils came from cattle stations. Today it is 55 per cent. The reason for that is that greater services are going to Aboriginal communities. The people in the bush are still waiting for something more technological to happen. From being top of the list for satellite reception they are now far down the list. Communication in the bush is still very poor. Many people, particularly those living in the south, believe that there has been a great technological push to the outback but schools of the air such as Alice Springs and Katherine will be needed for some time yet, especially with the present move to outback areas because of extension to road construction, tourism and other development.

The Northern Territory has a history of trade with Indonesia that predates by centuries the arrival of Europeans in Australia. In more recent years the Northern Territory has been working on building even closer co-operation between the two areas. A recent visit to Indonesia by the Northern Territory Chief Minister, Mr Steve Hatton, and a party of seven officials highlighted the importance placed on close ties with Indonesia by the Northern Territory Government. While he was there Mr Hatton made special mention of the teacher and student exchanges and the development of education exchanges between the two countries, opportunities for mutual developments in tourism, cattle and buffalo exports and co-operative health programs.

Close ties are also being established with the promotion of teaching of Indonesian as a second language throughout the Northern Territory school system. By 1990 it will be compulsory for all primary students and will be available to every secondary student. Already there are more students studying Indonesian in the Northern Territory than in the rest of Australia. The ties also extend to cultural and sporting exchanges, from boxing to the Darwin to Ambon yacht race. The ties now also extend to commerce from the private sector in Alice Springs.

Getting in on the ground floor has been the secret of one of the most successful manufacturing companies in the Northern Territory, Peter Morgan Refrigeration. Peter moved to Alice Springs from Adelaide in 1985, which turned out to be a boom time for the town. The company manufactures mobile cool rooms and with great gusto the enterprise was developed in earnest. Through Austrade, Peter promoted the company through Indonesia and Malaysia and he is on the verge of signing joint manufacturing contracts which could result in an initial 100 units being sold in Indonesia alone, worth about $1 1/2m. Peter believes there is limitless potential for his type of business in South East Asia. In Malaysia he is on the ground floor because of the value of his product to primary industry and fishing-two of the main industries in that country. Added to that, he says he has heard nothing but good reports in feedback about his product.

The Territory's most important natural resources are minerals. For more than a century mining has played a key role in Territory development. Last year the mining industry produced mineral products with a value of over $1 billion. As projects now being developed come into production, the growth in value of the industry's total output will accelerate. At present there are seven major mining organisations extracting uranium, bauxite, manganese, gold, silver, lead and zinc. In addition, one firm is producing uranium oxide from stockpiled ore. There are also smaller mining operations recovering tin, tantalum, gold, lead and silver. In the Pine Creek area the revival in gold mining has been led by Pine Creek Goldfields Ltd, a joint venture between Renison Goldfields Consolidated Ltd and enterprise Gold Mines NL. This company started operations at Pine Creek in October 1985 after two years of exploration. Initial investment was $35m, and another $10m has been added this year to increase output by 40 per cent. The budget of 58,000 ounces of gold for the 1986-87 year has been exceeded with the production of 61,702 ounces. The engineering superintendent, Russell Luxford, believes the operation has a life of six to seven years with expansion to ground close by which could prove viable.

It is particularly pleasing to report that the Aboriginal community is also producing its modern pioneers through the medium of tourism. From the far north on Melville Island to the Centre, Aboriginal people have become involved in establishing closer understanding between blacks and whites. On Melville Island, a joint development between the Tiwi people, the Tiwi Land Council and Australian Kakadu tours has been launched, although the Land Council has no financial equity in the venture at present. The venture is at Putjimirra on the north-west of the island, with the Tiwi people providing the guiding services for two, three, four and five day tours with fishing, foraging and hunting. This venture started in May this year and is working well.

In Kakadu, one of the traditional owners, Mick Alderson, is operating Bamurradjadjam (Wild Goose) Tours with development assistance from the Northern Territory Tourist Commission. Mick's tours are restricted to his own part of Kakadu and emphasise birdlife and Aboriginal land use. His tours started in July after eighteen months of preliminary work, and today average 45 per cent loadings.

In the centre, Herman and Mavis Malbunka, and their assistant Alison Hunt, run Ipolera outstation west of Hermannsburg. This is a joint development with assistance from the Tourist Commission, the Central Land Council and the Aboriginal Development Commission. A two-day tour to the outstation also takes in Palm Valley and Glen Helen Gorge. Men and women are taken separately for bush walks to religious sites and to sample bush tucker. They are then brought together for billy tea and damper. Of course, these are only a few of the pioneering tourism enterprises that are operating successfully throughout the Northern Territory.

In addition to these individual efforts, the armed services are also playing their part in the pioneering of the Northern Territory. The Royal Australian Air Force's new base at Tindal and naval expansion stand out. In particular, I will mention the Australian Army which has a role at all levels of military involvement in peacetime and wartime. Principally there is the presence of Norforce, which was established in July 1981 as a successor to the 7th Independent Rifles. This unit has a war strength of 637. Its present strength is 292 plus 36 regulars. A recruiting program is planned for October. Norforce operates over 1.76 million square kilometres of the Territory's top end and into the Kimberleys. It is breaking new ground in defence areas. Norforce was a defence pioneer in that it was the first of the three regional force surveillance units formed to date. The others are in the Pilbara and Cape York. In turn, Norforce will be supplemented by another pioneer, the 2nd Cavalry Regiment, which will be in the Territory in force in 1992 with a strength of 850 and support units.

It is worth noting that Norforce has also pioneered the training of Aborigines and has developed an excellent relationship with Aboriginal communities through their presence in the bush when on exercises. The majority of patrols are required to live off the land and to supplement issued rations when they are out in the bush. This emphasises the importance of a close relationship that has been established between the Defence personnel and the Aborigines.

The pioneering efforts of these people that I have mentioned and dozens more have helped to stabilise the Northern Territory and to hasten its march towards statehood. That march is now at an end. It is time the Federal Government recognised that statehood is essential now if Territorians are to take their place as equal Australians, with the same rights, privileges and responsibilities and the same degree of self-determination as other Australians. Territorians will no longer allow themselves to be treated as second class citizens.

It has already been announced by the Federal Government that financially the Northern Territory will be treated equally with the other States from next year. If the Northern Territory is to be funded on a State-type basis and at the same time have the full range of responsibilities and rights, it is only fair that Territorians should have statehood. The long term evolution of the Territory has been towards statehood and it is now not a question of if but when. The Northern Territory and its people have proved themselves. With statehood, this great gateway to Australia could become the great northern State of the future. This is a unique opportunity for the Labor Government to become a pioneer because the opportunity to grant statehood will not come again in Australia's history.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the motion for the Address-in-Reply. I wish to focus particularly on page 5 of His Excellency's Speech where he deals with the area of defence. His Excellency, on behalf of the Government, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The policies outlined in the Defence White Paper presented to the last Parliament will further enhance Australia's defence capabilities and increase the involvement of Australian industry.

In recent times there has been a lot of praise for the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, and for the Government's Defence White Paper referred to by His Excellency. With the help of a loyal news media, more garlands will no doubt be heaped on the Minister and the document. Make no mistake about it: for saving us from the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities, the Minister does deserve some gratitude. However, we should not get carried away with gratitude. The White Paper is a competent document but it is not a work of strategic genius. After all, it leaves out of its considerations the whole of Australia's western flank and its exposure to the Indian Ocean and to strategic developments there. A job left hugely incomplete cannot earn top marks. The fact is that the White Paper is still only a draft statement. The Government and its departmental and academic advisers have a long way to go before they can produce an integral strategic policy for Australia. This policy needs to take into account the extraordinary growth of Indian naval power and to contemplate what India plans to do with a navy twice the size of any two regional navies and equipped to conduct sea control operations on lines of sea communication which are important to Australia and vital to our neighbours and trading partners.

The fact that these important questions have not been considered in the White Paper reflects a view widespread in the defence bureaucracy that India does not form part of our region. It is true that India is a long way from Australia and that an almost empty Indian Ocean stands between us. Madras is 6,653 kilometres from Perth and 5,510 kilometres from the North West Cape. There is a lot of water for an invader to cross and there are no handy jumping off points even for those parties of raiders which loom large in the figuring of the Government's defence advisers.

From the North West Cape in the direction of India, the nearest land is Christmas Island, 1,613 kilometres away and the Cocos Islands, 2,150 kilometres away. Being occupied Australian territories, they would not be ideal places from which to launch a surprise swoop on to the north west Australian coast. So why then does Australia need a two-ocean navy, as it has been grandiosely called in the White Paper, with one half of it based on HMAS Stirling? It is unlikely that the purpose of an Indian Ocean fleet is to throw back a sea borne invasion by India.
