If honourable senators look at the White Paper they will find no fully essayed rationale for having an Indian Ocean fleet. Admittedly, on page 12 of the White Paper there is this important observation:
Australia's region of primary strategic interests lies in South-East Asia, the South-West Pacific, and the East Indian Ocean.

However, while the White Paper devotes space to discussing South East Asia and the south west Pacific, there is no discussion, not even a line, on the east Indian Ocean. Oddly, Antarctica, which is outside our area of `primary strategic interest' rates two paragraphs. The best the document has to offer on the subject of a western fleet is a few scattered fragments of suggestions and elementary strategic insight. For example, under the heading `Naval infrastructure' on page 47 of the White Paper we read:
. . . homeporting of major fleet units at HMAS Stirling recognises the need for the navy to be able to operate effectively from both coasts for the direct defence of Australia.

Understood in the light of the Government's strategic assessments, the phrase `direct defence' means counter action against attacks, short of all-out invasion, on the Australian mainland or our territories or against our coastal shipping or offshore installations. That is how the phrase `direct defence' is described on page 24 of the White Paper. One can infer from the White Paper that the Government believes that small forces operating from Indonesia might be the most likely threat that our Indian Ocean fleet would have to deal with.

A look at the map makes it clear that naval forces deployed from HMAS Stirling are well positioned to defend against military action originating from Indonesia and for launching counterattacks in Indonesian waters. Clearly, Indonesia's south-western flanks are as exposed to attacks delivered from our west coast as that coast is from attacks launched from the north. This exposure of Western Australia to the north dictates the need for substantial defence forces to be deployed in the west. Beyond the facts of geography are those of international relations. The White Paper reconfirms at page 3 Australia's obligation to provide protection and control for shipping under the Radford-Collins agreement. Under this agreement, Australia's area of maritime responsibility in the Indian Ocean extends out to longitude 60 degrees east, that is, almost to Mauritius. Now this fact is not mentioned in the White Paper. Instead it hints that in times of crisis Australia would consider meeting its commitments under Radford-Collins only after it had met priority requirements in our own area. Nevertheless, the Government has admitted to having international obligations in the Indian Ocean.

If one draws together these separate threads, the White paper can be made to yield some of the basic components of the case for a Western fleet. The point to bear in mind, however, is that they find no integrated expression in the White Paper. If somewhere in the mountains of Department of Defence bumf there is a fully matured strategic basis for an Indian Ocean fleet, it has not found its way into the White Paper. Perhaps it is a well kept secret.

I suspect the reason for this silence is that if the White Paper had actually surveyed developments in the Indian Ocean, the document would have sunk the Government's strategic posture. If the White Paper had discussed the Indian Ocean it would have had to mention the rapid growth of the Indian Navy, its tremendous reach, its two aircraft carriers, together with a replacement which is on the way, supported by Soviet-built Kresta class cruisers and replenishment ships, as well as its bases in the Andaman Islands from which India can threaten the Malacca Straits. This has serious implications for our allies under the Five Power Defence Arrangement-Singapore and Malaysia, our neighbour Indonesia, and our chief trading partner, Japan.

If the White Paper had discussed the question of the Indian Ocean it would have had to explain the use India intends to make, for example, of its Russian-built Bear F long range anti- submarine warfare aircraft. These aircraft have a range of 5,000 kilometres which would enable them to observe vessels travelling Indian Ocean routes with Australian trade, to direct Indian submarine attacks against these ships and to combat our own submarines from points relatively close to our western shores.

As one would expect, Soviet arms bound for India are sometimes modified to suit special Indian requirements. It is not beyond the bounds of possibility then that India's Bears have been modified to fulfil an anti-shipping role, a development that would make a lot of sense. In this case the Bears could directly attack surface ships.

The significance of India's Bears lies in the fact that they probably will be used in combination with India's growing submarine fleet. At the moment the Indian navy has eight diesel-electric submarines of the comparatively outdated Soviet Foxtrot class. However, the Indians have embarked on a major expansion and modernisation of their submarine force. They will add to the fleet six West German Type 1500 and six-or possibly more-Soviet Kilo class submarines. So, depending on the rate at which the Foxtrots are withdrawn from service, the Indians will have within a decade between 12 and 20 submarines, supported by maritime reconnaissance aircraft-quite a force.

There has also been a suggestion that India wants a nuclear-powered submarine, possibly the Soviet Echo II, which is armed with either Shaddock or Sandbox anti-ship missiles. These missiles can be fired from a submerged vessel and be directed on to their targets by Bear D reconnaissance aircraft. Were India's Bear Fs modified to incorporate the capabilities of the Bear D-a development which would seem to be demanded by the acquisition of missile-firing nuclear submarines-India would have the capacity to attack in the West even Australia's coastal trade. Information about these developments has been on the public record for at least 12 months. They surely would be known to Australian military intelligence. Yet none of the questions posed by the growth of Indian naval power were discussed in the defence White Paper. Probably the reason for this has been domestic political rather than strategic or diplomatic. Consider this question: how could the Hawke Labor Government justify a strategy which eschews defence of the sea lanes and denies the need for carrier-based aircraft at the very time when a great regional military power is developing the capacity to project naval and naval air forces into Australian waters?

I do not in any way want to be taken as suggesting that India is developing these forces to attack Australia. However, we should not turn a blind eye to these developments. We should foster good relations with India, an area with which I have been particularly concerned. I was a member of a delegation of this Parliament which visited India some time ago. Nor should anything said by me tonight be taken as being a reflection on Indonesia. I believe, as has been said by somebody in one of the maiden speeches, that it is very important to maintain and develop close relations with our neighbours. Nevertheless, at the very time when Australia has rejected a strategy of power projection and sea land defence-rejected in the defence White Paper-India has undertaken to develop forces capable of dominating our Indian Ocean lines of communication. The mere existence of this capability ought to be a warning to us, and ought not to be ignored, particularly in a document such as a defence White Paper.

Australia has abolished its fleet air arm and now the RAN will have to hug the coast to be within range of RAAF air cover. This year the Indian aircraft carrier Vikrant will be joined by a second, Viraat, formerly HMS Hermes. There are plans to build a third carrier in India, a copy of Britain's latest HMS Ark Royal, as a replacement for `Vikrant'. The Indian Fleet Air Arm will field some 27 `Sea Harriers' and 66 helicopters, including those based on cruisers, destroyers, and frigates, of which 24 will be advanced Sea Kings armed with anti-shipping missiles in addition to their usual anti-submarine weapons. There will also be 62 other fixed-wing reconnaissance and anti-submarine aircraft. By any standard this is a formidable force.

Then there is the rest of the Indian Navy. It will be able to boast three Soviet Kresta II cruisers which will be modified with an upgraded SAM area defence system; at least six Soviet Kashin II destroyers; and an Anglo-Soviet mix of 23 frigates. Keeping in mind the large submarine force already mentioned, it is clear that the Indian Navy is being designed to do far more than to counter the much smaller Pakistani Navy, whose offensive force consists of six submarines. What the Indians intend to do with this fleet is a matter more of educated guesswork than of certainty. Intelligent people that they are, the Indians play their cards close to the chest. Apart from maintaining-quite correctly-that India must be able to defend her Indian Ocean lines of communication if she is to develop as a major industrial and trading nation, India has given few hints about how its Navy serves national defence and foreign policy objectives.

Nevertheless, I believe that it is possible to sketch the outlines of the new role which India could be preparing to play in world affairs. Given India's huge army powerful air force and its apparent preoccupations with Pakistan and China, one might be tempted to think of India as primarily a land power. The fact that the Indian Navy was, until recently, the forgotten service might have lent some credence to this view. However, India has a huge coastline and the sea offers her both dangers and opportunities-the opportunities for the expression of power and the expansion of influence denied her on the borders with Pakistan and China.

India's problem is that she is hemmed in by her land borders. For a start, there are the Himalayas which pose a barrier to expansion in some ways more formidable than an ocean. In any case, India faces China in that area. On one scenario advanced with which I do not concur, India may wish to flex her new and more sophisticated military muscle to get square with China for the defeat suffered in 1962 and the loss of uninhabited territory in the Aksai Chin. I emphasise that this and other scenarios are mentioned here because they have been advanced as possibilities. We should always bear in mind our responsibility to understand the legitimate concerns of India and maintain friendly relations and frank dialogue with that country. Mr President, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
